SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what I am speaking on. I assume it is some amendments moved by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the shadow Opposition Minister, but I do not mind, because I believe that the Government has made the greatest mess of Australia's telecommunications that it is possible to make. After all the struggle and negotiation we finish up, like the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), huge and monolithic. It is unwieldy; a national and an international organisation locked together. A small, tight, profitable organisation, OTC Ltd, is being locked in and unionised with Telecom Australia so that Australians become captive to this massive organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: With all the opportunities that the Government had to do some imaginative thinking, at the end of the day the Minister, Telecom, the Department of Transport and Communications and the unions had their way and threw out those more enlightened people within the Cabinet and their propositions. They have stuck Australians now with a hopeless organisation, something that has as its competitor an organisation with a few satellites. The Government is hoping that somebody will come along with some finance and buy it up. The captive audience is sitting by interlocked with Telecom so as to provide an alternative service to Australians. That is the process the Minister wants Australians and this House to accept as an alternative, as an advance into the future for this important area of telecommunications.

It is not good enough. It is nowhere near satisfactory for the current and future needs of Australians. The new socalled competitor will be dependent upon Telecom; it will be controlled by Telecom. The Government has formulas and X factors and so on to control the interconnect process of the new competitor to allow it to operate effectively. That organisation will be controlled by the worst of monopolies. So the competitor really is dependent on the sale of its product; it is dependent on being sold itself; it is dependent on capital in a scarce capital market; it is dependent on people willing to take a risk against a monopoly, a huge organisation. Its usefulness will be limited unless it is allowed to operate effectively.

The control and conditions to be applied by the competitor are dependent upon the management style of Telecom because Telecom will be the main contributor to the so-called regulator, Austel. The information being supplied to Austel can be directed by the Minister. Then at the end of the day, he has further control. Where does he get his advice from? He gets it from the Government-owned organisation, Telecom, and the Government Department. So we have a Minister who can give directives to Austel, the so-called regulator. Then at the end of the day, when he gets that information from Austel as to what he should do, he relies on advice not only from his Department and Telecom-two government-controlled organisations-but also from another controlling factor of the Australian Labor Party, the Telecom unions; powerful and significant organisations.

How can the Minister come to the Parliament and present this as an enlightened alternative, an advance into the future? It is wrong in concept. The Opposition from day one has said that the Government has been wrong in creating this massive organisation by putting OTC in with Telecom. That was the Government's first mistake. Its second mistake was to try to convince the Australian people that there was going to be anything but a two-airline policy of the radio waves, because that is what it has created. The Government has the same sort of regulatory process and watchdog sitting on top of this duopoly as it had with the two-airline policy. It scrapped that policy, saying that it was not working, but it has not learned from that process. We endorsed the scrapping of the two-airline policy. When in government we were moving in that direction. But at this point the Government has re-established that process as, it claims, an interim measure.

The problem is that once there is an interim measure established it becomes permanent and gets extended. The legislation says that there will be new competitors by 1997, but Australia needs new competitors now. We need to open up that market if we are going to capture trade opportunities worldwide and in our near vicinity.

The two-airlines policy was administered by a price setting authority; the Government is going to have Austel controlling this organisation. Not only is Austel going to facilitate the interconnect process and the operations of the competitor-and other competitors in the future-but also it is going to be the policeman. Not only will it set the rules and the operation processes, but also it will police whether people are abiding by those rules and decisions of itself and the Government. That is unworkable. There is not a nation on earth that thinks that can be done where the regulator, the facilitator, is operating as the policeman. Not in Britain or the United States or anywhere else is there such a concept. How can we have the person setting the rules judging whether people are abiding by those rules? Australians are going to get the worst of every world in this process and these decisions.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991 is a process which establishes the movement from the organisations that exist now-that is, OTC Ltd, Austel and Telecom Australia-to a new so-called commercialised structure. Part of the process that I wish to deal with in the brief time that I have available involves the factors that the Government has put in place which will set the price for that interconnect process. There is an X factor in the formula which is the basis of the Government's decision and it is supposed to relate to the cost of supplying the service. The Government has refused to put in place any idea of a complete audit of Telecom to establish what its real costs are in this process of setting fees. Until that is done, no-one in Australia knows what Telecom's real operating costs and real cost factors are.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me point out to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) and to the House that Telecom was the organisation which said that the community service factor for supplying remote areas of Australia cost it $800m. Subsequently, over a period, that argument has been demolished. Telecom stuck to that argument for five years to demonstrate how much support it needed from the Government in order to supply this community service factor. It did not have to justify its figures and it did not have to support the claim that the cost was $800m. It then turned out that the figure was about half that amount, and that was subsequently accepted by Telecom as being the right figure. The amount of $400m is approximately the cost to Telecom and the Australian taxpayer of that community service delivery. How can any-body in Australia accept that the Telecom organisation is either capable of supplying or willing to supply accurate figures as to the cost of that X factor in the formula which will be the basis for fees and licences that will be set?

It seems to me that unless the Minister and the Government are prepared, during this transitional stage in this process as outlined by the Bill before the House, to have a full audit of Telecom conducted by an outside organisation so that the community at large and those people who are setting up to compete against Telecom will know that they are dealing with accurate figures, those people cannot be certain that they are not being dudded in the process.

There is a factor for amplification of Telecom services. Every additional service has an amplification factor; there must be more cables or more wires or more switching gear further back in the system. That can be built in. Who is going to check all of that process? Where is the so-called transparency, if the X factor right at the beginning does not start from a sound basis? In any transitional process, such as in the setting up of boards, the setting up of combined management techniques, or the setting up of new proposals to allow Aussat and other competitors to assess whether or not they are going to enter this market and supply real alternatives to Telecom for the Australian people, clear guidelines have to be laid down. How can the competitors have confidence if in this transitional process there are not clear guidelines that will ensure fairness?

People say that there is a tilt in the process with the X factor and the consumer price index factor taken into consideration. Maybe there is, and I believe that there should be. But how do we know that the starting base is right? We do not know the starting base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that this Bill be now read a second time.
—The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the fee setting process in my comments on the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill and I wish to pursue that a little further. The Government has established what I consider to be, given world trends, a reasonable price cap figure for supplying services, and the fee setting process is one that is in conformity with world practice. However, the price control formula is far from satisfactory unless soundly based. It is my view that, if we are going to foster genuine and sustainable competition-and those are the words of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley)-then right at the beginning there has to be certainty in the process. The Minister has given no assurances of any certainty whatsoever. There must be a requirement on Telecom Australia to provide that certainty.

SPEECH.PARA: I have given one example of where that large organisation has for years misled the Australian people or, if not misled, has not been capable of supplying accurate figures until somebody else went and did them for it. That is a shame, because that outside organisation supplied factual information on the real cost of supplying telephone services and other services to remote areas-the community service factor which every Australian really feels should be part of the communications system and which, by the way, would be a factor that must be supplied by any competitor.

The use of the word `transparent' applied to this area, as used by the Minister in his speech, is just an inanity. It is not transparent. The Minister has a hidden process of setting the X factor; he has a recommendation by Austel to himself. Sometimes he gives it a direction, then he makes the ultimate decision. He is the director of this process; he is the grand conductor of it. It is not an arm's length process. I know that the Minister, in the setting of licences, ultimately should have the say. I know that the Minister has an important role in this process and I would not want to take that away, but he has too much of an involvement.

The facilitator and the regulator in this instance are the single same person, and that person is almost captive to the Government, or can be captive to the Government; and that is not what the Australian people want. They want to have released into this field some real dynamics whereby those people around the world pouring brilliant stuff into this process of telecommunications and the linking of computing processes with telecommunications will open up a new future for Australia. That is going to rely on what Austel and the Minister think should happen. I believe Austel's facilitating capacity should be in some way split from its capacity to act as a policeman. It is the only way we are going to get fair play out there when we get a few really full-blooded private competitors in the field.

It is the only way that the Minister or the Government will know what Telecom is up to. Unless we separate those things the needed advice will not be available. There will be no sureness of direction and decision making which is needed in this vital area.

I am really fearful in this situation that we are going to waste the next two years anyway-this Government will no longer be the government after that-while a huge organisation continues to muck around with the lives of Australian people. There are good people in Telecom. It is a good organisation, but it needs to change.

—The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AND OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``the House declines to give the Bill a second reading, as it is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for:
(1) its failure to allow reasonable time for consideration of this measure; and
(2) adopting a structure for the Corporation which:
(a) will not meet the stated intention of achieving greater competition in Australia's telecommunications industry;
(b) does not make adequate provision for the capital requirements of the Corporation;
(c) provides for an unjustified `merger fee'; and
(d) does not make adequate provision for future private equity''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.
—I indicate that we will be intending to divide on this Bill. I thank the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) at the table for allowing us to proceed in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also indicate, as I did at the commencement of this debate yesterday, that I think it is a tragedy that we are not going to be able to have a detailed debate through the committee stage of all the matters which relate to this Bill. This is a major change in the Australian telecommunication industry and the significance of the change will touch every Australian over a period of time. We believe there are fatal flaws in this Bill, as many of my colleagues have outlined.

Indeed, we have had a series of shadow Ministers here speaking-the shadow Minister for privatisation, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale); the shadow Minister for environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney); the shadow Minister for trade, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer); and indeed the last member who spoke, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) will take some moments to indicate some concerns as well.

Many people on the Opposition side have been involved in the preparation of what has been a very detailed and complex package of legislation-the most complex that I have dealt with in the seven years I have been in this place. It is much more complex than the energy and resource taxation legislation and it has been a challenge to everyone. Although I do not usually do so in this place, I want to thank two particular people on my staff, Vivienne Shield and Robina Mitchell. Indeed, the departmental staff whom I have dealt with have been excellent.

To mark the significance of this particular piece of legislation, it is of note that sitting in the gallery we have today the Minister of Communications from New Zealand. New Zealand has made tremendous strides in this area. I acknowledge those strides and I think it is particularly significant that the Minister, Mr Williamson, is here today to witness the final stages of this Bill.

With those few words, I will leave it to the honourable member for Lyne to indicate why we are opposing the amalgamation of OTC Ltd with Telecom Australia. The legislation is bad law and bad prospect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My criticism of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill is that it does not properly cater for privatisation. I believe that the efficiency of Telecom Australia has improved, particularly in recent years. We have to appreciate that technology has improved not only throughout Australia but throughout the world, and this has been evidenced in the telecommunications area.

SPEECH.PARA: But there are factors about the legislation that concern me. The main one is the fact that the Government has gone only so far with privatisation. The Government is being very cautious, though naturally we respect the fact that it has to take note of the unions to see that they are agreeable to the legislation. This has been done, as evidenced by the fact that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has not been able to go as far as I am sure he would like with privatisation.

Telecom itself should have had the machinery, and particularly the financial means, to be able to extend its services throughout Australia. There has been improvement, and I think that an extension of services could have been achieved, but Telecom required extra funds to do so-funds that were beyond the ability of the Government to supply through the Loan Council. Telecom itself has indicated the amounts that would be needed in order to keep up with the technology and development that we would like to see throughout Australian cities and country areas.

I believe that either we should extend the services of the telecommunications organisation or we should completely privatise telecommunications. I am of the opinion that, by creating a situation for the operation of only Telecom and one competitor, the Government has not gone far enough. Austel will be in charge of the lot, answerable to the Minister. I have no objection to that; I think it should be answerable to the Minister when there is a small number of organisations-and there will be only two organisations. If there was complete competition, there would not be a need to be answerable to the Minister. However, I believe that the Minister must have the final control under the set-up proposed under the present legislation.

We will see competition in the telecommunications field only if there are four, five or more players. We may see that after 1997, as mentioned in the Minister's second reading speeches on the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill and related Bills, but there is no certainty that we will see it or that we will see in Australia the competition that is so necessary to provide extra service, particularly to the people whom I speak about, the ones in the outback areas, the rural areas of Australia, who I believe deserve it.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) spoke very convincingly about opportunities for our balance of trade in exporting our technology-exporting it particularly to the Pacific basin area, but to anywhere overseas. We have in Australia the brain resources and the technology to enable us to export the things that we have developed, particularly to Asia, but I am principally concerned about giving our own people here in Australia the service they deserve.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) last night spoke about the educational side of telecommunications and what it can extend to people in outback areas; that is very important indeed. I know that honourable members who, like myself, represent the rural areas of Australia are often chided by the Government because they speak of cross-subsidisation, but that is a very big factor as far as we are concerned and I will not belittle it. I believe cross-subsidisation can be catered for if we have true competition in the telecommunications field. If that true competition were to exist, I would accept that there may not be a need for cross-subsidisation because that competition would keep down the cost of extending services to the country people of Australia.

People in my electorate are often 20 or 30 kilometres up the valley from their nearest neighbour or even from a person who has a telephone. We are concerned about these people. As well as manufacturing industries and the smaller businessmen around the country, these are the people we do not want to see paying those extra charges. I make no excuse at all for the present cross-subsidisation because people in country areas are disadvantaged to a great degree as far as freight and general costs are concerned.

They are the people about whom I wish to speak today in order to emphasise to the Government that unless it goes right down the line with privatisation and puts everything into competition, the legislation now before the House will not be sufficient to allow for the matters I am addressing. Will they be catered for within a budget? For example, if there is a competitor to Telecom and it says that it will take a line to a certain point, whether that be the front yard or the street front-it might be five miles down the road too, and that is important-the property owner who wants the telephone will have to pay the extra cost to get it put on.

I welcome the involvement of private enterprise in the maintenance of telephones and the laying of a lot of the cables. I do not believe I am wrong in what I am saying; I believe I am correct. If honourable members looked at the legislation and said `Righto, this is not the case', I think they would be wrong. I believe it is the case. If I am wrong, the Minister might inform me where I am wrong in regard to the connection point further down the road or outside the property, which, as I said earlier, could be quite a distance away. I emphasise my concern about the provision of a service to people who require a telephone that needs to be of a particular quality simply because of the distance between their property and a telephone exchange.

I am also concerned about the cost of a local phone call. I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that untimed local phone calls will remain. In my electorate, anywhere around the countryside, and even in the suburbs of cities, if someone rings a person a mile away that is not a local phone call, and that is because of the zones that are within the area. Because such phone calls are not local calls, they will cost more. Why is that? Is that overcome in the Bills that we have before the Parliament? I do not believe that it is. I do not believe that the problem will be overcome even though a certain amount of competition may be provided. Maybe the Minister can explain that for me. As I see it, anomalies do exist within the legislation before the House.

I know that time is very short, and I appreciate the opportunity of being able to say a few words. I have not actually prepared any notes on this legislation, but I wanted to voice my concern about what country people are going to pay and about the quality of the service that they are going to get. I believe that Telecom is doing a reasonable job. Its services could have been extended. But if the Government does privatise, as is planned here, it should do it properly to provide the competition that will enable us to keep our costs down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In replying briefly to the second reading debate on the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill, I will canvass a pretty wide territory, as other speakers to this Bill have done.
—You have 2 1/2 minutes!

—Is that right? The views put forward by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) are certainly taken into account in the legislation. We are most concerned about the situation of rural consumers. Though they may not necessarily believe it, they will be among the principal beneficiaries of the competitive regime which is put in place. Basically, as the honourable member would know, most rural consumers operate through the subscriber trunk dialling system, not through the local call system. There is no doubt at all that the people who will experience the greatest price falls once competition is introduced will be people who operate their accounts primarily through that system.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member is also concerned about community service obligations. They will also be met in the competitive arrangements that are established. There has been a claim that what is being created here is a behemoth-and the suggestion is that it is one somewhat of my dimensions. Were that only true! I would not be in this place if I ran some operation which enjoyed the profitability of telecommunications companies. That not being the case, I am obliged to be here introducing legislation about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have lots of friends.

—I would have many more friends than I have at the moment. People are a little unaware of the situation relating to competition. It is true that we are combining OTC Ltd and Telecom and the organisation will be more powerful than its individual parts. There is no question about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Two consortia are now vying to buy Aussat, which is neither here nor there in reality to the competition; Aussat is irrelevant. What matters is the fact that the outfit which acquires Aussat will have a licence to compete exclusively, but ultimately in a broad field, across the board for the next six or so years.

The two consortia already in place-of course, we hope there will be more-are twice the size, at a minimum, of Telecom. They are at least twice as powerful as Telecom in the telecommunications system. Telecom is going to experience competition at the hardest conceivable end. Those two operations which are currently bidding for it, and have a profitability that dwarfs that of Telecom, are going to find it pretty easy to operate in a competitive mould. The last thing they want to do is get into bed with Telecom. Their interests in the long term-because they will face open competition after 1997-lie in ripping as much market share off Telecom as they possibly can in the shortest possible order, and they have the financial means to do so.

If we do not combine OTC and Telecom we will not have an operation that is effectively able to compete internationally on some of the highways that the Opposition spokesman on privatisation, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), and other spokesmen such as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) talked about. But we will have in this country a couple of operators who, in their capacity to absorb and create new markets and to rough up new opponents, are of an order that Telecom has never even conceived.

—It is understood that the Opposition wishes to incorporate in Hansard those of its amendments and proposed new clauses which have been circulated but were not moved before the expiration of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have those amendments incorporated in Hansard. I am pleased to announce that they are joined in part by the Australian Democrats, so it will be interesting when the legislation gets to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The amendments read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN AND OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1991

(1) Clause 3, page 2, at the end of the definition of ``authorised person'' add ``provided that before so authorising a person the Minister shall be satisfied, having regard to that person's abilities and experience, that person is suitably qualified to perform the functions required of the person''.
(2) After Part 1, page 4, insert the following new part (comprising clauses 7A, 7B and 7C):
``PART 1A-REQUIREMENTS PRIOR TO
SUCCESSION DAY
Proper commercial debt/equity ratio to be
provided for Telecom and OTC

``7A (1) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), a succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2(1) unless and until the Minister is satisfied that Telecom and OTC each have achieved a capital structure, in terms of debt and equity, on a commercial basis equivalent to the average interest cover and debt ratio of the mid range Standard and Poors AA ratings of major telecommunications companies.

``(2) In this section `Standard and Poors' means the international organisation of that name which provides and publishes financial and other information and analysis relating to private and public organisations and entities.

``(3) As soon as practicable after forming a judgment as to whether the requirements of subsection (1) have been satisfied, the Minister shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament full documentation recording details of the debt and equity position of Telecom and OTC, in the terms required by subsection (1).
``(4) A succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2(1) unless and until the provisions of subsection (3) have been complied with.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991, as it also welcomed the associated Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991, which provided for a plain English rewrite of part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. This Bill is a transitional one associated with the rewrite, and it acts as a conduit between the old and the new part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The most important intent of the Bill is to ensure that changes made to the Veterans' Entitlements Act during the 1990 Budget sittings are included in the rewritten plain English part III and to ensure that there is a continuity between the old and the new part III.

SPEECH.PARA: Significant Budget changes rewritten in plain English by this Bill include the deeming provisions and the tightening of the definition of `allotted for duty' for the purposes of establishing qualifying service and thus eligibility for the service pension. The Bill also includes consequential amendments to other parts of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, mostly in terms of cross-referencing, in light of the new part III.

The Bill features the inclusion of plain English indexation provisions, which take into account the latest consumer price index figures so as to be current on 1 July, when this Bill will commence. I note that this transitional Bill is subject to the same assurances from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) as the initial rewrite Bill: namely, that any unintended consequences will be legislatively attended to as quickly as is practically possible. I commend the Government for its efforts to make veterans legislation more accessible to the veteran community through this plain English approach. All members of parliament have had to deal with complex problems from veterans in their electorates, and I am pleased to see that the Government is moving to a more easily understood format for veterans legislation.

In this context the role of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) must be acknowledged in the way it has assisted veterans in dealing with various complex veterans matters associated with legislation which was not written in plain English format. So I take this opportunity to commend the RSL for the way it has approached this task over many years. Many hundreds of sub-branches of the RSL have voluntary counsellors who have given great assistance to veterans in helping them interpret and understand their entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

Clearly, the coalition will not be opposing this Bill; however, I would like to reiterate to the Minister some concerns of the Opposition which were signalled by my colleague the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) during the debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991. Over the years the Government has consistently said that there would be no integration of the repatriation hospitals without the consent of the RSL. It is plainly obvious that the Government is pushing ahead with integration despite the fervent opposition of the vast majority of the veteran community, and the RSL in particular.

The Minister cannot blame the RSL for representing the ex-service community-that is what it is there for-and the ex-service community in 1991, by and large, wants to retain the repatriation hospitals. The Government has not been successful in communicating to Australian veterans its case in regard to hospital integration, and it has gone back on its promise that it would not go ahead without their consent. For that the Government stands condemned.

Can I also say to the Government that its tactic of going around the RSL on this subject, with a huge mail-out to some 360,000 veterans and war widows, will raise much anger in the ex-service community. The pamphlet is entitled `The Repatriation Private Patient Scheme-How You Will Benefit'. I say to the Minister that the benefits of a repatriation hospital scheme are already well known to the ex-service community. I believe that the RSL will continue to heavily criticise the Government for its steamrolling tactics. I make the point to the Minister that under a coalition Government there would be no such breakdown in relations between the Government and the RSL. The Government is fond of boasting of its consensus approach when it comes to its mates in the union movement. However, when it comes to Australia's veterans community it seems that a steamrolling approach is acceptable, and I say to the Minister that such an approach is not acceptable to the coalition.

Lastly, the coalition has not lost sight of the fact that when we are dealing with veterans legislation we are dealing with compensation as opposed to welfare. As a nation we owe a debt of gratitude to members of our veteran community for their service to the nation. The vast bulk of our veteran community is now at an age when it requires assistance in one form or another from the Government. The vast majority of the veteran community believes that this Government has approached this matter with a begrudging attitude. I assure the House and the veteran community generally that the Opposition acknowledges the compensatory nature of the benefits and will act accordingly when in government after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991 deals in the main with a continuation of the process now becoming entrenched in the Hawke Government legislation; this being the gradual conversion of key documents into what could be described as plain English versions. This Bill basically mirrors the legislative changes which have been made in the Social Security Act 1991 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 which passed through this House on 16 May.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is not only desirable but also necessary because of the need for related social security, taxation and veterans' affairs legislation to be identical and legally sound in their language and specifications. The process of language demystification, began by the rewriting of the Social Security Act 1947, can be seen as an attempt by the Government to ensure that obligations and entitlements under the law are not obscured by outdated, interpretationally unclear and/or esoteric language.

It is a sensible and long overdue initiative which can only lead to more certainty in the law and, therefore, a higher degree of compliance with the law's intention. In broad terms, this Bill provides the necessary legal machinery for the transition from the former part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to the new part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The objectives which it includes are: the consolidation of savings and transitional provisions; the inclusion of plain English indexation provisions; amendments to part III resulting from the 1990 Budget legislation; the consequential amendments of other parts of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and other veterans' affairs legislation; the consequential amendments of other Commonwealth Acts; and further amendments to part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

In similar terms to the new division 1aa contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Bill is intended to reflect existing policy. It therefore does not involve any policy initiatives and does not have any financial impact on veterans' pensions or entitlements. As the Bill could basically be described as being of a machinery and non-controversial nature, I will not take up the time of the House by going into further detail on the matter. Suffice it to say that all of us in this House have reason to strongly support a demystification of the legislative process. I am sure that every member has witnessed, during the course of the day to day representations on behalf of constituents, the confusion and uncertainty that can surround the finer delineations of legislative intent.

I believe that the old Social Security Act 1947, with its myriad of amendments, would stand as a perfect example to us all. How many times have honourable members in this House had to make lengthy representations to establish entitlements under that Act because of the confusion that has been generated and maintained by the nature of the Act's wording? As honourable members know, Australia is in the midst of a micro-economic efficiency drive which will reshape our economy and set up the framework for this nation's development as an export oriented and successful member of the world community. We should remember that it is not only the well publicised multi-million dollar micro-economic issues such as waterfront reform that are important to us; it is also the countless numbers of small issues such as plain English legislation that contribute to the process of efficiency.

There can be no doubt that confidence and trust in the intent and certainty of the law permeates very positively through the different levels of society. As far as I am concerned, the rewriting of the Social Security Act 1947, which started the process of plain English translations of legislation, stands as a tribute to the abilities of both the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), who initiated the process, and Senator Richardson, who pursued the matter into law. The procedure they have begun will without doubt play its part in the restructuring process that is vital to the future economic health of this country. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to take this opportunity once again to speak on a veterans' affairs matter, even though the Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill essentially does not involve any policy changes. As has already been said, this Bill provides the necessary legal machinery for the transition from the former part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to the new part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. One of the reasons I choose to speak in these debates on veterans' affairs is that I believe that veterans need to have a strong voice in this Parliament. Fortunately, there are a number of honourable members on our side, and a number on the other side too-although very few are here this morning, except for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys)-who are able to present that voice within this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The veterans represent an important sector of the community at large and therefore they deserve very special consideration in this Parliament. We are talking not only in a narrow sense about veterans. There are very few First World War veterans still alive these days, as we saw with the Gallipoli reunion a couple of years ago, but there are a very significant number of veterans from the Second World War, Malaya, Korea and Vietnam, and now very much younger veterans have been accorded that status, having returned just recently from active service in the Gulf. We are not talking only about veterans but also about the interests of war widows, the families of veterans who have passed away, Legatees and so on.

In passing, I take this opportunity to commend the ongoing, vital and ever-growing work of Legacy. I think it is truly a tremendous community organisation. I particularly commend the Legacy organisation on the northern beaches of Sydney, where my mother lives. As a war widow, she is constantly attending Legacy functions. That organisation is extremely generous and kind to war widows.

There needs to be a sympathetic and understanding approach to policy in the area of veterans' affairs. Being one to give credit where credit is due and having done so before, I am pleased to say that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, is sympathetic and understanding of his portfolio. I think that is widely recognised in the community. That does not necessarily mean he is perfect, and certainly we on this side of the House do not see the Government's record on veterans' affairs as being entirely perfect.

The Minister reminded me in the debate last week, I think it was, that I have 23,000 veterans in and around my electorate on the Gold Coast. Many of them are aged, and with age sometimes comes a sense of insecurity. Many of the changes that have been implemented affecting aged pensioners, such as the deeming provisions and so on, and some that have been implemented in the veterans' area are threatening to these members of our community.

I mention again the Government's policy in respect of repatriation general hospitals (RGHs) and the concerns that the Returned Services League of Australia still has about that policy. I take the point the Minister has made here on occasions that in many respects the availability of public hospital services and even private hospital services for veterans is commendable. Certainly for veterans in my electorate it may save them having to travel to Brisbane. Nevertheless, for many veterans the availability of ongoing RGH services is important. They see that as something that has been specially provided in recognition of what they have done. They believe that they get very special service and understanding in those hospitals, although that is not to say that they would not get it elsewhere.

Having been in RGH Concord myself at one stage, I know that it has a real empathy with veterans and their widows. I see that the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), is at the table. I think he was on the staff at RGH Concord, so he knows exactly what I am talking about. It needs to be recognised not so much that services are available elsewhere for veterans but that the integration of RGHs into the State health systems is unsettling for the veterans.

We also ought to recognise-I know the honourable member for Lowe has pointed this out-that the demand for services in the RGHs is increasing. The community may well have the impression that, with veterans ageing, the demand is decreasing. My understanding is that the demand is increasing and will not peak until 1995. That is not so much a product of the numbers of veterans but of the fact that, as they get older, they require more and more services. That is perhaps one area where we could point to the Government's handling of the issue not being perfect, although it is in a sense defensible, and the Minister has made that point in the past.

I am pleased that in relation to this Bill the Minister has undertaken to consult fully with the ex-service community and to correct any unintended consequences that may arise from the legislation. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), who spoke earlier, was critical of the process of consultation in respect of one or two matters. However, in this particular area the approach of the Government has been commendable. We in the Opposition make the statement very clearly to the veterans' community that we would be totally committed to an ongoing process of consultation with the various veterans' organisations and the veterans themselves in respect of any changes we proposed to make to their existing rights.

The Government, in a sense, has been inclined to play hard ball with some service and ex-service personnel. A survivor of HMAS Voyager recently visited me in my office. He was in a very bad state. It surprised me that he had suffered so much. I must commend the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) for the way in which he has pursued that matter. In speaking in this Parliament on 12 February 1991 he referred to the Bernie Verwayen case, which had been decided in the High Court. He was one of the sailors on the Voyager in 1964 when it was rammed by the aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne. The fight went on for many years for the survivors of the disaster and for the families of those who did not survive for some form of compensation. Successive governments played that matter very hard, but the High Court finally decided in favour of Bernie Verwayen. Consequently, one expected that that would be a test case which would flow on to all other sailors.

I now find, however, having investigated the matter with this particular constituent, that it is not all plain sailing, if one could perhaps excuse the pun, because now the Government is expecting every one of those sailors to go through the court system and for each one's particular circumstances to be examined very closely. I can understand a reason for that, but I would encourage the Government to speed up the process as much as possible, because this particular constituent who came to me is suffering rather extreme hardship while he waits for his settlement. In fact, he is trying to get some form of disability allowance from the Department of Social Security, he is awaiting what is called a compensation clearance, but the bottom line is that he is once again disadvantaged by bureaucracy and I am very concerned that if any invalid payment is made to him, eventually he will have to pay it back out of his court settlement when that is finalised.

I am very anxious to see the whole process sped up in favour of all of those who are waiting. Some of them are not young any more, some of them are in a surprisingly poor state of health, and they definitely need to have that process speeded up.

Veterans, of course, have a great interest in the whole matter of defence. They of all people have very often paid a very high price for preserving the freedom which we enjoy in our country today, and they, of course, have a very real concern about the way defence has gone in this country in recent years.

It is timely that we should be discussing this particular legislation, in view of the prospect of what at least we on this side of the House see as being a further diminution of the funding available for the defence of this country. This has been a process of a run-down in defence which has been going on now for some years. Veterans' organisations will speak very volubly about that when they get the opportunity of seeing exactly what the Government has in mind in respect of its new defence strategy. However, the Opposition has made it clear that it opposes any Defence Force structure cuts which will impact on combat capability.

As we see it, the Government proposes to significantly reduce combat capability. It intends to place a ceiling on the Army's combat force. At present there are approximately 12,799 combined front line combat and immediate support combat troops, which means there will be a reduction of 1,744 in the Regular Army combat forces.

I know that I would be going beyond the bounds of this debate if I were to go too much into the defence proposals, but I do want to sound the alarm for the Government and let it be fully aware-I am sure the Minister is aware-that veterans' organisations, and indeed veterans at large, are very concerned about the defence of this country. After all, as I have said, they are people who have gone and fought to preserve what we have, and they would be extremely concerned if they saw any reduced capability in our defence forces. I think the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), when he makes his statement, will need to do some pretty fast talking to convince veterans, and indeed the Opposition, that the Government is going down the right track.

There are a number of matters relating to defence which I was intending to canvass briefly, but I might just leave a little bit of time because the Minister may want to make a few remarks before this Bill is guillotined. It is not, as we have said, a momentous Bill. In fact, its intentions are commendable because, as has already been said, one of the main points of the Bill is to give effect to the plain English rewrite of part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Opposition has no problem with that. However, I make the point that for us, veterans' affairs remains a very important policy area, an area where we believe ultimate consideration should be given, that it should be a policy area which is extremely conscious of the need of veterans and their families. The Opposition supports this Government initiative.
