SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Customs Amendment Bill 1991 is to implement changes to the anti-dumping and countervailing procedures announced in the 12 March 1991 industry statement. The Bill contains some minor changes to Customs search procedures introduced last year. The proposed changes to the countervailing procedures are of quite major significance-first, in themselves because of the effect on primary producers in particular and, second, because they signal to Australian industry and indeed to our trading partners that we are getting serious about stopping unfair trading practices. Moreover, the fact that we need these changes, which the Government has indicated are just the start, and that an inquiry to be completed by the end of the year could recommend more also indicates that two years ago the Government got it wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The current revamped anti-dumping system, we should remember, has effectively really just commenced. It is the culmination of years of review. But from the start, the new procedures really were inadequate and it is encouraging to see that finally, if belatedly, the Government has recognised this.

Anti-dumping measures are and always will be, I suspect, a rather vexed issue both philosophically and at a practical level. Many economists will tell us that the dumping of products generally is in the national interest of the recipient country because it gives that country access to cheaper goods. The effect is not positive, however, if an efficient local producer is forced out of business and the foreign exporter, once it has wiped out that competition, eventually raises its prices. Such predatory dumping can do untold damage to our industry and standard of living, as we all know.

The coalition does not agree with the view that we should not have an anti-dumping mechanism at all because, in the real world, there are cases of genuine dumping which should be speedily dealt with. I think there is no doubt that, as our industries become more efficient, which they most certainly will under a coalition government, and develop high quality products destined for the export market, dumping will become less of a problem in this country, or at least less of a perceived problem. But that does not mean to say that we should not have an effective mechanism in place just in case. However, we are also strongly of the view that an anti-dumping mechanism must not be used as an alternative form of industry protection to shield industries from genuine international competition.

The point is that we believe a mechanism must be in place to counter dumped and subsidised products, and it also seems to us that, if this is agreed, the mechanism must be surely effective. We concede that, because of the danger of the mechanism yielding arbitrary protection for certain industries, the procedures must be balanced and thorough. However, the current mechanism and, indeed, even the proposed new shortened mechanism take so long that a local industry could be for all practical purposes destroyed before the provisional measures can be imposed.

I shall be moving an amendment at this, the second reading stage, which amendment I have asked to be circulated, calling on the Government to reduce the current three-tier investigation process to two; that is, a 55-day preliminary investigation period, after which provisional measures can be imposed, followed by a single 120-day final investigation stage.

I should remind the House that, when the current arrangements were debated in 1988, the coalition successfully moved amendments to shorten the first two stages from the Government's proposal of 70 and 180 days to 55 and 120 days. At the time we were told that 55-day and 120-day periods were impossible and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said that the amendment would lead to it being `much more difficult for the Australian Customs Service to reach the sort of quality findings' that it had been reaching in the past. Not only have these critics been proved wrong, but now it is the Government itself which is proposing to reduce the maximum time for establishment of a prima facie case from 55 to 35 days and for the preliminary investigation from 120 to 100 days. This still means, however, that an industry which is suffering material injury from dumped or subsidised imports could have to wait 135 days before receiving any relief by means of provisional measures-and that is 4 1/2 months.

The final investigation undertaken by the Anti-Dumping Authority takes another 120 days, another four months. Altogether the process, even under the improved arrangements, will take up to 8 1/2 months. We do not accept that this is the best that can be done in a world of computers, faxes and satellites. We announced some months ago that we consider that one layer of investigation could be removed and that the preliminary investigation period could be condensed into the initial 55-day period. This would allow provisional measures to be imposed after this time. Ironically, these time limits, or at least the targets in those days, were in place before the latest group of changes and, indeed, Professor Fred Gruen, in his 1986 review of the anti-dumping system, recommended that the Customs Service should make substantial efforts to meet the targets of 55 days for preliminary findings and 120 days for final findings in normal cases.

I understand that the Government will be conducting a review of the anti-dumping system later this year, and I sincerely hope that this question is looked at more closely, the proposed 40-day shortening of the preliminary injury period to be implemented by regulation being just the first step. I would in particular request the Government to explain why countervailing inquiries, for example, need to take so long as opposed to anti-dumping inquiries, when the information about subsidies ought to be and is generally publicly available.

Specifically, however, the Customs Amendment Bill addresses other related aspects of anti-dumping and countervailing measures, most importantly by increasing access of primary producers to the mechanism. The change is long overdue; it was also recognised by Professor Gruen; and it was at the heart of the coalition's decision to require a Senate inquiry into, amongst other things, this aspect of current anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements. Upstream producers will now be able to claim relief from dumping or subsidisation of processed agricultural goods, provided that the goods are closely related to the raw agricultural material. In other words, as I understand it, citrus producers will now be in a position to claim relief against dumping of orange juice, for example, but I assume that sugar producers would not be able to claim relief merely because sugar was used as a preservative in the same juice.

The coalition accepts these necessarily strict tests of vertical integration to ensure that importers are not harassed by dumping claims from peripheral suppliers to the local industry. The legislation also provides for the calculation of a full dumping margin at the preliminary findings stage of a dumping or subsidisation inquiry in order to help speed up investigations. Presumably, this margin is more easily determined because it does not require an estimation of the extent of injury to the local supplier. Again, the coalition will support this change, although I seek the Minister's clarification that this change is consistent with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) articles. I also note that the Minister has said in his second reading speech that the Government will be monitoring the new provisions in light of the changing international trading arrangements and GATT requirements, and we endorse this approach.

The third amendment relates to the sunsetting of countervailing measures and effectively removes an anomaly whereby sunset provisions are dated from the first notice relating to subsidised product and not to the current notice. In effect this means that countervailing measures against subsidised product A from country B might be sunsetted after just a few months because measures against subsidised product A from country A had been in place for almost three years. That proposed amendment will ensure that the three-year sunset period applies to each notice for a full three years. We support it.

Finally, the Bill makes some minor changes to Customs search procedures and specifically extends the potential pool for judges for appointment as `Division 1B Judges' under the Customs Act 1901. We do not oppose those changes.

In summary, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. The measures relating to the anti-dumping and countervailing procedures are long overdue. They are a step in the right direction. We believe another step in the right direction would be to shorten further the investigation process in line with Opposition policy, as I have described. I commend the amendment standing in my name and move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that, in conjunction with the amendments to antidumping and countervailing procedures contained in the Bill, the Government should further streamline these procedures so that Australian producers have adequate defence against dumped and subsidised imports, by condensing the entire preliminary investigation period to 55 days, after which provisional measures can be implemented, followed by a final investigation period of 120 days'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are debating this morning, the Customs Amendment Bill, in fact is to give effect to certain anti-dumping measures which were announced in the Government's 12 March economic statement, Building a Competitive Australia. It includes extending antidumping remedies to certain primary producers and seeks to ensure that anti-dumping remedies are kept in place for a full three years.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation clearly demonstrates yet again a commitment by the Government that, once announcements are made in industry statements or in documents such as Building a Competitive Australia, we are serious about removing impediments to efficiency associated with government operations, with the private sector, with private industry and so on. In fact, as is recorded at page 5.18 of the Building a Competitive Australia document, the 12 March statement delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Government is committed to further trade liberalisation but it will not allow Australian industry to be seriously damaged by imports at dump prices.

In that regard it was recorded in this document that as a first step the Government had decided to strengthen anti-dumping processes immediately by speeding up processing of anti-dumping and subsidisation complaints by Australian industry, by providing better access to the system for Australia's agricultural and horticultural producers and by ensuring that anti-dumping actions will be kept in place for a full three years whenever they are warranted.

To further speed up the process, preliminary measures imposed by Customs will be based on the dumping margin or amount of subsidy rather than on a calculated non-injurious export price. The basis, therefore, was set in that document and, as indicated today, we have the legislation which translates that announcement by government into legislative effect.

The Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) at the table went to the provisions associated with the legislation in detail in his second reading speech. Therefore, there is no need to recount all the bases of the legislation itself. I would like to go to one or two issues associated with this whole problem of dumping, and that goes more to the question of proof of dumping-the question that once a case in fact is proven by the Australian Customs Service and the anti-dumping authority and so on then that particular case should be widely publicised so that it acts more as a deterrent.

The question associated with the legislation of actually shortening the period to give consideration to the three stages, which the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) referred to, goes some way at least to speeding up that process. But of course by the time the actual determination is made the goods have been dumped in this country, they have been dispersed through various mechanisms and, as a result of that, there is already some injury which has been wrought on the Australian producer.

At the end of the day, if that dumping case is proven, it becomes a responsibility to act on that proof and to take appropriate deterrent action against the importer, against the dumping organisation. So in effect we are sending out clear signals that whilst we in no way stand in the way of trade liberalisation, as I have already indicated, at the same time we are not prepared to allow that to occur where we will see Australian industry seriously injured by dumping.

One only has to look back over history to see cases where dumping has occurred. I can recall one case involving tyres being dumped in this country. There are many other examples. This legislation appropriately now extends the principles to agricultural produce. As has been said time and time again, we in Australia enjoy the most efficient agricultural industry in the world, yet there are always barriers and impediments thrown up against the efficiency and the opportunity for our agricultural industries to earn their correct rewards for their efficiency and effectiveness.

In the case of dumping, this serves as an example as to where a further barrier can be put in place with people on the land correctly earning what is their right and due. This Government, as I have indicated, is aware of such considerations. I do suggest to all members of this House that this document, which unfortunately probably did not receive rave reviews when it was brought down on 12 March as some of us would have liked, nevertheless does contain some very important provisions. Today's legislation is one such measure.

As the Minister rightly indicated in his second reading speech, the objectives of this amendment to give additional protection to agricultural producers are appropriate. There is that question of vertical integration and the definition thereof which the honourable member for Barker rightly referred to as a consideration, but nevertheless it is appropriate for the circumstances.

Finally, the second amendment here is to correct some technical drafting changes in respect of internal body search provisions of part XII of the Act. These of course were introduced in this place, and were debated and passed last year. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration canvassed this particular issue in its review of the Australian Customs Service over the last 12 months or so and made recommendations about searches and so on, and the provisions for detecting illegal imports into this country of narcotics and other prohibited substances. It corrects anomalies which escaped the Parliamentary Counsel or the drafters of legislation. Accordingly, all this legislation is timely, and I certainly join with the honourable member for Barker in commending it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this Customs Amendment Bill because it is vitally important to rural Australia. We have a situation where the horticultural industries of Australia in particular are being swamped and destroyed by imports coming in willy-nilly.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make the point that before this Labor Government came into power we had a good scheme. We had a scheme that worked. The Government wrecked it, and all it is doing now-in spite of the commendation of the Bill by the last speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), when saying what good boys they are-is trying to correct some of the mistakes it made to get it back towards the workable scheme which we had in position before. But it is not going far enough-nowhere near far enough.

It is absolutely disgraceful that we can see on our morning television orange orchards in the Riverina being bulldozed because of imports. Even in my own area of the north coast of New South Wales there was a threat some time back, which has gone now, of the importation of bananas which could destroy the Australian banana industry, not just through economics but through the importation of disease. Therefore, I repeat that I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak on this Bill. It is important to all of rural Australia.

We cannot allow a situation where imports come in from countries all over the world. I have seen, for instance, apricots from Turkey which were of such poor quality that, although they were good enough to be imported into this country, when the importers brought in too many and wanted to export them from Australia, the apricots did not meet our export standards. That is not good enough either.

The current legislation reduces the period for investigation to 135 days. That is a step in the right direction; there is no doubt about that. But we in the coalition have put forward a proposal in this amendment. I hope the Government will accept it. We have proposed that there should be only 55 days for the preliminary investigation and 120 days for the final investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good policy.

—Indeed, an excellent policy, and one that the Government should adopt. I would go much further; I would completely reverse the anti-dumping legislation. At the present time, if somebody imports material, we have to prove that it has been dumped. I would rather have it the other way around. I would like to have a list of products that are susceptible to dumping and a requirement for the importer to prove before products come in that they are not being dumped. I would not have months and months of investigation. That is no good for our primary producers.
—Industries are destroyed while that is happening.

—As the honourable member for Mallee says, industries are indeed destroyed while that is happening. In the present economic situation, which has been brought about by this failed Labor Government, with its economic policies, the rural producers of Australia cannot afford to suffer dumping of horticultural and other products for as long as the investigation is proposed to take. I make the point very strongly-and I make it to people on my own side of the House as well as to members of the Government-that we should consider the reversal of the whole anti-dumping legislation and that we should consider the whole culture and philosophy of it.

SPEECH.PARA: We should create a situation where, if people want to import a product that is in danger of threatening our own industries, they have to prove first that they are not dumping. They must prove that prior to importing, prior to putting our own rural industries at risk. I think that is fair enough. It is fair to our people and it is fair to the importers and producers in other countries, who would still have the opportunity of exporting to us. Our importers could still bring products in, provided it could be established and proved that they were not dumping and not putting at risk our own rural industries.

I know that time is limited and that other members of the House wish to speak. I conclude by saying again to the Government: please accept our amendment; let us speed up the introduction of anti-dumping measures and, preferably, down the track, let us turn things right around and stop dumping altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -Government initiatives, including general tariff reductions and the re-vitalisation and redirection of scientific and research and development effort and business taxation reforms were introduced to help industry to increase efficiency and compete more effectively in an internationally competitive environment.

SPEECH.PARA: To assist Australian horticulture specifically, the Government established the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) to encourage and coordinate horticultural marketing and facilitate exports of Australian produce. At the same time, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation was established to foster efficient and competitive horticultural industries through research and development and the Horticultural Policy Council was established to advise the Government on policy matters relating to horticultural industries.

The effectiveness of these bodies relies to a great extent on the level of support they receive from industry. The more industries become involved with the corporations and Council, the greater is the potential for coordinated and effective marketing, research and development and policy advice. In some areas industry has been slow to take up the opportunities, particularly in relation to the AHC.

The Government agrees that Australian industries should not be subject to unfair market competition from imports and has in place anti-dumping legislation which was strengthened in 1988 by the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority. The current anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements are frequently reviewed to ensure their continued effectiveness. The Customs Amendment Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 to implement certain reforms to the current anti-dumping and subsidisation regime which were announced in the 12 March industry statement and to effect technical drafting changes to the internal body search provisions of the Act to clarify the nature and function of judges' orders made under those provisions.

In relation to the standards and inspection of imported foods, since July last year the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has been responsible for testing a range of imported foods to ensure that they comply with the requirements of the food standards code developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Foods subject to inspection are tested to ensure that they meet microbiological standards and, where relevant, are within the approved Australian tolerances for residues of chemicals or heavy metals.

The program assigns imported foods to one of three risk categories which determine the nature and frequency of inspection and analysis carried out. The Government believes that decisions to control food imports should be consistent with our international trading obligations and should be justifiable on the grounds of demonstrable health risk. Consistent with this position, it is unlikely that fresh and processed horticultural products, which generally pose little risk to human health, will necessarily be included in the program.

While I can appreciate growers' concerns about the effect of the value of the Australian dollar on the competitiveness of our exports-and this has been raised many times-it is important to recognise that it has been necessary to reduce unsustainable levels of domestic expenditure and demand for imports. But it is also important to note that the Australian dollar is trading at something like 20 per cent less than it ever did under those on the other side of this House.

The topic of increased competition from imported food products has been widely reported in the press, and it is important that the threat of these imports is put in perspective. In 1989-90, Australian horticultural imports, excluding wine imports, were valued at approximately $415m, compared with exports of about $520m. Similarly, the value of wine imports and exports in 1989-90 were $52.7m and $118.3m respectively. Australia is therefore a net exporter of horticultural products. It makes sense to recognise that if we were to stop those products coming in we would simply stop the net export value that we have already going out. The Government understands the concern at increasing competition from imports of horticultural products; at the same time, as a major agricultural exporting nation, we have much to gain from the liberalisation of trade. Of course, we support the need to move that way.

Australia cannot seriously seek the removal of trade distorting subsidies and high tariffs in other countries without similar systems operating here. It must be remembered that Australia exports a higher percentage and a broader range of agricultural products than does any other country. Something like 70 per cent of all our agricultural produce has to find markets overseas.

The livestock and cropping industries, which constitute a significant proportion of the Australian agricultural sector, have an even higher dependency on exports. Australian agricultural industries would not just gain from increased liberalisation of trade; they have much to lose from an increase in international protection. All imports involve a level of risk, and both the risk and the level of acceptability will vary according to the commodity and the pest and disease considerations. Clearly, if assessment indicates that the risk is sufficiently low and that economic and other considerations point to quarantine procedures being appropriate, there can be no technical justification for prohibiting such imports.

It is fairly clear, as I have said, that we cannot afford to put up protective barriers because Australia itself is so vulnerable to the vagaries of world trade. We can help to reduce this problem in other ways. The Government has introduced compulsory labelling of fruit juices and is working with the States to have compulsory labelling of country of origin of all produce, both processed and unprocessed.

The way in which we promote Australian products is also important. Given that the second great State of Origin match will be played tonight, it is important to note that the Brisbane Broncos are out supporting the Queensland banana industry. That is the way in which Australians must promote their products; it is a great idea. The Brisbane Broncos have had a bit of bad luck lately, but it is still the greatest team in the Winfield competition. That is the way in which Australia must promote its products-by getting out and having a go. Australia produces the best quality product and so has a great opportunity to outdo its competitors, but it must not succumb to the temptation of putting up trade barriers. Australia has much to gain by liberalisation of trade.

I support these Bills and I commend the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who is at the table, for his concern, dedication and interest in freeing up trade, and for the effort he has put into this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You commend all the Ministers.

—As the honourable member interjects, I do commend all Ministers because they are top quality. There is no comparison between them and the motley crew on the other side of the House, who really would not make a cricket team and do not bat down to No. 1-with the exception of the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), who was not a bad cricketer in his day. I am pleased to support the Ministry, unlike honourable members opposite, who really do not match up at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will add a little to the words of my colleague: I would hate to be a primary producer or horticulturalist in the electorate of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). Getting all those platitudes, claptrap and regurgitated Government propaganda does not alleviate the problems of Australia's primary producers and manufacturers. That sort of rubbish does not go anywhere with those people because they are going broke and their families are suffering. Government platitudes are no substitute for careful thought and good policies-the sorts of policies the coalition is presenting to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has had two policies to run Australia: it has had a policy of high interest rates and a policy of reducing tariffs. Those policies are diabolical for anybody who is providing jobs or manufacturing anything or self-employed or lucky enough even to have a job. No wonder unemployment is rising; the Government is exposing the Australian people to a flood of imports while charging them extra money for homes and for everything they buy or want to get hold of. The aspirations and incentives of Australians are dead, and their opportunities are non-existent. Those are the policies of the Australian Labor Party (ALP); if those were the policies it wanted to implement, it has been extremely successful in doing so.

It is about time the Government moved to restrict the implications of its policies by preventing international cheats or those who abuse the openness of the Australian market by putting products onto it that are either subsidised or have a loss sale factor. The technique that can be used is to put on the Australian market for a short period a product-be it a manufactured good or a primary product such as orange juice, potatoes or whatever-at a low price so that Australian producers and manufacturers are eventually forced out of production and out of business. They are forced out of business because they cannot compete with imports.

Because Australian producers have been knocked out of business, Australian consumers and the Australian market are exposed to whatever price the foreign goods are lobbed on to the market for and the importer requires Australians to pay. While a period of competition between Australian and imported products is good for consumers initially, my concern is that, if unfair advantage is used in this process, Australian consumers will ultimately suffer because they will become captives of those foreign producers or manufacturers.

The Government has moved some amendments to the existing dumping legislation through the Customs Amendment Bill. The idea of this legislation is to allow Australian manufacturers and producers to have the Australian Government charge importers who are cheating the system full price for their goods if the Australian producers and manufacturers can demonstrate that those goods are being dumped here-that is, being sold below the price they are sold for in their country of origin or are being subsidised by the government of the country of origin.

This legislation seeks to redress some of the changes made by the Government in earlier years. My friend the honourable member for Hinkler said that these changes were apparently sensible at the time but have proved to be impractical. Senator Button when introducing these changes said they would improve things for Australian producers. They did nothing of the sort; they made the situation more complex, lengthy, time-consuming, involved and legalistic. Further, they are seen to be less than effective. So the Government is now moving back to the situation it found on coming to office.

I applaud the Government for that, but the legislation really does not go far enough. For example, it extends the opportunity not only for the actual manufacturers but also for the producer of a like good to mount a dumping case. An easy example is that of citrus growers producing oranges to be processed into orange juice. Previous legislation would not allow citrus growers to take a case of dumping against the import of citrus juice. That seems crazy, but that was the legislation. This legislation extends the capacity of the producer of like goods to mount a dumping case; I think that is a worthy and sensible amendment.

The legislation also provides that the time for hearing these matters be limited. That does not go anywhere near what the Opposition has proposed, which is that there should be a 55-day preliminary hearing, after which penalties or charges should go on-the countervailing duties. If anyone then takes the matter further, a 120-day hearing process is to be entered into and fine detail ultimately decides the question. However, if somebody is dumping, the Opposition proposes that action should commence against the person or organisation after 55 days.

This whole process has great complexity because Australia has to balance anti-dumping steps with its international obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That is an agreement by trading partners around the world that they will try to play a fair game, and that when they have a dumping procedure or tariff measures the trade process should be as open as possible. The Europeans run their own outfit and do not listen to anybody, including Australia and the United States (US); they are absolutely selfish and single-minded about protecting their own markets and do not care about the rest of the world.

Despite the comments by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), neither has achieved a single thing in the trade area to free up or to improve Australia's trade opportunities with the rest of the world. They have made a lot of placatory noises to the producers and their families, who are suffering, but they have achieved nothing.

In the process of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Australia must apply to itself some sort of discipline in the way in which it enters into decisions on dumping and the restriction of the entry of imports into this country. This is a complex matter, and countries around the world do different things about dumping. From the initiation of cases, the determination of nominative values, export prices and the prima facie inquiries people have, the domestic price determination and the production costs, every country does a different thing; Canada, the United States and Europe all do different things.

One tries to assess Australia's position in this process. I would have to say that Australia is free and open-certainly it is not the most open and free, but somewhere about the middle-while the United States, for example, might be more restrictive than most countries. Yet there are countries to our north such as Singapore and the other Asian countries that feel the rest of the world is far too restrictive about letting goods in, and that includes Australia.

Australians know that if we were to have an open door process for the importation of all goods there would be massive unemployment and dislocation of the Australian economy. While we move to restrict the application of tariffs, and do that fairly quickly and sensibly, there must also be an underpinning factor that prevents international trading cheats from knocking off Australian jobs, manufacturers and primary producers. The Opposition has strong views about this and it has sensible policies as alternatives to those put up by the Australian Labor Party.

The Government has been slow in introducing these amendments, which are partially effective. The Government does not understand the urgent need for a quick decision in the preliminary hearing, nor does it understand the damage that can be done to Australian producers or processors while evidence is being gathered. The Opposition does understand that and its policy takes account of it.

There is another area that the Government needs to apply attention to, and that is the area of standards. Australian manufacturing producers are obliged to meet certain standards but others may not be.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has now expired. The original question was that this Bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Barker has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we come to this critical part of the session where we have few days left and a lot of legislation to go through. As usual, the health legislation amendments in connection with nursing homes and hostels are brought in at this stage. I understand that there is yet another one to be introduced tomorrow afternoon which has to be passed through this House next week. The point I want to make is that we have never had an opportunity to really debate the issues of the aged in nursing homes and hostels and within the community with any degree of freedom, because we are being caught in this vice of speaking to a timetable set by the guillotine.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, I will be one of only the few Opposition members who will be able to speak to this matter. If this is the manner in which the Government continues to treat these very vital matters affecting the most critical part of our community-the aged, who need to have a reliance within the community on certain factors-then its social justice program stands for nought.

The National Health Amendment Bill contains minor amendments, on which we have sought information from the Department of Community Services and Health as late as this morning. In our consultations with the industry there seems to be one area that is causing some concern, and that is the area of exempt homes. Our consultations with the major sectors of the industry have suggested that there has been a lack by the Department of consultation with these people and with the consumers. To the extent that we have looked at that aspect of it, and in preference to opposing the legislation, we have suggested that this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. That has been done in the Senate and I understand that the Bill itself and these provisions relating to exempt homes will come up during its consideration of the matter.

It appears that the problems with the exempt homes stem right back to the introduction of the original provision. The coalition allowed it through on the basis that we wished it luck but we believed that there were many things to be sorted out on the way through. Apparently the industry believes that they have not been sorted out adequately. The concept of the user pays principle that is contained within the exempt homes provisions is being frustrated by applications not being made because people are still sceptical about it. Where the applications are made, there seems to be some unnecessary delay in getting it onto the books. It appears to me that the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has quite a few determinations that can be made together with a discretion, which might also affect the position.

In relation to the aged care industry, particularly the nursing homes, if we look at the statistics in the years ahead it appears that the way that we are moving does not seem to take into account the ageing of our population beyond the year 2000. In many cases nursing homes are being closed and preference is being given to the establishment of hostels which will become-I understand that the Minister would agree-light nursing homes, but with a subsidy much less than that paid to the nursing home at the moment.

I think it is very important-it is essential-that a bipartisan approach be taken to the attitude of exempt homes, particularly as to where the funding will come from in the future. I shall just give one example. As I said, the hostels will become light nursing homes, available only on geriatric assessment team approval, which makes it most unlikely that husbands and wives, or couples, will be admitted to hostels in the future. Yet at that stage there is an entry contribution available to the hostel owners in order to supplement what have been, in some cases in the voluntary sector, losses on operations. If this is going to be the trend, we see a need to address the problem of why this entry contribution cannot be taken further in connection with that principle. As I said, we will refer that matter to a Senate committee. I understand that it will not mean that there will be any deferment of the legislation; but it will provide the opportunity for consultation with the people involved at that stage. The Opposition will be moving a second reading amendment, to this effect:

. . . whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its regret at the uncertainty caused by the Government's delay in concluding a Charter of Residents' Rights and a form of agreement between nursing home residents and proprietors.

We will do this because we think it necessary to remind the Parliament and its members of just what the process was. I know that, in the rush up to the 1990 election, the Opposition was being blamed for delaying the implementation of the charter in December 1989, at which time we sought to have inserted in the legislation a provision for parliamentary review, in both Houses, of the agreements and the documents, which were not then available. The accusation made at that stage was that we were delaying implementation. I know that some people in the aged care industry believed that and blamed us for it. But that was back in 1989.

At the end of last year we then had the rush to lay down a draft. I have mentioned in this House before the draft that came before us as far as the residents' rights were concerned. Also, the residents' agreement with the owners was far from what I believed was the standard required by this Parliament. Again there was a rush to legislate in December 1990 so that these things could be confirmed and put in the hands of the industry.

Upon asking the Minister about the timetable, I understand that we now have a new timetable for implementation of the legislation. There has been another change, which means that this will not become available until 1 September this year. At the moment there is market testing of the information kit within the industry.

The Opposition also understands that there has been some delay in seeking confirmation of the constitutionality of that agreement and also of the residents' rights document. We have not been advised about the concerns that were expressed previously. Again, this shows that the huge rush that was made in order to satisfy an election deadline, and also to satisfy those consumers and residents, has not been successful. We understand that from 1 September 1991 all new residents in nursing homes are to be offered the agreements to sign. I hope that they are in a form which is constitutional and which can be signed without any repercussions from that point. Existing residents may also be offered the opportunity to sign agreements as from 1 August 1991, but must have been offered that opportunity by no later than 31 January 1992. I point out that that is over two years since the process of the legislation began in this House, and probably three or four years from the process of starting it in the first place. That amendment to the motion for the second reading will be moved later on.

In relation to residents' rights, the concern presented to us by the Catholic bishops still has not been addressed, and the Little Sisters of the Poor highlighted the problem they had. The Government did accommodate the Little Sisters of the Poor in the first situation, but has not in the second situation. In a question on notice, I asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services what would happen with Commonwealth funding if, as threatened, the Little Sisters of the Poor and other organisations would not sign the agreement. The answer was that the proprietor offers each resident an agreement for signing. If the proprietor complies with the conditions of the agreement, that is okay, but if the proprietor refuses to sign the agreement, there are a range of options which the Government may pursue and, in an overall context, the level of care and accommodation provided by that nursing home would be taken into account. I am not too sure how comforting that will be to the Little Sisters of the Poor or to the Catholic bishops. It shows that in this whole process there is a lot to be desired.

One problem within the industry at the moment is that, in some respects, there is a de facto application of the residents rights and also the charter. While the objections by the Catholic bishops have not been addressed, there are still many concerns in the industry as to where they stand. At the moment I think they feel that they are in no man's land or no woman's land.

I will mention some of the other problems that the industry and the consumers have had in connection with the aged care industry. Firstly, a unilateral approach was adopted by the Government at the last Budget where there was defunding of the hostel subsidy. The care aggregated module (CAM) hours were reduced without any reference to the industry, in spite of the fact that inquiries were taking place in connection with CAM at that time which would be finalised in the future. The Government's attitude was that the CAM hours were reduced without any consultation, which caused problems for people in the industry.

A concern was expressed to me by the small nursing homes, more particularly the Victorian Bush Hospitals Association, and also the country hostels which were operating very small units, all of which were approved and encouraged by the government of the day. The threat of the top up funding being stopped on 31 December this year is causing some concern. In my talks with the people in the bush hospitals, I know that consultations have been taking place with the Minister's staff and his Department, but I believe that they still require some firm plan. I agree with the principle being adopted that there should be an overall strategy for nursing homes and hostels that will be affected in country areas. There has to be some strategy in place to appreciate what can happen, but there should be some guarantee of funding so that nursing homes can continue into the future.

Coming from a country electorate, I know that people in the country, in smaller townships, have exactly the same needs when they are aged, whether it be for residential or hostel accommodation or whether they stay at home. All these needs can be addressed if we pursue the principle of the multipurpose facilities, genuinely believing that they do provide an answer.

I understand that there is also a problem in connection with the listing for exemption from deeming provisions on gifts and donations. The Department has ensured that those matters receive the approval of the Department. The last time I heard, many applications had been lodged, but very few commitments had been given at that time.

I have talked about nursing homes being exempt and also the method of funding into the future. As we see it, the nursing home industry is being cut down on CAM, but we all know that the CAM component does not provide for any profit to the organisation. Whether it is a private or a voluntary organisation, it should be used to provide the care specified within the residents classification instrument. From speaking to people in the industry, I understand that there is very little fat left in the standard aggregated module, which means that there is no contribution flow through to hostels.

There is a concern, particularly in Victoria, that nursing home beds are being reduced because of their size. This is in conformity with what is required from 1990 to the year 2000. This means that in the year 2000 there could be a vacuum in the need for nursing home beds. There appears to be no long term planning in that regard.

I will just mention the clause about community visitors. We certainly agree with the amendments that are being suggested in this regard, in that the community visitors no longer have the responsibility of judging the standard of care. I know that has been a concern to dons and staff where visitors come in through the front door and look over the shoulders of the nursing staff to make sure that, in their opinion, they are doing the right job. The Opposition believes that visitors should come in, as I think the Act says, to observe the requirements of the patients themselves. I think that is a good move.

I will move to another area away from the visitors to the advocates because I believe there is still a major problem there. The Minister will be aware of correspondence that I have had with him in regard to an example of a government nursing home in Maryborough, Queensland, where in fact the advocate not only went on the basis of a claim, but also made comments to the press afterwards and made it a public matter before the Department's own complaints unit was able to deal with it. I do not believe that is good enough and the Minister's response in this regard is worth reading. We do not disagree with some of it, but there is a point. He wrote:

A major aim of the advocacy services is to protect and safeguard the rights of these residents. In this context, as the services are not affiliated with either public or private sector bodies, they are not subject to any restrictions on whom they may speak to on behalf of a resident. This includes the press.

I know in the agreement about the residents' rights we did have some conflict at that stage, but, basically, we said that an advocate who goes into a nursing home should reveal the name of the person who is the complainant. I believe that was the manner in which it was justified. But I do not believe that it is up to that advocate then, out of his own opinion, to go to the press and make those comments. It is interesting that the Minister justified this in a letter to the organisation:
In cases where press coverage does result from the involvement of an advocacy service, nursing home and hostel proprietors are free to provide rebuttal in the press, if that is appropriate.

The reality is, and I think the Minister would agree, that the only news and press one gets about the nursing home industry is not what good is being done, but every time there is somebody thrown out because of an exempt bed provision or when an advocate goes and makes declarations to the press. That is an initial charge that cannot be rebutted irrespective of where one stands with the press. I believe there should be some restriction on advocates speaking to the press, particularly before the complaints unit of the Department is able to investigate it. Once one is condemned in the first headline, it does not matter how much there is a withdrawal or a rebuttal on the back page, which obviously follows the next day; that does not overcome the national headlines that ensue from that initial reaction. So I do wish the Minister would look at that aspect of it.

What I understand is the situation is that a determination made by a delegate of the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health is not required to be tabled and is therefore not disallowable, and the determination made under section 98c (1) (b) of the National Health Act 1953 makes changes to the system that pharmacists use to make a claim for payment from the Health Insurance Commission.

There are several determinations available to the Secretary to the Department in this regard, all affecting pharmacists, but, unfortunately, the discretions are in the hands of the Secretary and they are not subject to any appeal or other system of an independent review of that particular decision.

,The particular amendment that we would have moved had we moved into committee, but which will be pursued in the Senate, would make those determinations subject to disallowance. Other than the points that we have made, we support the Bill. I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in support of the National Health Amendment Bill, but in particular to amendments which will include the Commonwealth's outcome standards as a condition of approval for all approved nursing homes. Outcome standards for Commonwealth approved nursing homes were introduced in 1987. A series of parliamentary reports, including the McLeay and the Giles reports, recommended changes to the administration of the aged care program, including the issue of standards of care.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1984 Giles report made a comprehensive examination of the quality of care standards in nursing homes and found evidence of substandard care. Amongst other things, that Committee, the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, recommended that a Commonwealth nursing home standards committee be established to develop uniform guidelines for minimum standards of nursing hours, physical facilities, para-medical services and quality of care. Subsequently, the 1986 nursing homes and hostels review recommended sweeping changes to the Commonwealth's administration of aged care, and its recommendations included that standards for quality of care and quality of life should be controlled through input and outcome measures which would need to be met as a condition of funding, and that the Department of Community Services and Health should-in consultation with State authorities, consumer organisations and the industry-formulate a manual on quality of care and quality of life for nursing homes and nursing home residents.

The Government took action to develop appropriate standards and to ensure that residents of nursing homes have the quality of life that they deserve. Development of the outcome standards resulted from a sharing of skills and experiences in an intergovernmental forum and through extensive national consultations with industry, union and consumer representatives. The nursing home outcome standards emphasise the importance of residents as individuals and as members of the community. The standards set out the care and lifestyle objectives which the nursing home industry is expected to achieve for all residents. They represent a significant change in the way the Government perceives nursing homes.

In the past, regulations and legislation have primarily addressed the inputs to care and the physical environment of nursing homes rather than the quality of care and lifestyle of residents. Outcome standards also recognise the changing perception of nursing homes as being the long term homes of residents as well as providing health care facilities. In other words, they have to be places that people would like to live in. They are not specifying inputs or processes. The standards encourage flexibility in nursing home design, service provision and work practices.

The intent of the standards is also to encourage and enable residents to perform activities, maintain responsibilities and receive support according to their individual needs and capabilities. Due to the residents' increasing frailty, it is recognised that not all residents will be able to avail themselves fully of freedoms which are properly theirs. However, this is no reason to qualify or withdraw those freedoms for the majority of residents in nursing homes.

The Government understood from the outset that for this new approach to be implemented, the industry would require assistance. Significant funding has been provided by the Government to meet these needs of industry. However, it is important to understand that this is a regulatory program. The Government needs to ensure that residents receive the care that they are entitled to as citizens of this nation.

For the small percentage of nursing homes that have not performed as high quality care providers, it is this Government's responsibility to take action. I draw the House's attention briefly to the fact that the member for Perth in the State Parliament of Western Australia, Ian Alexander, has recently highlighted a number of problems in nursing homes in that State. I think that the Government's action in trying to control that small number of nursing homes is extremely important in the context of his comments.

The proposed amendments to include outcome standards as a condition of approval of all nursing homes will make clear, particularly to those proprietors that provide substandard care, that action sometimes needs to be taken. The amendment clarifies that action can be taken to withdraw or suspend Commonwealth benefits to a home when it is not satisfying standards.

The Government has not shirked from taking action against homes that have failed to meet the standards where these have been drawn to its attention. Since July 1990, when sanction action for failing to comply with the standards became available, the Government has implemented sanctions against 17 nursing homes. This action has met with a great deal of success. This means that residents are receiving a better quality care. In nearly every case the nursing home has improved its performance to meet standards almost immediately. In a couple of other cases the home has closed or new admissions have not been allowed to the home until the standards were improved. This action, therefore, highlights the important regulatory role the Commonwealth continues to play in the aged care program and, indeed, one that it has to play.

However, to talk only of a regulatory program is to concentrate on the few bad apples in the barrel who fail to provide quality aged care. As most Australians are aware, the aged care industry has a proud record of providing excellent quality of care to its clients. The huge majority of nursing homes provide an excellent level of care by dedicated staff doing an extremely good and a very rewarding job. The last few years have seen significant changes in the provision of care and a recognition that the changing size of the aged population and their care requirements of the aged will provide even greater challenges well into the next century.

As part of the Government's residents' rights strategy and intention to ensure information about nursing homes is widely available, the Government publishes reports of its visits to nursing homes and hostels for the aged. These reports are given to the proprietors of nursing homes before they are published. A recently released report on the outcome standards by Dr John Braithwaite of the Australian National University found that the industry overwhelmingly supports the standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Great bloke; great name!

—I am sure he is no relation to the honourable member. The major industry associations, consumer groups, unions, nursing home staff and residents are generally supportive of the standards and Dr Braithwaite reported that, despite inevitable tension associated with the day to day operation of a regulatory program, the underlying reality is one of industry and government working together constructively to improve the quality of care for nursing home residents. On 1 January 1991 the Commonwealth introduced similar outcome standards for hostels. The standards are another step in the Commonwealth Government's reform of aged care in Australia, which emphasises rights and dignity for individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make at this point a comment about Barridale Lodge, which was opened in my electorate on Saturday by Senator Pat Giles-as it turns out, the person who chaired the Committee that produced the Giles report in 1984-and to indicate that the quality of this particular lodge is excellent. It was built by a constituent of mine, and the charter of residents' rights was well and truly on display in the foyer of the hostel. I am sure that, if we can continue to have excellent facilities like this made available and if those facilities are able to offer proper care to aged Australians, then this Government's achievements in this area will go down in history as being very great. Accordingly, I commend the National Health Amendment Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the National Health Amendment Bill I wish to draw the attention of the House to a very serious problem in relation to aged people with an intellectual disability. I am glad that the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) is in the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the problem is that the option of retirement is not available to many such people. My attention has been drawn to this issue by Mr Trevor Caldwell, Director of the Noweyung Centre, and members of the centre's board of management. Noweyung Centre is an officially designated adult training support service and is located in Bairnsdale in my electorate of Gippsland.

In essence, Noweyung is a day training centre helping intellectually disabled people to become more independent and training them for employment. It hardly needs to be said that these objectives receive the enthusiastic endorsement and support of all members of the Parliament. There are approximately 40 clients at Noweyung ranging in age from the late teens to the sixties. I say in passing that Noweyung is very highly regarded and is supported both morally and financially by the east Gippsland community.

The Council for Intellectual Disability Agencies (Victoria) Inc. held a zone meeting in early April in Maffra, which is also in my electorate. It was in the form of a workshop to consider options in Gippsland for aged people with an intellectual disability. Naturally, Noweyung was represented at that workshop. The workshop identified a number of significant issues affecting the intellectually disabled aged in Gippsland.

As I said earlier, the issue upon which I wish to concentrate my remarks in the very brief time allowed today is that of the requirement for the intellectually disabled aged to attend day training centres. In other words, sadly they are unable to retire to their residences because of a lack of staffing during the day. A number of clients of Noweyung reside in CRUs-community residential units. These are houses located in the community in Bairnsdale and they reinforce the goal of independence for people with an intellectual disability. CRUs are generally owned by community organisations and in Bairnsdale are owned by the Noweyung Centre or by the Kilmany Family Care Organisation, which is very well known in east Gippsland and is an agency of the Uniting Church. However, State and Federal governments share the recurrent costs associated with CRUs. The State Government provides the majority of funding and the Commonwealth funds administrative costs and some ongoing costs.

Since staffing of the community residential units is for a morning and an evening only, every person at a CRU must find a day placement. That is fine for a young person who wants to attend training centres like Noweyung to obtain independence and training skills, but what about the people of retirement age? Many of them wish to remain at home in the community residential unit and pursue gardening interests or handiwork-work of a personal nature. Some will be interested in pottery; some might be interested in woodwork. This is the problem in essence.

I will quote directly from the minutes of the workshop held in Maffra by the Council of Intellectual Disability Agencies of Victoria in early April because it best summarises the problems for us. With respect to the major issues affecting aged people with an intellectual disability, the minutes state:
Lack of options in Adult Training Support Services for ageing clients who are no longer interested in training and employment and for whom these services are no longer relevant.
Providing for aged clients is not a function of Adult Training Support Services, therefore these services are not appropriate for the aged and retirees. Everyone has a right to retire.
CRU residents cannot stay at home during the day.

There is an assumption that residents attend other programs such as adult training support services. CRU's are not funded to provide a service during the day. Lack of choice for the aged-e.g. can't decide to stay at home for the day.
The need for choices, options and flexibility is the key issue.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this is something of a new problem. The easiest and most obvious way to solve it, I think you would agree, is to increase funding for daytime staff in CRUs. That may not be financially realistic or even necessarily the best solution to the emerging problem. What can be said with certainty, however, is that governments must consider as a matter of some urgency solutions to these problems. Perhaps work that I am not aware of has been done by governments. If so, I will be glad to know of it from the Minister for the Aged, Family and Health Services, who is at the table. This is most certainly an issue which I will pursue on behalf of Noweyung and the intellectually disabled aged generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting the National Health Amendment Bill because of what it will do not only for aged Australians in general, but also for older people living in the region which I represent. I think that this Government has a record of quiet reform in this area which has been quite positive. It has developed a national policy towards the care of the aged which has centred upon the needs of the aged rather than having other things as its focus. I think it is very important that the Government has considered the needs of those people and has tried to put in place policies which reflect and cater for those needs.

SPEECH.PARA: First, one of the major thrusts of this Government's aged care policies has been to enable older people to remain in their homes for as long as possible. To do that, we have put in place the home and community care (HACC) program. Over the last five years that program has been of enormous benefit in expanding domiciliary care services such as home nursing, home help, personal care, Meals on Wheels, home maintenance, transport services and day care centres. A part of the HACC program has been the flexibility which has been allowed to fund services that in the local communities are of benefit and cater for the needs of those it is servicing.

The second thrust of the aged care policy of the Government is the provision of a high standard of residential care. No matter how we would like to provide services which would enable older people to stay in their own homes and live within their own communities, there are people who do need to go into residential care. The Government has addressed the important aspects of the standards required for nursing homes and the techniques with which we can monitor those standards. It is no good having nursing homes that are of poor quality. The people whom we are talking about are entitled to receive the best quality care. This Bill contains additional measures that will further assist this process.

The third aspect the Government has addressed is that of the fees charged to residents. Up to now, many residents in private nursing homes have paid well above the minimum resident contribution, which is set at 87 1/2 per cent of the full single pension plus rent assistance. When we look at the fact that 90 per cent of nursing home residents are pensioners, we see that paying above the minimum fee set is a considerable burden. It is pleasing to see that from 1 July this year, no resident in any nursing home need pay more than the minimum resident contribution. It is an enormous achievement after five years to have reached the point where residents of nursing homes can be completely secure in knowing that they can afford the costs of their care.

In the brief time that I have left to speak I would like to mention two projects that cater for older people in my electorate. The first is a project that is under construction at the moment. The auspice body, the Villa Maria Society for the Blind, is constructing Villa Madonna, stage 1 of a 40-bed nursing home. The Federal Government has provided $1.2m for this, which has been extremely appreciated.

The point that it does illustrate is that, in a sense, we have encouraged people to cater for older people with special requirements, whether it be because of disabilities or whether it be because of-importantly to my electorate-coming from migrant communities. I am pleased to see that the Government is continuing in that vein.

The other program that I would like to mention briefly is, of course, the Bundoora Extended Care Centre (BECC). It describes itself as a centre of excellence in the care of older people. I think the people who know that centre would agree that it can indeed entitle itself in that way. The important services that it provides are geriatric assessment teams which ensure that people are placed within, or put within and targeted towards, the appropriate services.

The BECC also has a computerised nursing home waiting list which can give us valuable information on the needs for nursing home places in the region which it services. Another project is its community care project, which is an extension of the HACC philosophy where it assists people to match themselves up with services which will assist them in remaining in their own homes. In February last year it opened an information centre which provides, in a citizens advice bureau style, information to older people on all aspects of accommodation, health care and community services that cater for old people.

Finally, of course, it will go into the provision of nursing home placements. The nursing homes that it has put in place have unique and very innovative designs that will ensure that the older people placed within those homes get the type and standard of care that they are entitled to. In conclusion, I have great pleasure in supporting this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister seen media reports about the removal of Cambodian boat people from Sydney to Darwin? I ask the Minister: what is the current situation of the Cambodian boat people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question.
—Laurie is back. How are the numbers going?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—I would have thought, given the rare occasions I get to the box, that people would be interested in what is a very important issue. There has been a lot of misinformation and hysteria surrounding the Cambodians and the movement of these people. Let me go through the facts and processes we are required to adhere to if we are to maintain the integrity of the migration program and our international obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: Dealing with the Cambodian boat people: since November 1989 five boats with a total of 320 people have arrived from Cambodia. It must be remembered that unauthorised boat arrivals have technically not entered Australia. Despite this, they can lodge claims for protection on refugee grounds. As prohibited immigrants, these people cannot under law simply move into the community. They can enter only when they have a legal basis to remain in Australia. For this reason they must be kept in custody. I point out to the House that last year I attempted to move all of these people into the one facility. For a whole range of reasons, mainly through the intervention of community support groups, I was persuaded not to do that. Some of these groups put to me most strongly that in the interests of natural justice the boat arrivals should not be moved to a central location.

I remind the House of the process these people are involved in to establish their refugee status. All applicants for refugee status are assessed against the United Nations definition of a refugee. This definition has as its guiding principle the concept of well-founded fear of persecution. I cannot emphasise strongly enough how fair and just this system is. I believe that nowhere else in the world do applicants have the opportunities they have in Australia to substantiate their claims. Nowhere else in the world are those claims so thoroughly assessed. The checks and balances that have been built into the system are second to none.

I turn to the question of the movement of these people. Last Monday week one group of Cambodians was moved from Sydney to Darwin. The media has been running hot with alarmist and distorted stories about this. We have been accused of heavy handed tactics and secrecy over decisions on these people. I want to put a couple of things straight for the record. The basic privacy principles prevent me or my Department from discussing individual decisions. It is not my intention now to discuss the merits of these specific cases, or ever in the future to discuss the merits of individual cases, especially ones so sensitive as those involving applications for refugee status.

The applicants themselves, or those purporting to represent their interests, have made the decisions public. I must emphasise that, contrary to reports, these people have not been deported. No-one has been deported. They have their review rights, which they have yet to exercise. Given the outcome of the primary decision, there was a strong case for transferring the group to more secure accommodation than the relaxed conditions in which they were being held. The move was made in a responsible way and in the interests of the welfare of the people.

I am informed that no telephones were disconnected. The only telephones they ever had access to were the public ones and in the manager's office. They were in fact given access to the phones in the manager's office. The elderly lady herself chose, after discussions with departmental officers and members of her community, to go to Darwin. We put a doctor on the plane with her, so she was fully covered healthwise. The group's legal representative was advised at 11 a.m. and the group left Sydney at 2.30. No individual was handcuffed, either in Sydney or during the journey to Darwin. The dignity of all individuals involved was fully respected at all times.

So where does that leave me today? If there is one message I would like to get across it is this: if a person arrives in Australia without documentation, the proper processes must be adhered to; otherwise it will distort our immigration program and the significant reforms we have brought into the migration area over the past few years. Some months ago-this might be of interest to those people purporting to support the Cambodian people-I initiated discussions with the Cambodian authorities to establish an orderly departure program from that country. This would prevent people making the hazardous, treacherous, dangerous voyage-in terms of pirates and other threats-they are forced to make. I look forward to that day.
