As the Leader of the Opposition said the other day, `I've got a lot tougher options than that'.
—That is right.

—That is right, a lot tougher options-like handing back billions of dollars of unrealised capital gains; like the abolition of the company tax; like income taxes levied at a State level; like a zero inflation outcome, while adding 15 per cent to prices and to inflation; like health vouchers without any details about how the poor will be protected; like education vouchers, the same; like telling workers they cannot get their lump sums till age 65; like making people deal with a private organisation for social security. These are the radical alternatives. We are waiting to hear the Leader of the Opposition courageously put the details because, when the Deputy Leader was challenged today, he was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What's your rate going to be? What's your consumption tax rate going to be?
Mr Reith: Well, we'll tell you what the rate's going to be in due course.
Then the next question was:
But you also have to come clean and answer some more questions. You have to tell us what the rate is and when you are going to tell us. When are you going to tell us about the rate?
Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting!
—The answer was:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, we'll tell you in good course.
Questioner:
Well, when is in due course?
Answer:
I'm not putting a date on it. I'm not going to have you sitting on my doorstep.
Then the questioner-he was persistent, this guy-said again:
Well, six months, 12 months? When will we have the details?
Answer:
All in good time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 145, but I also remind you again of both the precedent that I have drawn to your attention and the one you drew to my attention, which I have since researched. The precedent I bring to your attention is the precedent of Speaker Snedden, who of course said that the Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party. Having researched the remark--
—Order! The honourable member has drawn my attention to a standing order.
—No, the fact is that, on the occasion you mentioned, Speaker Snedden did uphold similar points of order on two occasions in that exchange. I now point out to you--
—Order! The honourable member has raised his point of order and I will rule on his point of order.

—I want to complete my argument on this serious subject. My point of order on irrelevance is that we have had a question put to the Treasurer. The Treasurer, of course, is talking about things in the future when one would think this Parliament would be entitled to know how he is going to reinstate 500,000 jobs.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—That is the issue of today, and I ask you to do as Speaker Snedden did and ask him to draw his answer to a close.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Treasurer is in order. He is answering the question.
—The Government has adopted an economic policy which has had all of the economic and social balances--
—It has failed.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—It has had all of the economic and social balances weighed properly. Yet this so-called alternative will not deal with Australia's current account and inflation difficulties. This is not a solution. It is radical, but it is not a radical solution. It will create a radical mess of the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition is now backing off at a million miles an hour from its consumption tax. It will not say what the rate is or what the details are. Honourable members opposite have penny-ante questions about the wholesale sales tax when they are not prepared to detail a thing. As the Prime Minister said, the Opposition comes here, puts an issue up, and when pressed for details it evaporates-the bubble blows, it evaporates. What we want from the professor is some detail. We want some detail from the Leader of the Opposition. And we can well understand why the Opposition backbench is now highly nervous about the Leader of the Opposition's strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A shrinking violet!

—If the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition continue to interject, the chair may have to take some action. I warn the honourable member for MacKellar, who has just interjected.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BLACK ECONOMY: GOODS AND SERVICES TAX

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: is it a fact that the black economy in Australia is worth about $10 billion a year and that about half a million Australians earn some of their income in the black economy? Is it also a fact that no tax is currently paid on money earned in the black economy but that the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax means that these people would start to pay their fair share of tax? Is it a fact, therefore--
—Panic!
—Just wait for it. Is it a fact, therefore, that failing to introduce a goods and services tax means that this Government is the friend of tax cheats and tax avoiders?
—Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise. Honourable members on my right and on my left will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gall of those opposite on the question of taxation is beyond measure. We on this side of the House, this party, has not had a royal commission condemn this Government as having the tax avoidance industry as the fastest growing industry in the country. I remind honourable members opposite--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind those opposite that that was precisely the indictment of the Liberal and National parties by their own royal commissioner who found that the fastest growing industry in the country was the tax avoidance industry. The Opposition had been told, when in government-the Opposition had been told and had been warned by every relevant authority-that the way it administered the tax system in this country allowed people to cheat, defraud and impose a greater burden on the ordinary people of this country. The honourable member for Bennelong, then Treasurer, did virtually nothing about it, perhaps because to a large extent he was not allowed to.
—What about Brian Burke?
—Order!

—Those opposite take the view about the governance of this country that the greatest burden should be imposed upon those with the least capacity to pay. One would have hoped that those opposite would have learned from the exposure of their dereliction of duty in their previous term of government. Obviously they have not.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat: we on this side of the House are pleased beyond measure to see how concerned now the Opposition has become about this issue. It is not surprising that it is this week we are seeing this series of questions, because many honourable members opposite have come to understand that they simply will not be able to sell, in this country, the concept of a broad-based consumption tax. Honourable members opposite will not be able to do it because it is, by nature, regressive. It means that the poor, the lower to middle income earners, will pay relatively more for everything they buy than those who are rich. Honourable members opposite know that that is true.

The situation would be bad enough if that was all that they were doing, but I repeat: the Opposition's felony in this regard is compounded by the fact that it is doing this to raise more money-not less-as the honourable member for O'Connor said. The Opposition is not talking about a broad-based consumption tax to raise less money--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—Order!

—The Opposition is talking about it to raise more money. And what is its purpose for raising more money? It is so that in this area of tax it can take the capital gains tax off those who, under its previous administration, avoided paying billions and billions of dollars. Just take a simple example. The person-the man or woman-who worked in an enterprise or a company, by the sweat of his muscle or the toil of his brow, the person who worked paid--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha! Ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members laugh because they are the protectors of privilege. In the period up to 1983 they believed that it was, as they still believe that it is, all right for the factory worker or the clerk, on what that factory worker or clerk did, to pay his full share or her full share of taxation; but if someone, who just incidentally had some shares in that company, picked up the phone and said `Buy' or `Sell', and happened to make some significant capital gain on that massive exercise, they believed that that capital gain should have gone untaxed. That is the Opposition's concept of fairness.
—You are wrong! It is already taxed under the Act, you dope.
—They are not all taxed. If they happen to acquire something else--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo, and the honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—If the privileged, the already wealthy, in this country happened to acquire wealth simply by the fact that their capital asset increases in value, then they pay no contribution. The Opposition, when in government, allowed them to avoid billions and billions of dollars. The result was that when it went out of office, it had a top tax rate--
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Prime Minister has not addressed himself to the subject of the black economy and the $10 billion in tax avoidance.

—I am talking about the black economy of those opposite, and what they allowed to go untaxed. Those opposite allowed billions and billions of dollars that should have gone into the tax revenue of this country to go untaxed. That was because those who acquired this enormous wealth through the increase in the value of assets were the people with whom the Opposition is socially and politically identified.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is it in order for the Prime Minister to mislead the House by failing to distinguish between a tax on a capital gain and audited tax paid by a share trader?
—Order! There is no point of order. The member for Bennelong will resume his seat.

—Opposition members talk about the black economy, and that was the great black hole that they left untaxed. As I said, for a quarter of a century, when in office, they allowed people who should have been contributing to the revenue of this country to go untaxed. This country was denied, literally, billions and billions of dollars because those opposite allowed their friends, the ones with whom they identified, to go untaxed. It was not until this Party came to government that those billions of dollars started to be paid as they should have been paid before. That was the black hole in the Australian tax system, but they have not learnt.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition is saying now-this is a simple truth-that it will bring in a regressive, broad-based consumption tax and make the poor, the low and middle income earners, pay more than the wealthy. Those opposite can then use those proceeds to abolish the capital gains tax and once again allow that black hole to appear in the Australian taxation system. We repeat, on this side of the House, that the Opposition should stick to its guns, because they are the guns that will shoot it down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources in his capacity as the Minister responsible for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
—What! You mucked it up yesterday.
—Order! The member for Higgins will cease interjecting.
—My question concerns pit bull-terriers, but I do not have one to table, I am afraid.
—The member might get on with his question.

—Is the Minister aware of growing concern in the community regarding the importation of pit bull-terriers, given their record of vicious attacks on children and the recent decision by the British Parliament to ban these dogs? Does the Minister agree that these dogs are dangerous and pose a risk to health and safety? What action does the Government intend to take to address these issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, and I recall that in 1988 he raised this issue in the House. I have also received a number of submissions and representations from various members of the Parliament, including the Deputy Premier of Queensland and the honourable member for Kennedy to name just a couple.

ANSWER.PARA: At the outset I should point out that at present there are no provisions under the Quarantine Act by which particular breeds of dogs, or even savage dogs, might be prevented from entering Australia. It is worth noting that there has been a significant increase in the number of pit bull-terriers and similar dogs that fall broadly into the category of those dogs bred specifically for fighting purposes. I might say that pit bull-terriers are to the wider canine community what the honourable member for O'Connor is to parliamentary Standing Orders. Putting that aside--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Charles

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: very clearly standing order 76 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
Mr Speaker, you should therefore require the Minister to withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister might help the debate by withdrawing any imputation against the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I am happy to withdraw, Mr Speaker.
—Why did you say it?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Higgins, and the honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting as well.
—However, I will not be muzzled--
—This is pathetic.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo might remember my previous warning.

—On a more serious note, because this is a very serious issue, as evidenced by the number of representations I have received from a range of people in this Parliament, the issue is the importation of this category of fighting dogs, who represent a real danger to community health and safety. For example, unofficial figures in the United States indicate that some 20 or so of the latest 24 fatalities that have arisen as a result of dog attack are relevant to this issue. That is, pit bull-terriers or similar dogs have been involved in those fatalities. I think honourable members need no reminding about the recent spate of incidents in the United Kingdom-most recently an attack on a young child that very nearly was a fatality-and not so long ago in Queensland one instance of an attack where one of these dogs killed a Shetland pony, another dog and a cat.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a serious issue. I have announced a review to be conducted by the primary industries and resources committee to look at the whole raft of issues involved here. We need to be cognisant of the right of owners to have these breeds of dogs, but at the very minimum we should look at whether we should continue to allow such dogs to be imported and, if we do import them, under what conditions. Possibly, as in other instances, we would have neutering of dogs to ensure that there was not a proliferation of these dogs. We might also look at issues such as compulsory muzzling and other regulatory requirements when the dogs are in the wider community.

I conclude by saying that I think honourable members will be aware from the growing incidence of these types of dogs in their own communities that they represent a real threat to the wider community. One need look only at the reactions of parents as they walk their children down the street and one of these dogs comes along-either on or off a leash-to realise that at the very minimum this matter ought to receive detailed and serious consideration by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister of the statement made by the Treasurer on 13 March this year, and I quote--
—When are you going to give me a question?
—You're dead meat, pal, disappear.
—When are you going to give me a question?
—Order! The Treasurer will cease interjecting.
—I quote the Treasurer:

QUESTION.PARA: Since 1983 the Government has undertaken path-breaking reforms of the Australian tax system.

Is it a fact that since 1983 the Hawke Government has increased sales tax collections from $3.5 billion to $10.7 billion, an annual increase of more than 18 per cent while inflation has averaged just over 7 per cent? Does the Prime Minister honestly believe that the tripling of the wholesale sales tax burden on Australian families and businesses can legitimately be seen as a reform? Finally, what compensation has been paid to Australian families for this increase in the wholesale sales tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the shadow Treasurer, the honourable gentleman who asked the question, understood anything about economics, which obviously he knows nothing about-it has been obvious for many months-he would understand that in an economy which has experienced the considerable rates of growth that we have, we would expect an increase in sales receipts. That is precisely what has happened. If we look at the contribution that has been made by this Government in the area of tax collection, we find that we have transformed an economy which was one of the most inefficient and inequitable in the world-a fact that was recognised internationally. When Opposition members went out of office, they left what was recognised as one of the most inefficient and inequitable tax systems in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the leadership of the Deputy Prime Minister, in his role as Treasurer, there has been a massive reform of the tax system which has made it both more efficient and more equitable. That is something which is recognised by virtually every commentator in this country and abroad. If we want to have an assessment done of the coalition's seven years of stewardship and what it left as a tax system, compared with what the Australian tax system is now after eight years of this Government, I will guarantee that the assessment from the independent assessors will say on every occasion that we leave the Opposition for dead, as we have done and as we will continue to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer advise the House what measures have been taken to ensure a fairer and more equitable tax system in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has already referred to the scandalous state of the tax system when the Government came to office. It came to office just after the former Taxation Commissioner had enjoined the former Treasurer over a period of years to help him repair the tax system by what is now recorded in the famous so-called telephone book of letters, which the Commissioner then published. When the Government of the day tried to attack the Australian Taxation Office--
—He did not.
—Yes, he did.
—That's a lie.
—The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that remark.
—The letters were a disgrace and members of the Opposition should have hung their heads in shame.
—Mr Speaker, that is a deliberate misrepresentation of the facts.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw the remark.
—I withdraw the remark; but it is a misrepresentation of the fact, and he knows it.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I call the Treasurer.

—Since the Government came to office it has systematically tried to deal with tax avoidance by broadening the tax base and by removing opportunities for avoidance where most of the avoidance schemes had, in the main, a capital gain pinned underneath them. We dealt with that by the adoption of a capital gains tax-which both the Leader of the Opposition and his deputy this week have committed themselves to removing-by the establishment of the fringe benefits tax, which was opposed by the coalition, by substantiation; by the abolition of entertainment as a deduction; by reducing tax rates to lift compliance; and by reducing the Opposition's 60 per cent marginal rate to a top personal rate of 47 per cent and the rate of tax on distributed income from 78c in the dollar to 47c for companies. At the same time, as far as the elderly are concerned, we removed full rate pensioners from the tax system, and by 1995 we will remove even part rate pensioners from the tax system.

ANSWER.PARA: This is why the tax base of Australia is now more secure. It is one of the reasons why fiscal policy has been more successful in the last half dozen years, because now the tax system is doing its proper job. The tax administration has had the proper support, with both personnel and resources, and a courageous commissioner supported by the Government, instead of a commissioner trodden under by a government which was interested in supporting tax avoidance-the former coalition Government.

It becomes a bit of a laugh when we have the Deputy Leader of the National Party asking a question and arguing to the Prime Minister that there should be a consumption tax to stop tax avoidance. As if the coalition ever had the slightest interest in tax avoidance! It had none as the tax system fell apart under the weight of the tax avoidance industry. We saw all that history. He said that there should be reforms such as dividend imputation where shareholders only get a rebate if the primary tax has been paid. That is one of the reasons why corporate tax collections have gone up 500 per cent since the Government came to office-because of more growth and more activity.
Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you ask a question?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.

—Look, ask a question instead of sitting there like a turkey. This Government has radically altered the Australian tax system and has introduced, for the better, taxes which are path breaking-the fringe benefits tax, substantiation, capital gains, dividend imputation-and in relation to which the Australian Treasury is often visited by other large international Treasuries, looking at these particular measures, because they have been world firsts, nearly everyone of them. That is why the Australian tax system today is more decent, more clean and more fair than it has ever been in its history
—And more efficient.

—And more efficient, as the Prime Minister says. The notion that we should have a consumption tax to tax the black economy because honourable members opposite are interested in tax avoidance is, of course, simply a sick joke.

—I direct my question, absolutely without notice, to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister accept that the existing wholesale tax system is riddled with anomalies favouring the rich? How can he justify a sales tax on the chocolate biscuits and ice-cream that ordinary people buy, when the privileged pay no tax on caviar and oysters? How can he justify a 20 per cent tax on the humble bicycle, when there is no similar impost on people who can afford to pay for a chauffeured car? More importantly, how can he justify a 20 per cent tax on the handyman's tool box, when highly paid Government Ministers, amongst others, do not pay sales tax on designer Italian suits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the design of any wholesale tax system, it is inevitable that there will be some anomalies.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise on my left.

—As distinct from that inevitability, what is being proposed by those opposite is not some minor anomalies between classifications but something which is a major social disaster. If they believe it is not an anomaly, let alone a disaster, to impose on every person in this country a massive increase in tax which will discriminate against the poor and the low to middle income earners, then they have another think coming. I can tell them that if they go on with this proposal, which we sincerely trust they will, the people of this country will make their judgment about it, because they will know that what they are motivated by is what, historically, has motivated members of the tory parties in this country. They have always been about having a tax system that gives a further opportunity to those who are already rich and privileged to avoid making a contribution to the Commonwealth revenues. That is what has characterised every conservative government in the history of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Those opposite will go to the top of that conservative class, because on this occasion their proposal is to impose this regressive tax, this broad-based consumption tax, that will make the poor pay as much as the rich for every item that they buy. In doing that, they will increase their revenues so that they can shovel billions of dollars back into their pockets, into the pockets of the already rich. That is what they are about. The honourable member for O'Connor knows what it is about, and I am sure that no-one, whether up there in the gallery or elsewhere in Australia, will avoid the obvious conclusion that, as a result of last Saturday, those opposite are starting to get very worried indeed about their capacity to hoodwink the people of this country. All we on this side say is, `Start to spell it out'. For instance, just last week the Leader of the Opposition confirmed that the consumption tax would apply to electricity accounts.
Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No. On 21 May the Leader of the Opposition was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Will that be on electricity accounts and telephone accounts?
The Leader of the Opposition stated:
In principle, until we announce the detail, it will be on everything.

I suggest that those opposite will have to do a lot of explanations to the pensioners of this country. They should explain to the pensioners of this country how they will justify a situation where they impose this consumption tax upon the use of their telephones. As we know, the phone, for many pensioners, is their connection to the outside world. How will those opposite compensate them? Will it be on an average sort of charge so that the people who need to use it most will pay more? What about their electricity accounts? Are those opposite going to provide some sort of subsidy to the States to cover the pensioners in regard to their electricity accounts?

These are the questions of detail in regard to the poor and underprivileged in this country that we are waiting for members of the Opposition to spell out. They have had plenty of opportunity. They say that they never come up with a proposal until they have thought through it in detail, but on every occasion when they are asked by the press or by anyone else to give some detail they say that they have no detail. When they get the detail in regard to what they will do to pensioners we will be waiting for them but, more importantly, so will the pensioners be waiting for them in 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister inform the House of the purposes and findings of the mission which recently visited South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At my request, a delegation lead by Professor Ross Garnaut of the Australian National University, including a Deputy Secretary of my Department and officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau visited Johannesburg, Cape Town, and Pretoria from 9 to 16 May.

ANSWER.PARA: The achievement one day of a non-racial democracy in South Africa is now inevitable. I have long believed it will be of immense importance that the Government which comes to power in South Africa when apartheid has been scrapped should have the will and the capability to manage the economy of that country effectively. The economic policy experience in postcolonial Africa has not been a happy one and it will be tragic if the same or similar mistakes were to be made in South Africa.

In particular, it has been my consistent view that as South Africa moves towards a more equitable and just society there must always continue to be a place for white business, for enterprise and capital. It is clear that South Africa has embarked on an historic process of political transition, albeit one that is complex, challenging and will undoubtedly proceed in fits and starts.

To the extent that the African National Congress seems to be developing economic policies which are practical and sensible, the greater will be the confidence in South Africa about making the transition to majority rule. I and members of the Government have discussed these matters on a number of occasions with leaders of black opinion, people who will have an influence in a future democratic South Africa. Most recently I had the opportunity of having such discussions here with Nelson Mandela.

The mission that I sent to South Africa was designed as a practical and useful follow-up to these ideas and to these discussions. It went there with two essential purposes: first, to undertake discussions with a range of relevant interest in South Africa about economic policy for the post-apartheid period and, second, to consider ways in which Australia might assist with the development of the intellectual infrastructure for sound economic policy.

The mission held very extensive discussions with organisations and the mass democratic movement, with the Government, with academic economists, with representatives of South African business, both white and black, with analysts of the South African economy and with other people.

The Government has received a very useful report from the delegation which is currently under study. I am not in a position at this stage to announce decisions, but I will say that the delegation has provided useful recommendations in relation both to enhancing the capability in South Africa for economic research and policy development and longer term training and education.

When decisions are taken by the Government, I am confident that honourable members will see them as a constructive expression of our wish to look beyond issues such as sanctions and the present difficulties in South Africa, important though those issues are, and to position ourselves in this country to make a contribution to the well-being of all South Africans in the non-racial democratic South Africa which surely will one day come about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. According to the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University, at least $1.2 billion a year is paid in sales tax on business inputs for export products. How does he justify maintaining this wholesale sales tax system when he claims to be aiming for a competitive and clever country? How can our export industries be competitive when our major trading partners do not have to carry this extra burden?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with the honourable gentleman's question is that the premise is wrong. It assumes that our export industries are not competitive.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Opposition runs up against facts, all it is reduced to is this hollow belly laugh. I will repeat the facts to the honourable gentleman. I know the facts upset him when they get in the way of his prejudices and predispositions. But I will remind him again of the figures which I have put to this House before. These are figures which not only should he not reject but of which he should be proud.

ANSWER.PARA: The premise of his question is that Australian industry is not competitive. How then does he explain the facts which I have put before the House on a previous occasion and which I put again? These are the figures from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development which show the comparison of Australia's performance in the latter part of the 1980s with the rest of the world and with the OECD. How, if we are not competitive, do those opposite explain the fact, in regard to manufacturing exports, that the average for the OECD from 1983 to 1989 was an index figure of 100, and in 1985-base 100 for the OECD average-there was a 31 per cent increase? The index went from 100 to 131. That was the index for the OECD. Australia's performance was up from 100 to 179.

If the honourable member begins to have any knowledge of the subject on which he purports to ask a question which is based upon the premise that we are not competitive, how does he begin to explain that the OECD average in this period was a 31 per cent increase in manufacturing exports and Australia's was 79? The premise of his question is false. The reason why the premise of his question is false is that this Government, by a series of decisions, has created a more competitive economy in this country, not least because we have a wages policy in this country which the Opposition has never had and which it would never be capable of introducing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Can the Minister inform honourable members of what further progress has been made in ending driftnet fishing in the South Pacific?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his question and acknowledge that the honourable member has been a leading opponent of driftnet fishing. As the Parliament is aware, this Government has actively opposed the use of driftnets in the South Pacific, particularly since the sudden upsurge in driftnet fishing towards the beginning of 1989, particularly by Japan and Taiwan.

ANSWER.PARA: The action we have taken in the region, first of all, is with the conclusion of the Wellington Convention in November 1989 to ban driftnet fishing-we worked on that convention-and globally, of course, through the United Nations in relation to driftnet fishing. Therefore, the Government welcomes the entry into force last week, on 17 May, of the Wellington Convention, which bans driftnet fishing in the South Pacific. Australia itself will be able shortly to ratify the convention once the amending legislation has been passed through the Parliament.

We also welcome the United States signature to the convention and its first protocol. We note that the American Administration has sent a message to Congress advocating ratification of the convention. Also, we welcome the fact that Japan from July 1990, and Taiwan earlier this year, ceased driftnet fishing in the South Pacific. The entry into force of the convention means that driftnet fishing has now completely ceased in the South Pacific.

This is a major regional achievement, which has involved extensive cooperation between Australia, the Forum Island countries and the Forum Fisheries Agency. Of course, we are not satisfied with that achievement. We have still got concerns about driftnet fishing operations in other oceans, including the Indian Ocean, where large Taiwanese fishing fleets still operate.
The Government will continue to oppose the use of driftnet fishing globally, and our opposition will be registered at the next session of the United Nations General Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and I ask it against the background of his concern for tax avoidance. Is it a fact that there is a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on brown paper bags? Given the evidence before the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, was the only tax paid on the money raised by Brian Burke the 20 per cent sales tax on the bags?
—No comment.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Did the Minister see the recent Four Corners documentary on alcohol advertising in Australia? What is the Government doing to tighten up the self-regulatory system of alcohol advertising?
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Surely the honourable member is asking the Minister to announce policy.
—The honourable member for Moreton has asked the Minister a question. The question is in order.

—Mr Speaker, further to the point of order, I am well aware he asked the Minister a question. I am asking you whether the question is in order on the grounds that the honourable member is asking the Minister to announce policy, which is forbidden under the Standing Orders.
—Order! Would the honourable member for Moreton ask the question again or rephrase the question.
—Order! With all the interjections in the House, I need to be clear on what the honourable member was saying. The honourable member will ask his question again.

—I asked whether the Minister had seen a recent Four Corners program on alcohol advertising. I asked what the Government is doing-not what the Government is intending to do-to tighten up the self-regulatory system.
—Order! The question is in order. Even to ask the Minister what the Government's intentions are on the matter is also in order. The Minister will answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that all State and Territory governments, along with the Federal Government, believe that the existing self-regulatory system for alcohol advertising needs re-examination. A national survey was done under the national campaign against drug abuse of community attitudes on alcohol advertising. The vast majority of people perceive that the current code of alcohol advertising seems to be in conflict with what they see on their television screens, read in their newspapers and hear on the radio.

ANSWER.PARA: The issues the Government is concerned about spring basically from the sad fact that in Australia about 6,000 Australians die every year because of alcohol abuse, at a cost of at least $6,000m annually to our economy and our society. There are also very extensive costs to industry, which are difficult to quantify because that $6,000m does not cover the cost of sickies and absenteeism, workplace and low productivity that come about as a result of alcohol abuse, in the workplace in particular. At the moment very little information is collected on these particular matters. I do not think that Australia can afford to lose one life, let alone the costs associated with alcohol abuse.

It is also pertinent to note that alcohol abuse, as distinct from reasonable alcohol usage, is associated with crime and violence. I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question because I know he is very concerned about these issues. It would be instructive for members of this House to go back to the first speech of the honourable member for Moreton in this House, when he raised the issue of violence, particularly domestic violence.

There are things that governments can do and there are things that the whole community is responsible for. What the Federal Government is seeking, along with every other State and Territory Government right across the political spectrum, is community involvement and participation in dealing with these issues. The State, Territory and Commonwealth Ministers have asked the Media Council of Australia to look at alcohol advertising.

There is a discussion paper currently circulating in the community, in a major community consultation, and we expect the Media Council of Australia to report back to the Ministers of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy by September.

I have also recently established an Alcohol Industry Consultative Council which has representatives from all peak alcohol industry bodies, from the manufacturers through to the retailers. This will enable a formal, regular and constructive process to operate in which the Government can work with the alcohol industry on issues such as advertising and labelling.

We are trying to address the issue of alcohol abuse, as distinct from reasonable usage by the community, by working with the community and with industry and to seek their active participation in dealing with these problems. It is only by active participation of all involved in coming to terms with a very serious problem in our community that these issues will be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has gone beyond his personal explanation. He ought not to debate the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). During Question Time the Treasurer completely misrepresented matters affecting my administration as Treasurer in two very important respects. SPEECH.PARA: The second area of misrepresentation is his oft repeated claim that no anti-tax avoidance legislation was passed by the former Government. I would remind the Treasurer and the House that, in the time that I was Treasurer, I passed the following landmark pieces of tax avoidance legislation: I outlawed the Curran tax avoidance scheme, the dividend stripping scheme; I introduced the new part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was necessary in the face of the literal interpretation being then given by the High Court of Australia to section 260; I introduced the Crimes (Tax Offences) Act of 1980, which was the first occasion that any government in this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the honourable member--
—I am giving facts, Mr Deputy Speaker. He has used the Question Time of this Parliament year after year, day after day, on a daily basis and--
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Well, I do take a point of order. I am indebted to the Leader of the House. —Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order, I acknowledge that the former Treasurer tabled the so-called telephone book of letters. In that respect, he is correct. But the letters themselves were a sham and a shocking disgrace to his administration.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The fundamental need to adopt a Goods and Services Tax as part of a comprehensive package of structural reforms to get Australia out of its current economic malaise.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless politicians are prepared to give some leadership to fight for a better tax system and a better industrial relations system, and unless politicians are prepared to tackle the hard issues facing this country, then I say that basically this country is doomed. The Government can run all the scare campaigns it likes. It can run up to the next election with a scare campaign on tax-as it will, I am sure-but I say to the Government that we will fight this issue literally tooth and nail all the way down the wire for the simple reason that this country needs a better tax system. It is an essential, fundamental part of the restructuring of the Australian economy which we will implement as we go into the next election and then start to implement our policies.

SPEECH.PARA: This country has some pretty basic problems. We have a massive debt-$131 billion and climbing. We literally have a rural crisis, if not a rural depression. We have trade union leaders who have too much power. We have a Government which is bloated and inefficient. We have the States' finances in a deplorable state. We discourage people from saving. We have a tax system where people pay not only too much tax but a system which is in itself inefficient. On top of that, what are we facing? We are literally staring down the barrel of a depression.

What is the response of the Australian Labor Party? I say to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), honestly, I think he ought to be ashamed of his response. On leadership-he undermines his own leader to pursue his own personal ambitions. He puts the country's interests second best to that. He spends all his time running around with his campaign managers and others to advance his own cause.

On policy-he is up here with his deception and his fiction about the state of the Australian economy. A couple of months ago the Treasurer actually said that `the recovery was coming through now.' Every year he has the gall to say, `things are getting better'. Remember that one when he said, `we are entering a golden age'? He said, `Australia has turned the corner'. There was that Budget one when he said that he was going to bring home the bacon.

Every year this economy worsens. The bottom line is that there is a decline in living standards for the average Australian family. As a result we face the really horrific prospect that we as a generation could pass onto the next generation a lower level of living standards than we ourselves have enjoyed.

Look at the Government's wages policy. It is an absolute shambles. The Government does not have a wages policy. It is literally in no man's land. It has abandoned its own centralised system in, literally, a fit of pique. It has adopted the rhetoric of an enterprise bargaining system but it does not have the guts to take on its mates in the trade union movement to adopt a decent enterprise system.

Fiscal policy-it is literally out of control. The Treasurer himself said last August that fiscal policy was the rock upon which his policy was based, the foundation of his policy. What have we seen since then? The Government had an $8 billion surplus virtually disappear down to $2 billion, and it is likely to go below that. The public sector borrowing requirement-the Government's impact on the national pool of savings-in a couple of good years the Government made a contribution in the total government sector of 1.2 per cent, but what is it now? The Government does not have its wrist in the national pool of savings; it has its whole arm in the national pool of savings with all the implications that has for high interest rates for the Australian community.

The deterioration in fiscal policy is literally of Whitlamesque proportions. As a consequence, when the Treasurer looks to monetary policy-because he has done nothing else in micro-reform, on wages policy or on fiscal policy-he continues to rely on high real interest rates.

As the Governor of the Reserve Bank said the other day, interest rates in this country are still very high. What has brought on the recession? What is the instrument of the recession that the Treasurer said that we had to have? It is high interest rates, of course.

On tax policy, apart from more tax-and the honourable member is the world's greatest Treasurer, he is the biggest taxing Treasurer that we have ever had-where is his policy for the next election? We have already put out one of the most detailed tax policies that any Opposition has ever put out-as detailed as any tax policy-yet the Treasurer has the cheek to come in here and ask us for more policy details.

Let me go through the only pre-election tax policies those opposite have ever had. Do people remember? Back in 1983 the Australian Labor Party said: there will be no capital gains tax. We got a capital gains tax. In 1984 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), sitting in a radio booth in Perth, announced a tax summit. During the last election, what was his policy? It was the luxury car tax. What a fiasco that has been. What a fiasco the Treasurer is as a tax reformer. As we go to the next election, what attraction will the Labor Party be offering the Australian electorate? It will be offering the honourable member for Blaxland as Prime Minister and waging a scare campaign against the Opposition's tax reforms.

The Labor Party will be absolutely annihilated at the next election, because people in the electorate want solutions to Australia's problems; they do not want a lot of silly political games. The only reason that this issue has had a bit of a run this week is that Nick Greiner did not do as well as people thought he would do in New South Wales. Those opposite wanted a distraction from the leadership issue, so they thought they would pin it on the consumption tax. But they have only to ask anybody in New South Wales to find out whether the consumption tax is an issue. If only the Treasurer had gone back to his electorate during the election campaign, he would know it was not an issue. It is just a dead non-issue. Even the Treasurer's own Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said that the consumption tax was not an issue. Of course, none of the polls give any support for the argument.

In due course, we will put out some more detail on the goods and services tax. We will do so at a time that suits us-and for very good reason. Firstly, people will be very much attracted to the tax policy we will put out. Secondly, it is a policy which addresses this country's basic problems.
Let us look at the very extensive detail we have already put out on the goods and services tax. The first thing is that, under a coalition tax policy, people will pay less tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—I will give the Treasurer the answer to that. We will soon debate how we collect tax but, if people want to pay less tax, governments have to cut expenditure. In the last election, we had a list; we were up front. There was none of this business about keeping the tax policy in the bottom drawer. We told people what we were prepared to do by way of cutting back the size of government expenditure-the only route to reduce total tax take if someone is genuine about tax reform.

SPEECH.PARA: We intend to abolish the wholesale sales tax. In the last few years, those opposite have doubled their de facto hidden consumption tax and have never paid a cent in compensation. The tax is regressive, it hits low income earners and it causes no remorse whatsoever for the Treasurer.

Of course this is a matter of concern. That is the reason I went to New Zealand. New Zealand has introduced a goods and services tax. I went to an outer suburb of Wellington, I went to the local parish priest, I went to the Salvation Army, I went to the local accountants and I walked down the main street and talked to people with small businesses. I went doorknocking in a housing commission area outside Wellington and I went to a preschool centre. I asked people the same question: `What do you think about the goods and services tax introduction in New Zealand?'. They said, `It is a fairer, better tax system'. And so it will be when we introduce a goods and services tax.

We will abolish taxes on exports. Blind Freddy can see that we need to boost Australia's export performance to do something about our massive and accumulating debt. It is a joke. The Prime Minister said in here yesterday, `The bush will be opposed to a goods and services tax'. Why then is the National Farmers Federation a strong advocate for this change? The answer is very simple. For starters, we will abolish tax on exports. The Government says, `Let us boost our export performance', but at the same time it has a wholesale sales tax that imposes a penalty on people who are exporting. Something like $1.2 billion is paid in tax on exports. That is a massive millstone around the necks of Australian exporters, the very people we want to encourage.

For people in rural and provincial Australia, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax will mean the abolition of literally billions of dollars on transport and transport equipment. That will be a massive boost in the arm for rural Australia as a result of our introduction of a goods and services tax.

We will also reduce the effective price of fuel for the person on the land. One of the big costs of running any farm is the cost of fuel. Under us farmers will get a rebate for that proportion which is the goods and services tax.

We will tax foreign tourists. I reckon that is a fair thing. They come out here and use our facilities. Anywhere one goes in the world, foreign tourists make some contribution to the facilities that they use and enjoy. That is the sort of tax system that we will have.

We will abolish the tax on business inputs. There will be none of the mucking around of the Government in the March industry statement. The Government was looking there at $300m. The total level of intermediate tax business inputs in this country is $5 billion to $6 billion, yet the Government is preening itself for having moved $300m.

The Opposition is going to get rid of the lot, which will be tremendous for business. It will give it a real boost that in the end will mean jobs for people. It will be good for small business as well because it will pick up a cash flow benefit from the introduction of a goods and services tax. The Opposition is going to tax the cash economy. Five years ago the Treasurer himself said that if we really wanted to get into the cash economy, we had to have the guts to introduce a goods and services tax. Sure, it is a tax on spending, but the Opposition is saying, `Let us have a bit of a tax on spending so we can make way for big increases in what people earn, a big reduction in personal income tax.' That would put some incentive back into the tax system and Australians would have the motive and the incentive to drag the economy out of the recession the Treasurer said we had to have.

It is very instructive to go back to 1985. When the Opposition announced this decision originally it put out a booklet entitled, `Why you should vote for a consumption tax, by Paul Keating'. At the nub of the Treasurer's argument then was the personal income tax burden on the average Australian. Basically, the person today on average weekly earnings plus 30 per cent is paying the same marginal tax rate as he was back in 1985, which was the justification for the reform the Treasurer then proposed.

As part of this overall package the Opposition is going to abolish the capital gains tax. Why is it going to do that? We want to give people incentive to build up their assets, to build up their family wealth, and in turn to build up the productivity base of this country and give it a chance to get out of this recession.

There are a lot of other advantages: it is a self-policing system; it is efficient to collect; it shores up the income tax system. It will also mean that people will actually know the taxes they are paying. A lot of taxes paid today are hidden taxes. They are part of the Treasurer's trebling of taxes: the man who opposes a consumption tax has actually increased his de facto consumption tax take from $3 billion to nearly $11 billion. It is a huge, ramshackle mess, and a lot of people do not know they are paying it.

I can tell the Treasurer that by the next election all the people will know exactly what they are paying. As they go into the supermarkets they will understand that virtually half the things going over the scanners are subject to the existing wholesale sales tax. The Treasurer does not pay any tax on his designer suits or the caviar he has for morning tea, but the ordinary average Australian faces a huge tax burden. Look at all the things Australians pay tax on: there is a 20 per cent tax on Palmolive soap; a 30 per cent tax on alarm watches; a 20 per cent tax on Sunsilk; a 20 per cent tax on Kleenex tissues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Antiques are exempt, aren't they?

—Yes, antiques are exempt. Australians pay a 20 per cent tax on their cars and a 10 per cent tax on dishwashers. In fact, we can hardly move in this country without paying tax to the Treasurer. There is a 20 per cent tax at the end of the day on a Toohey's Draught 345 millilitre bottle; a 20 per cent tax on Rexona anti-deodorant; a 20 per cent tax on Johnson's baby powder; a 20 per cent tax on Ovaltine; a 10 per cent tax on choc-iced mints; a 20 per cent tax on Diet Coke; a 20 per cent tax on Lemon dishwashing liquid; a 20 per cent tax on toothpaste. Australians cannot get out of bed in the morning without paying tax to the Treasurer. They pay a 20 per cent tax on black and white portable television sets. Anybody watching this debate today is paying a 20 per cent tax on the television; if they are listening to it on the radio, they are paying a 30 per cent tax here and now to this man, who has the cheek to say that he opposes a consumption tax. In every school-bag, home, workplace and supermarket in this country Australians pay his wholesale sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: There is broad support for this change. It is not the be all and end all because there is no single solution to Australia's economic problems, but this reform of the tax system as part of a broader tax reform package, as part of a broader economic package, is one of the many things that will turn around this country's economic performance. What narks the Treasurer is that the trade union movement said no to him one night in a motel in Canberra, and the last thing the Treasurer wants to see is the Opposition go on to finish the job.

After the next election, the Opposition will introduce a goods and services tax; it will cut people's income tax; it will abolish the capital gains tax; it will have a decent compensation package; it will tax the cash economy; it will abolish tax on exports; and it will be good for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a coincidence that on the day following the day when the consumption tax was debated for one hour in the Liberal Party caucus meeting-where 20 speakers apparently spoke and where the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) urged them not to panic-we have this ham-fisted attempt by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) to promote a goods and services tax-a consumption tax. We saw the confidence which was striking the Opposition backbenchers as they heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition stumble his way through what was supposed to be a convincing expose of why a consumption tax should be introduced. We could see their minds ticking over, saying, `If this is the best we're going to get out there when it really counts, we're in trouble'. They are dead right; they will be in trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: The first claim the honourable member made was that this Government is a government which is `bloated'. This is a government with outlays at the levels of 1973, a government which has got outlays down to the levels of 20 years ago, with one of the smallest public sectors in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). And it is supposed to be bloated. He said that we are staring down the barrel of a recession. Apparently, he thinks he should make it worse by lifting taxation, thereby cutting disposable income, on a range of goods from food through to building materials-every item and service in the economy.

The Deputy Leader said that the Government does not have a wages policy. Average weekly earnings for the year came out a couple of weeks ago at 5.1 per cent, in the middle of a boom at 6.5 per cent when employers were seeking to pay 15 per cent wage increases. He made the totally nonsense statement that the Government does not have a wages policy. Then he talked about high interest rates, just as bill rates are nudging 10.5 per cent, which is not by any definition high but is by most definitions low. Then he said that I was the biggest taxing Treasurer and that Australia is a highly taxed country. The truth is that we are the second lowest taxed country in the OECD. We are 0.1, one decimal point, away from being the lowest taxed country in the OECD, which is Japan. We are on the bottom of the list.

The Deputy Leader claimed that the Government is bloated, when we are at 1973 outlays levels; we are staring down the barrel of a recession, but he wants to increase the tax; we do not have a wages policy, but we have wages running at 5 per cent of average weekly earnings; we have high interest rates, but interest rates are now down to 10.5 per cent; and we are a big taxing country, but the fact is we are the second lowest in the OECD. This is the sort of absolute arrant nonsense that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition trafficks in. How he can ever believe this sort of rubbish will be persuasive when the weight is on has me beat. Let him go on deceiving himself. He will not even ask me a question. Talk about having me beat; he is so afraid of me, that he will not even ask me a question. The only chance I get to reply to him is when I have to get up to respond to him on a matter of public importance. He will not even ask a question these days.

Then the Deputy Leader said that the consumption tax was an issue in New South Wales, and had I been in New South Wales I would have known that. He said that if I had been in his electorate I would know that it was an issue. Some time ago I received a letter from the Combined Pensioners Association in Bankstown in my electorate. It said:

After a great deal of discussion between our members I been asked to write to you regarding the introduction of a consumption tax. We feel it would place a great deal of hardship on the elderly, as well as everyone else, and we wish to state that we totally oppose a consumption tax being introduced.
Yours faithfully,
Mrs C. Koos,
Assistant Secretary,
Combined Pensioners Association,
Bankstown Branch.

That is what people in my electorate think of the Opposition's consumption tax. I notice that members of the Opposition are always getting back to the grassroots. We had the Leader of the Opposition saying, `I have to explain things a bit more and spend a bit more time developing techniques to get people at the grassroots to understand'. Back to the grassroots. He said that anyone in New South Wales would know that the consumption tax was an issue. Then the Leader of the Opposition said, `I had, I guess, only particular knowledge of one seat, which was Vaucluse, in which I spend all my time'. Perhaps that is the manicured grassroots, the hand-clipped grassroots.
A Government member-Out with the workers of Vaucluse.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right-out with the proletariat in Vaucluse! Out with the grassroots! Of course, the honourable member would not know what went on in New South Wales, because he got clobbered. He trundled his consumption tax out, and he got kicked to death; that is the long and short of it. As well as that, he got beaten around in his own party room.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member gets up in the House like a Toltoy-one of those silly things which is knocked over and which bounces back and finds its equilibrium again. He is up in the House today doing his Toltoy number: he can be booted down but-boing, boing, boing-he is back up again with his facile defence of a consumption tax.

Then he said that I would not know what people thought about it, and went on to say that there would be big reductions in personal tax rates. How-when, as has been conclusively demonstrated, even to just compensate taxpayers for the impact of a consumption tax there are no funds left to cut marginal rates of tax? The tax base is so much broader now than it was in 1985. In 1985 there was a thing called the fiscal yield or fiscal dividend. That has gone. Because the tax base is now so much broader, it costs so much more money to compensate for such a measure. That is why, if we were to fully compensate taxpayers and social security beneficiaries for a consumption tax, we would actually reduce the surplus. So this absolute nonsense about how a consumption tax would reduce income tax rates is unbelievable.

The Deputy Leader then went on to talk about designer suits bearing tax. The fact is that clothing does not bear tax in this country. However, the honourable member would have the same tax on designer suits as on bread. That is his policy. He would tax everything-bread, butter, all the basic essentials of life. He gets up here with these silly questions, these silly points, about whether certain biscuits or certain beverages are taxed. In this country, beverages are taxed, as is confectionery. Just as confectionery is taxed, products that can be regarded as confectionery are similarly taxed. They are not anomalies. It is to avoid an anomaly. Food is not taxed in that sense; that is, meat, vegetables, butter, bread-all the basic things-are untaxed. However, those opposite want to tax them-at the same rate as they would tax cars, suits, television sets, and everything else. They consider that this is the rate that should be put on basic things.

The honourable member then went on with this rubbish about things that are taxed in relation to babies. For the record, babies' items which are exempt under the current sales tax arrangements include: food and milk, clothes and footwear, cots, prams, strollers, pushers, bassinettes, cradles, booster seats, safety seats, restraining harnesses, drugs and medicine, medical services and baby blankets-all untaxed. But wait until everyone finds out that their phone bills, doctor's bills, dentist's bills, cab fares and haircuts all carry 15 or 20 per cent tax, the same amount as their bread, their can of baked beans, the bricks for their house and the gyprock for their ceilings. Wait until they are told that all those things carry 15 or 20 per cent tax.

The next time the Toltoy is dragged out to get banged around, it will not come up again. It will be squashed by the weight of public opinion. The back bench opposite know that. They have worked it out. Premier Greiner went in there with the approach: `We are the managers, we can manage-and, by the way, we will have a State income tax, we will have a consumption tax, and at the same time we will give you very high State taxes and charges, but we will manage your affairs for you.' The public said, `No, you won't, we'll manage you'-squash, splat, and a big squelch! Now we find the Liberals saying, `That wasn't much of a strategy. That is now out. Sorry-back to the drawing board; that's out'. The Liberal back bench said yesterday, `Listen, about this strategy'.

Meanwhile, back at the ranch, we have got our friend the professor-who I believe will be one of the Labor Party's great assets-as he starts running through all of these options about the radical program which he has. The consumption tax is just a modest part of this program before he gets onto such things as health vouchers, education vouchers, zero wage increases and a zero inflation rate. We will start to see some of these issues emerge, such as the abolition of the capital gains tax. There is a facile claim that people need the incentive to take their income free if it is in the form of capital, but to be taxed if it is in the form of income. What a nonsense. All the tax avoidance began in the first place by turning income into capital and taking it free.

TALK.START.PARA: —You opposed it.

—I used to oppose it. Does the honourable member know why? It is because I knew how the honourable member would misrepresent our honest claims. I did the clever thing, I put it off the agenda, flattened the Opposition and then put it in. The honourable member should understand that the Australian Labor Party fights on the rules as constructed by the New South Wales branch. That is what has got you rattled, mate. Our primary business is beating Liberals, at which we have become reasonable, national celebrities. It just galls those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Labor Party used to play into the Opposition's hands and we had the lovely John Carrick drawing a picture of `Reds under beds' and `Sampans from China' and all of the rest of it, the game was easy for those opposite. But when we decided to play it on a few of the rules which we have employed in New South Wales over 30 years, the Liberal Party just hit the wall with a loud bang. The result was that we decided not to talk about a capital gains tax. We would be honest with the public and say that we would not have one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be honest with the public and then introduce it.

—That is right, we did not introduce one in that Parliament. In the second Parliament we came back and said, `This is not an issue which we will expunge from our agenda. We will go to a tax summit and discuss it'. We did. We decided to implement it and we gave it all the precision, definition, clarity and fairness which it now has. That is how decent pieces of tax law are carried when they are explained and when they are equitable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition wants to remove it-it wants to untax. We have had a property boom and a stock boom over a period of five or six years and members of the Opposition want to take all of those untaxed gains and hand them back free retrospectively. Absolutely billions of dollars worth of tax would be handed back free, while, at the same time, they would tax bread, butter and meat at 20 per cent. Then they would not compensate pensioners; they would let the low income earners carry the burden, while somebody who has stored up capital profits in the tax system unrealised gets them handed back free of charge.

Surely those opposite do not think that our society will cop that kind of unfairness. Do they think the glib silly behaviour that we just saw a few minutes ago from the honourable member for Flinders is enough to put that sort of shabby inequity across? Of course, it will not be. That is why they will be nailed for the party they have always been-a sectional party interested in looking after only the income of the wealthy. That is all those opposite have ever been about, and that is all they are about now. Even though they say they are about a better economy and a better society, the truth of the matter is that they are just the same old crowd up to the same old things.

That is why no-one who has any conscience in public life could ever belong to their party. That is why, for us, it is not a political matter; it is a religious matter doing that lot. We want to see a decent country, not like our friend here from Welfare Avenue who forgot it all five minutes after he left Welfare Avenue. Five minutes after he left he ratted on his own people and joined the burghers up in Vaucluse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brian Burke is a man of principle.

—I know that I get right under the honourable member's skin and I will all the way to polling day. I will have you so tied up to the consumption tax, brother, that you will be sorry that you ever heard the term.
—Order! The Treasurer's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I have listened to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) make some most outlandish claims on a range of issues and use emotive rhetoric as his argument. But the real issue in this debate involves what I tried to do at Question Time today; that is, use some concrete examples to illustrate that every single day of our lives we pay sales tax on a huge range of everyday items: taxes ranging from 10 to 20 to 30 per cent. These taxes are hidden in the cost of the goods. They are taxes that the Treasurer does not want to talk about. I think it is about time that the hypocrisy of this Government was revealed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at a cross-section of these hidden taxes. Take, for example, a young couple-let us call them John and Mary-who are about to marry, set up their home and start a family. Before the big day, Mary's parents had sent out printed invitations to the wedding. They paid 20 per cent sales tax on the stationery. I guarantee that none of the guests who gave presents to the young couple had any idea that the paper and curling ribbon they had used to wrap their presents was taxed also at 20 per cent. The family friends who gave them, for example, a tapestry did not know that there was a hidden sales tax of 20 per cent on their purchase; nor on the wall clock, the cost of which included sales tax of 30 per cent. The bridal coronet and veil that Mary wore on her wedding day and her jewellery were taxed at 30 per cent and her make-up and perfume were taxed at 20 per cent. Her bouquet of silk flowers was also taxed at 20 per cent. The satin bows and ribbons on her bouquet and gown were taxed at 10 per cent.

John, of course, wants to look his best and play the part on this special day, too. His cufflinks, tie clip and collar pins are all taxed at 30 per cent. The dried flower in his lapel was taxed at 20 per cent, as was his leather belt and aftershave lotion. At the wedding reception the bride's father had to pay 30 per cent tax on the alcohol consumed, and the cost of the ice-cream wedding cake included 10 per cent tax.

John and Mary are saving to build their own home, so they decided to go on a camping and bicycling honeymoon. The car was taxed at 20 per cent and the bicycles strapped to the car were also taxed at 20 per cent, and the caravan hooked to the car was taxed at 30 per cent. Even the tourist map they had to buy was taxed at 20 per cent. John wanted to ensure their comfort and safety for their camping holiday, so he purchased car accessories, including fog lights, carpet mats and seat covers and paid 20 per cent sales tax. The fruit juice and savoury snacks that they kept in the car were taxed at 10 per cent.

After their honeymoon John and Mary set about the business of setting up their home. The first room they decided to furnish was the kitchen. They put out a `welcome' doormat and paid 20 per cent sales tax. The vinyl floor covering was taxed at 10 per cent. Their Hoover household appliances and the fridge, freezer and stove were all taxed at 10 per cent.

In trying to save money on joinery costs of built-in cupboards, they decided to buy free-standing cupboards and paid 10 per cent tax. The goods in these cupboards-Morning Fresh detergent, Mr Muscle oven cleaner, Handy Andy and even the pot scourer-were all taxed at 20 per cent. All the cooking utensils, pots and pans, toasters, china, place mats, electric jug, broom, vacuum cleaner and percolator, to name but a few, were taxed at 10 per cent. Even the tins of pet food they kept for their favourite pooch were taxed at 20 per cent.

The screen doors on their home were not included in the package deal from the builder. Ten per cent sales tax was paid on every screen door they added to their home. Of course, they needed a bed, sheets, blankets and towels-10 per cent sales tax was paid on all these items. Cushion covers, laundry bags and mattress covers were all taxed at 10 per cent.

To celebrate their wedding day, John and Mary, like many other young couples, purchased a photo album for their wedding photos. They paid 20 per cent sales tax on the album and they paid another 20 per cent sales tax on the frame they bought to display their wedding photo. In setting up the bathroom of their home, John and Mary, like all of us, would be horrified to learn the amount of sales tax they paid on everyday items. Toothpaste, toilet paper and tissues are all taxed at 20 per cent; cosmetics, 30 per cent; skin repair lotion, 20 per cent; soap and talcum powder, 20 per cent-as is hair spray, perfume, bath salts and deodorant. Safety and electric razors and hair dryers are all taxed at 20 per cent. Mr Deputy Speaker, you probably would not be aware that even the brass washer in the taps is taxed at 20 per cent.

John and Mary could not afford to curtain their home all at once-there is 10 per cent tax on continuous curtains and 10 per cent on labour-so they put up blinds, but they paid 10 per cent tax on the blinds as well. This young couple, like many others, could not afford to centrally heat their home, so they used personal heaters. They paid 20 per cent sales tax on those as well.

On every single item of furniture-lounge suite, occasional tables, lamp stand, bookcase-John and Mary paid 10 per cent tax. However, neither of them realised that when they saved their money to buy the colour television set, radio and compact disc player they would be paying 30 per cent tax on those items and 20 per cent tax on the discs and blank videos. These items would be found in nearly every Australian home.

When this young couple moved into their new home there was no garden established, so they set about landscaping it themselves. In order to do so, John had to buy some basic equipment. The shovel, rake and wheelbarrow were all taxed at 20 per cent. The plastic trellis and insecticide were also taxed at 20 per cent. He then bought a toolbox and paid 20 per cent sales tax on that, plus he paid 20 per cent on the tools to put in the toolbox. A ladder was 20 per cent and even paintbrushes cost him 20 per cent sales tax.

After both working hard all week to pay the mortgage on their home, they liked to relax at the weekend. John liked to play tennis. He paid 20 per cent sales tax on his racquet. Mary liked to play netball. She paid 20 per cent sales tax on the netball. But the real hobby that they pursued together was photography. They paid 30 per cent sales tax on their cameras, and for every accessory they bought for their cameras they also paid 30 per cent sales tax. Not only were the flashlights that they bought levied at 30 per cent, but also the bulbs used were taxed at 30 per cent.

They often needed a tripod to set up their shots and they paid 30 per cent sales tax on the tripod. The film they used was taxed at 30 per cent. They liked to develop their photographs themselves. The chemicals and photographic paper they needed to develop these photos cost them 20 per cent sales tax. When they did not develop their own photographs and had them processed and printed, that cost them 20 per cent also. If they wanted to mount any of their shots into a slide mount it cost them 20 per cent sales tax and the cost of the slide viewer was another 30 per cent sales tax. Any magnifier they needed to buy attracted 20 per cent sales tax.

Even all cleaning material needed for maintaining their cameras, whether cleaning brushes or cleaning cloth, attracted 10 per cent sales tax. Even the lens tissue cost 20 per cent sales tax. The entire lens cleaning kit was also taxed. If they wanted to frame any of their photos and hang them on the wall, the framing cost them 30 per cent, and the hooks that they used to hang the frame also cost 30 per cent sales tax.

This typical young couple that I have used as an example today is paying through the nose on all those items and hundreds more. Is it any wonder that this arbitrary form of taxation has escalated during the reign of this Government from an amount collected in 1983 of $4.9 billion to a massive $10.6 billion in 1990? Taxes are levied at these exorbitant rates but are concealed, so most people have absolutely no idea that they are paying, and they are paying these taxes every day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably no issue that we discuss in this place brings more into relief the fundamental philosophical differences that lie between the parties than does taxation. The honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) chose to trivialise the consumption tax issue, and I would like to take her up on one or two matters. I think it is important that we understand these things.
