First, all the items she mentioned-the refrigerator, the stove, the freezer, the Hoover, the blankets, the bed, the sheets, the towels-are taxed at 10 per cent at the moment. Those opposite are proposing 15 per cent. That needs to be understood.
—You don't know that.

—Then please tell us what the level is. It also needs to be understood that an item that costs $10 and has a wholesale sales tax component of 20 per cent has a tax component of $2. If the retail mark-up is 100 per cent, which is relatively standard, then with a 15 per cent consumption tax the consumer pays $3 tax on that item. Those opposite need to understand the mathematics. They need to understand, and people in the community need to understand, that there are a number of items that are taxed already within the system.

SPEECH.PARA: What those opposite are proposing is to tax milk, bread, cheese, fruit, vegetables and meat at 15 per cent. It is lovely to have items such as a motor car and a bicycle, but many people in the community are wondering how they are going to buy their milk, cheese, bread, fruit and vegetables. The fundamental difference is that those opposite are suggesting an increase in the tax impost on people who require these basic necessities. What will they do with the revenue? Hand it to people who do not need it, people who are wealthy.

Part of their whole tax structure, if they have one, and I doubt it, is that they will remove the capital gains tax. What they are saying-I have said this in the House before and it needs to be said again-is that if a person sells a property at any particular time or a parcel of shares held for some time and makes a real capital gain-not a nominal capital gain-of $30,000, then that goes untaxed in the year in which it is made.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for a speculative gain.
—No, I am sorry. I am saying when a real capital gain is made.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Atkinson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the case. If I hold the item for five years, what happens under the Opposition?
—You don't pay the tax.
—If I hold it for two years?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-You pay the tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying to those opposite quite simply is that for those people who are in between there is a tax reduction. The Opposition was proposing at the last election a situation where there was no tax for those people, retrospectively. It is clear that there should be a tax impost on someone who earns that amount of money. Opposition members are saying they will defray it over time. Why should people not be eligible for that tax liability? If I earn $30,000 in any year, whether it be income from my salary or rent or dividend or a capital gain, then I should have a tax liability. What the Opposition is proposing is the removal of that tax liability. It is indefensible that it should propose that.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of this item there are some arguments that can be made for a broad-based consumption tax. Many of us on this side of the House in 1985 took that position. The arguments are in respect of the savings benefits. Across the Tasman we have an example where there has not been an improvement in the savings position of New Zealand as a result of the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. We cannot draw a cause and effect relationship because of the fact that savings as a percentage have decreased in New Zealand, but what we can say is that since the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax there has been a decrease in savings in that country. If we look at savings as a percentage of gross domestic product, in 1986 the figure was 13 per cent; in 1987, it was 11 per cent; in 1988, it was 12.1 per cent. We do not have figures beyond that. What is very clear is that there was no increase in savings as a result of the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. So the argument falls down.

If the tax is to be neutral, by definition there will not be an increase in disposable income, so the savings argument falls through anyway. If it is not to be neutral then one has to argue against the case which says that this is a very unfair and inequitable tax. Opposition members do not want to take up that argument. If they take it up, they cannot say that there is going to be any savings benefit.

With the cash economy, I think there is a case for a marginal benefit as a result of the introduction of this tax. But we have to look at the way in which the cash economy occurs at the moment. Most of that economy occurs in personal and household services. In those areas, the person who pays the amount does not make a claim against taxation; that is why it is possible to avoid taxation. The person who pays for the service does not make a claim to the Australian Taxation Office and therefore it is possible for the service provider to avoid taxation by being paid in cash. That will not change, whether there is a consumption tax or not.

Equally, if those opposite argue that the system is unfair at the moment because of the wholesale sales tax system, they have to say that some of the people who spend the cash are at least paying some tax because of the wholesale sales tax system: that must be the case. If they introduce a broad-based consumption tax, they are saying that those people will have to pay at least some tax when they dispose of the income. I am saying to them that such people are already paying some. If the Opposition thinks that the benefit is going to be enormously significant then maybe it has a case, but there is no evidence anywhere to suggest that that is going to be the case. That is the argument the Opposition has to put. But that case has not been substantiated and cannot be substantiated.

Having argued the For case one has to look at the Against case, and that case is significant. If the Opposition's tax policy is going to be part of its total economic strategy, those opposite need to tell me how they are going to get a target of zero to 2 per cent inflation when they increase the consumer price index by about 5 per cent or whatever it is going to be, depending on the level of consumption tax they establish. It will be inflationary. The Opposition's inflation target will go out the window; It will not be able to deliver. One does not need to be top of the class, one does not need to be a professor of economics, to understand the connections that are made there. So if the Opposition's taxation policy is part of its total economic strategy, then it makes no sense. It is logically inconsistent to do what the Opposition is proposing.

Another problem-not the greatest problem, in my view-is what will happen in the future. We saw in the United Kingdom and in New Zealand that as soon as this tax was available governments took the easy option. Rather than expenditure restraint, rather than control over outlays, they took the easy option of increasing the consumption tax when they wanted more revenue. That is something we do not want in this country, and we have done everything possible to reduce outlays. I think the case is very clear. One has only to look at the Budget Papers to see the results.

The most important issue here is that of fairness. What Opposition members are talking about is taxing people on the necessities. They can stand up in this place and say, `Look at all these things that are taxed at the moment'. The things that are not taxed at the moment are important to people. When we get a haircut or go to the movies or go to the physiotherapist, when we buy bricks or gyprock for the house or pay a cab fare or go to the doctor, none of those things are taxed-but they will be taxed under the Opposition's policy.

More important than those are the fundamental things. This issue refers to the fundamental need for a consumption tax. I say to those opposite that the fundamental items that everybody needs are things such as milk, bread, cheese, fruit, vegetables and meat. What about the farmers and the freight on goods? All of these items are important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telephones.

—The telephone. We can go on and on. We have to consider the impact of these things, and the impact is going to be very significant. It is the fundamental issue of fairness that is most important in this debate. It is the issue that will destroy the Opposition politically, and should do so. Philosophically, whenever we talk about taxation in this place, we find one group that is determined to have a progressive system that is fair and simple and easy and provides for people's basic necessities; we find another group that takes the view that we should be looking after those at the top end of the scale and not taking into account the requirements people have to live a normal, decent life.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate concurring in the resolution of the House relating to an amendment of the resolution of appointment of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF MAJOR EXPLOSIVES STOREHOUSES, STAGE 1: MYAMBAT, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of Major Explosives Storehouses, Stage 1, at Myambat, New South Wales.

The works currently before the House are the first stage of the Army's major explosive storehouse project, or Mesh-P, planned for Myambat, near Denman, in New South Wales. The proposal will initiate the Army's need to store explosives ordnance in earth-covered explosives storehouses in accordance with North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) safety principles.

Existing facilities at Myambat were constructed during World War II and during the 1960s. The World War II buildings are no longer suitable for the secure storage of ammunition and present a continuing maintenance problem. The 1960s buildings are limited in their capacity to store some explosives under current United Nations-NATO regulations which were introduced after the construction of the buildings. As a result, these existing facilities are not sited to optimise the storage of the most hazardous nature of ammunition. This resulted in Myambat not being able to store significant quantities of Hazard Division 1.1 ammunition. Therefore, the basis of this proposed works is to provide more efficient and suitable storage for explosives, in accordance with the relevant guidelines and improved associated facilities.

The proposed works are located in three designated areas, and these are: the explosives storage area, the non-explosives area and the administration-camp area. Work will be undertaken in each of these three areas, including the construction of new explosives storehouses and upgrading of the access road and railway siding. A new returned produce store, depot store, support building and new accommodation for all ranks will be constructed.

Phase A will see the minor upgrading of the existing kitchen and mess facilities, pending their replacement in phase B. Associated engineering services will be undertaken, existing water and sewerage services will be upgraded and improved road works will also be included.

The project is expected to cost $34.4m at October 1990 prices but will be split into two phases. Phase A is estimated to cost $23.4m, and phase B $11m. It is planned to go to tender in June 1991, with completion of phase A taking about three years and phase B a further two years.

In its report, the Public Works Committee determined that a need exists to provide permanent ammunition storage and living, messing and working accommodation at Myambat, but the Committee raised three specific issues. Firstly, the Committee recommended that the Department of Defence study the costs and benefits of retaining Wallangarra as a second national wholesale ammunition depot and that the results of this study should be passed on to the Committee. The Department of Defence has agreed to carry out additional studies and submit the findings to the Committee.

Secondly, the Committee recommended that all projects referred to it be analysed to ensure the most efficient use of energy in the completed buildings, and that it receive copies of the results of these analyses. Australian Construction Services will make these arrangements on all future projects for which it has responsibility.

Thirdly, the Committee recommended that the Department of Defence continue to resolve outstanding issues with Rosemount Estates Pty Ltd. On this matter the Department of Defence has agreed to further examine the matters raised by Rosemount Estates Pty Ltd and to continue negotiations.
I would like to thank the Committee and its Chairman, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), for their support, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition certainly supports this motion, but there are a couple of things on which I would like to comment very briefly. Firstly, I notice from the reference to the Public Works Committee that we have now gone from phase 1 to phase A, which is an interesting development. I do not know whether that is of any significance.
—Military intelligence.

—I do not know whether it is up to the military. I note that there has been a slight slippage in the tender date in that when the reference went to the Public Works Committee it was hoped the tender would go out in April and it is now going to June. I would, however, point out to honourable members that as the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) is making a statement tomorrow-a fairly major statement on our defence for the next few years-I would have thought it may well have been prudent to wait until that statement had been made to see whether, in the light of that statement, it would still be appropriate to proceed with this development of the major explosives storehouses at Myambat in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF THE SINGLETON MILITARY AREA, STAGE 1, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of the Singleton Area, Stage 1, New South Wales.

This must be stage 1. Singleton Range, near the township of Singleton in New South Wales, was acquired in 1941 and a hutted camp was constructed during World War II. Some existing facilities have been around since the base was first established, whilst other temporary facilities were constructed in 1965.

From 1965 to 1973, these facilities were used by the 3rd Training Battalion to train national servicemen in recruit and infantry skills. With the ending of national service and the reorganisation of the Army, the infantry centre was relocated to Singleton from Ingleburn to occupy these vacated temporary facilities.

Service personnel at Singleton currently total 434. It is expected that the military strength will not vary significantly in the foreseeable future. Student numbers average 478. However, these numbers vary significantly throughout the training year, dependent upon course programming and availability of staff.

The proposed redevelopment of the base is aimed at upgrading existing facilities to provide sufficient and appropriate training, working and living accommodation for functions currently undertaken at the base and to clear the way to reorganise Singleton Range by relocating the existing, centralised range infrastructure of small arms ranges and buildings.

These works form stage 1 of the base redevelopment and will specifically involve the construction of new living accommodation for living-in staff and students, improved training efficiency of depot company working facilities and the construction of new range control facilities on Singleton Range.
The limit of cost estimated for these works is $29.3m at November 1990 prices. It is planned that the work will go to tender in 1991, with completion of construction expected in 1994.

In its report, the Public Works Committee determined that a need existed to replace existing inefficient training, working and living accommodation which does not meet current standards and that facilities at the Singleton Range need to be relocated to enable best usage of the range training area, but raised the following issues: the Committee recommended that all projects referred to it now as well as in the future be analysed to ensure the most efficient use of energy in the completed buildings, and that it receive copies of the results of these analyses. Australian Construction Services will make these arrangements on all future projects for which it has responsibility.
I would like to thank again the Committee and its Chairman, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), for their support, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a similar observation in respect of this motion. I note that both in the reference to the Public Works Committee and in the Minister's statement today reference is made that service personnel were to currently total 234 in strength and are not expected to vary significantly in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I make the observation that the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) will be making a major statement tomorrow, and I feel that it may have been more appropriate to have delayed this decision for at least a day or two, because we may have to consider the broader implications of base rationalisation in the context of whatever changes may be made in that statement tomorrow.

While not wishing to unnecessarily delay any decisions that have been taken, I would have thought that the Government may have been a little bit wiser to have waited until tomorrow so that, in the light of what is being said tomorrow, we will see whether this is still the most appropriate way to go.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Amendment of Resolution of Appointment

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Hand) agreed to:
(1) That the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations be amended to read:
(a) That a joint committee, to be known as the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, be appointed to inquire into and report upon:
(i) regulations made or proposed to be made under the Migration Act 1958;
(ii) all proposed changes to the Migration Act 1958 and any related acts; and
(iii) such other matters relating to the Migration Act 1958, regulations or reports as may be referred to it by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

(b) That the committee consist of 10 Members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.
(c) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(d) That the committee elect a Government member as its Chairman.

(e) That the committee elect a non-government Senator or Member of the House of Representatives to be the deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(f) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(g) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(h) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(i) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(j) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.
(k) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.

(l) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the public proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(m) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(n) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(o) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(p) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations appointed in the 35th Parliament.
(q) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by the effluxion of time.
(r) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.
Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990, the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990 and the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988. These Acts relate to the provision of superannuation benefits for Commonwealth sector employees.

The present Bill does not contain any major new initiatives for the reform of Commonwealth superannuation. Rather, the Bill proposes some changes to bring the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme into line with the occupational superannuation standards; proposes some changes to streamline the administration of the Acts and the schemes; removes some anomalies in the benefit provisions of the current legislation, thereby providing greater equity between members; and makes some drafting amendments to clarify the intention of the existing legislation. Most of the amendments are technical in nature. Most amendments relate to the 1976 Commonwealth scheme, the detail of which is set out in the legislation.

Generally speaking, the amount of the benefits is neither increased nor reduced. An exception to this statement would be a potential increase in the amount of the benefit payable when a pensioner or contributor under the 1976 scheme dies leaving behind more than one spouse. Currently, no additional benefit is payable where there is more than one eligible spouse-for example, where a person in a de facto relationship is also supporting a separated legal spouse. The Bill proposes that, where there is more than one eligible spouse, the benefit available for allocation will be calculated by treating the additional spouses as if they were dependent children, subject to the same overall maximum that currently applies to spouses' and children's benefits. Another exception would be amendments to remove the potential for some persons in certain circumstances to receive double benefits in respect of a period of service.

I mention that there is a small number of provisions that are to be backdated. This has been done to protect the members' interests. An example is the amendment to the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act that enables benefits to be paid directly to the 1990 Commonwealth scheme, rather than going through an industry fund and incurring that fund's charges.

I mention some changes to bring the Commonwealth schemes into line with the occupational superannuation standards. The Bill proposes the cessation of the cash-in-hand lump sum superannuation retrenchment benefit in the 1976 scheme from 1 July 2000. This amendment has been foreshadowed some time ago. Another amendment to the 1976 scheme resulting from the standards is to provide persons who change employment after reaching their minimum retiring age with the option of postponing receipt of their pension until genuine retirement from the work force. An appropriately adjusted pension would be payable at that time.

Increasingly Commonwealth authorities are setting up their own superannuation schemes. The authorities usually give their Commonwealth scheme members the option of joining their new scheme. Where employees join the authority scheme, they cease membership of the Commonwealth scheme. Sometimes they join the authority scheme without any benefit for their past membership of the Commonwealth scheme. In the past, they have either been paid a benefit from the Commonwealth scheme or preserved their benefits in the Commonwealth scheme.

The standards do not permit the payment of superannuation scheme benefits to members when there is no change of employment, even though membership of a scheme may have ceased. Therefore, the Bill provides that the 1976 and 1990 scheme members who join an authority scheme authorised by the Minister for Finance in such circumstances are not to receive a cash benefit, but are to receive preserved benefits in the Commonwealth scheme. The normal five-year qualification for preserved benefits in the 1976 scheme will be reduced to one year in such cases.

A number of amendments have been proposed to simplify and streamline administration and I give some examples. Functions relating to leave without pay and preservation have been transferred from the Minister for Finance to the Board of the 1976 scheme. The administration of the 1976 scheme is split between the Board and the Commissioner, but a transfer of functions to the Board is more consistent with the occupational superannuation standards. A proposed amendment to the Superannuation (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act will mean that notice of certain changes to the ministerial guidelines relating to superannuation schemes set up by Commonwealth authorities does not have to be served on employers not affected by the changes. Other proposed changes bring the administrative procedures under the 1976 and 1990 schemes into line.

Importantly, the Bill proposes to replicate in the Superannuation Act 1990 certain provisions in the Superannuation Act 1976. The provisions relate to the bulk transfers of members from the 1990 Commonwealth scheme to a scheme set up by a Commonwealth authority where that new scheme gives credit for past Commonwealth scheme membership. The amendments provide for an orderly transfer of moneys from the superannuation fund of the 1990 Commonwealth scheme to the authority scheme, so that neither transferring nor remaining members are disadvantaged. The provisions also permit payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to the authority scheme to help fund benefits in the authority scheme.

In my introduction, I mentioned that some amendments remove anomalies in the legislative provisions. One of the proposed amendments is backdated to 1986. The amendment corrects an anomaly in the provision relating to earnings by invalidity pensioners under the 1976 scheme. Currently, it is possible that a few invalidity pensioners can receive benefits based on one salary, but have the earnings test applied to a much lower salary. The amendment provides that the salary used for benefits is to be used for the earnings test.

Another amendment extends the powers of the Commissioner for Superannuation to apportion benefits on the death of a pensioner or contributor under the 1976 scheme. This power is limited to cases where there are dependants from more than one relationship. A discretion to apportion benefits in such cases is the only practical approach. It would be impossible to lay down hard and fast rules to cover every combination of domestic relationships that could exist or arise. This power would also help remove some of the anomalies that can arise under the current legislation. For instance, it is possible for a spouse of a deceased contributor to the 1976 scheme to disentitle children from an earlier relationship who were not living with the deceased contributor.

I now turn to a proposed amendment that could be important to those members of the 1976 scheme who are deciding whether to transfer to the 1990 Commonwealth scheme or stay in the 1976 scheme. A benefit classification certificate records the medical conditions existing at entry to the 1976 scheme. Should invalidity retirement or death be connected with one of these conditions, reduced benefits may be payable. In certain circumstances, the Commissioner may be required to issue certificates some time after a person has joined the scheme-for example, where medical reports are misplaced and not discovered until some time after entry. Such certificates, in effect, are issued retrospectively.

It would be inequitable for a member to make a decision to stay or transfer on the assumption that he or she does not have a certificate, only to find that a certificate is later issued retrospectively. The Bill proposes a moratorium on the retrospective issue of certificates so that existing members of the 1976 scheme can make their decision with some certainty. The moratorium is to be effective from 1 April 1991. The moratorium does not extend to cases where there has been non-disclosure of the relevant facts.

The Bill also provides that the 1976 scheme Board will have the responsibility for setting the rate at which deductions will be made to productivity benefits because of tax paid by the superannuation fund. Productivity contributions are now included in the assessable income of the fund and tax may be payable on that income. Although the nominal tax rate is 15 per cent, the rate of tax may vary from year to year as offsets are allowed against particular components of the fund's assessable income-for example, investment losses. Moreover, taxation payments are not made until after the end of the financial year to which the tax relates, but contributors may leave the scheme before the rate of tax is known.

To leave the decision on the tax treatment to the Board, which consists of equal numbers of persons appointed from the employer and member side and an independent chair, would be consistent with the occupational superannuation standards which place the day to day decisions of a scheme with the scheme trustees.

The Bill also includes amendments to the Superannuation Acts 1976 and 1990 to clarify the arrangements to apply with regard to membership of the Commonwealth schemes. These amendments will ensure the availability of the broadest possible options for persons resuming Commonwealth employment with rights under the 1976 scheme.

I now turn to the financial impact of the Bill. It is impossible to quantify the financial impact of the proposed amendments. Some amendments have the potential to increase costs, while others may reduce costs. What can be said with some certainty is that any financial impact is likely to be small. This follows from the fact that most of the amendments with financial impact would affect only a small number of persons.

Those amendments that would tend to increase costs include the moratorium on the issue of benefit classification certificates and the additional pension that may be payable where there is more than one eligible spouse. Savings may result from the removal of the possibility of double benefits. There may be small administrative savings and additional revenue may arise from some further employers being asked to pay a share of the costs of running the schemes.

The proposed amendment that appears to have the most potential for financial impact is the inclusion in the 1990 scheme of provisions to enable payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund when bulk transfers of members to a separate scheme set up by a Commonwealth authority occur. However, the amendment could not have any financial impact until an authority with staff in the 1990 scheme sets up its own scheme and permits 1990 scheme members to transfer to that scheme and the scheme is approved by the Minister for Finance. Even then, the authority would have made payments to Consolidated Revenue to fund its Commonwealth scheme benefits. It is only appropriate that when an authority provides its own superannuation benefits it gains access to an appropriate share of past moneys paid.

Finally, the payments from Consolidated Revenue under such an arrangement are spread out over a long period, possibly up to 40 years, thereby protecting the Budget from any significant short term outlays. I commend the Bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The commencement of the new national companies and securities scheme on 1 January this year marked the completion of the first phase of this Government's program for the reform of corporate regulation in Australia after the excesses of the 1980s.

We now have in place in Australia a single national regulatory structure that provides an effective framework in which the Government can begin the major task of redressing the damage done to our business reputation and the confidence of investors in our markets during the `decade of greed'.

The establishment of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) under the new national scheme, and the provision by the Government of substantially increased resources for corporate regulation and enforcement by comparison to that which was provided under the former cooperative scheme, is tangible evidence of this Government's determination to overcome these problems.

Equally as important as the need for the timely and effective enforcement of companies and securities laws is the need for those laws themselves to clearly establish the standards of behaviour that the community is entitled to expect of its corporate directors and managers and market participants.

At the time the legislative framework for the new national scheme was being prepared, I foreshadowed publicly that, following the establishment of the new scheme, the second phase of the Government's corporate reform program would commence. This second phase involves the reform of key areas of law that in the 1980s were shown to be deficient.

This Bill marks the first step in this second and most important phase of the reform of corporate regulation. The major amendments contained in this Bill will bring about the necessary and long overdue reforms to require companies to consolidate their accounts and those of the entities they control and to strengthen insider trading regulation.

The Bill also includes machinery amendments relating to the clarification and re-enforcement of the legislative framework of the new national scheme. The key law reforms contained in this Bill will complement the very considerable law enforcement effort of the ASC to raise the level of compliance with the law and bring about proper standards of corporate and market behaviour.

As I have mentioned, this Government is committed to an ongoing program of key law reform. This will involve a major review of the substantive companies and securities laws over the next few years. It is an ambitious program. It must be: for too long important law reform was not undertaken under the former cooperative scheme.

The development of laws which establish proper standards of corporate and market behaviour, that are capable of being enforced effectively and that will restore the confidence in the Australian market for both Australian and foreign investors, is essential to our future economic prosperity.

As part of this process, the Government expects later this year to bring forward two further Bills to amend the Corporations Law. The next Bill will deal with a number of important matters. In particular I mention proposals to facilitate shorter settlement periods for share transfers. This will enable the Australian Stock Exchange to improve its efficiency and increase the international competitiveness of our share market. Further amendments will include proposals arising from the review of the Australian company number (ACN) requirement and the clarification of certain aspects of the fundraising provisions. I expect this Bill to be released for public exposure in June this year and to be introduced for passage during the Budget sittings.

The following Bill, the third in the program for 1991, will contain major reforms in relation to loans to directors and related party transactions, the framework for corporate insolvency, directors' duties and the rights of shareholders. A full process of consultation with business and the community generally will be undertaken in relation to these proposed reforms. To this end I envisage that the third Bill will be released for public exposure during the Budget sittings.

Having outlined the Government's future program, I now turn to the specific reforms set out in the Bill I am introducing today.There have been widespread abuses of the existing company accounting and reporting requirements under which the true financial position of a group of companies has been able to be disguised by off-balance sheet reporting. This has enabled the financial statements of the company to be manipulated in such a way as to mislead investors and the market generally regarding the real level of liabilities or performance of a company or the group as a whole.

These abuses have been possible because company reporting requirements apply to companies and their subsidiaries. The definition of `subsidiary' has a rather technical meaning in the law which does not reach non-corporate entities. Further, group accounts have not been required to be consolidated, with the result that they can be very difficult to analyse.

One of the consequences of these practices has been a significant loss of investor confidence, both amongst Australian and overseas investors, in the reliability of corporate financial information in Australia.

To address these problems, the Bill provides for amendments to require that a company's directors must produce a single profit and loss account and balance sheet for all companies and other incorporated or unincorporated entities controlled by that company. The Bill will include a broad definition of control which focuses on the reality of control rather than technicalities.

In order to reinforce the requirement to comply with accounting standards, and to bring about greater consistency in accounts, a related amendment is to be made to the corporations law. Currently, the law provides that the directors need not ensure that financial statements are made out in accordance with an accounting standard if to do so would fail to give a true and fair view. This has provided the scope for some companies to use some dubious accounting treatments in reliance on the more general, and vaguer, true and fair test, rather than to comply with a relevant appropriate accounting standard.

Under the amendments, financial statements will have to both comply with the accounting standards and give a true and fair view. In this way the obligations under the law in relation to accounting standards will be brought into line with the obligations under the law applicable to the requirements of schedule 5 of the corporations regulations.

Insider trading has become a matter of increasing concern within the securities industry and amongst the wider community, contributing to the deterioration of public confidence in the securities market more generally.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-the Griffiths Committee report Fair Shares for All: Insider Trading in Australia-in November 1989, recommended significant legislative reform and administrative action in relation to the enforcement of the existing insider trading provisions. The Government's response to the report, tabled in Parliament on 11 October 1990, accepted the majority of the Committee's recommendations for legislative amendment, and in December 1990 draft legislation and an accompanying explanatory paper were released for public exposure.

The provisions in this Bill represent the outcome of the Government's consideration of that report in the light of public submissions on the exposure draft. The key elements of the new provisions are as follows. The definition of an `insider' will encompass corporations and partnerships as well as individuals. There will be no need for the prosecution to establish a connection between the person in possession of inside information and the company to which the information relates. Instead, any person, including a tippee, who is in possession of inside information will be prohibited from using it to trade in or subscribe for securities of the company.

A statutory definition of inside information is to be included, based on a `reasonable person' test. A person will be prohibited from trading in securities whilst knowingly in possession of information that is not generally available and where if it were generally available a reasonable person would expect it to have a material effect on the price or value of securities.

Information will be defined as being generally available where it is disclosed in a manner which would, or would be likely to, bring it to the attention of persons who commonly invest in securities of a kind whose price or value might be affected by the information and where a reasonable period of time for the dissemination of information has elapsed.

The offence will be extended to trading in prescribed interests, such as units of unit trusts, and other relevant securities. The definition of securities will be clarified to ensure that it includes prescribed interests, options and convertible securities.
Monetary penalties will be increased to:
- in the case of a natural person, $200,000, or 5 years imprisonment or both or
in the case of a body corporate, $1,000,000.

In addition, a body corporate that issues securities will be able to recover any profit accruing to the insider through dealing in those securities. Further, the ASC may bring an action in the name of, and for the benefit of, the body corporate.

The proposed provisions aim to strengthen the law relating to insider trading while at the same time not lessening the basic protections given to the accused under our criminal law. The provisions seek to ensure that legitimate business activity can continue.

Notwithstanding the abysmal failure of insider trading prosecutions, the onus of proof will remain on the prosecution in respect of all elements of the offence, including knowledge that the information is inside information. However, the operation of these provisions will be monitored to see whether they are effective in preventing insider trading and in restoring investor confidence in the securities markets. The futures insider trading provisions are also being reviewed with a view to adopting similar provisions to those proposed for securities in this Bill.

Other significant amendments to the Corporations Law are proposed to be made in the Bill. To more effectively administer the unit trust industry and other prescribed interest schemes, the ASC will be given additional powers to regulate compliance with trust deeds by managers and trustees. The Bill proposes an amendment which will treat a breach of a covenant of a trust deed as a contravention of the law. However, such a contravention will not amount to an offence. This will enable the ASC to investigate non-compliance with the provisions of deeds and to exercise its powers of civil enforcement where it discovers that such conduct has occurred.

A further proposed amendment will facilitate the maintenance of an accurate ASC information base relating to company officers. It will require the retiring directors, where more than half retire or resign at one time, to notify the ASC of that fact. This will overcome the substantial difficulties created for both the ASC and the former officers which presently arise when a company is in effect `sold', and the incoming directors do not lodge the appropriate forms as they are required to do under the law.

In accordance with the decision of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities at its meeting in February 1991, the Bill proposes a statutory moratorium in relation to the requirement for companies to include their Australian company number on their business documents and negotiable instruments. This amendment will further minimise any cost or possible confusion for the business community in relation to the ACN requirement. Companies and bodies will not have to comply with this requirement until after 31 December 1991. There is a corresponding proposed amendment in relation to the Australian registered body number.
The Bill also contains proposed amendments to the Corporations Act and the Australian Securities Commission Act to deal with various machinery, jurisdictional and transitional matters.

As the functions of the National Companies and Securities Commission have been assumed by the ASC, and the further existence of that body is redundant, the National Companies and Securities Commission Act is to be repealed and the NCSC abolished. The Bill provides for the winding up of the NCSC and the disposition of its assets, rights and liabilities, and will deal with related consequential and transitional matters.

Provision is to be made for the preparation of a final report and financial statements, and the vesting of former assets of the NCSC in the ASC or the Commonwealth, as appropriate. These machinery provisions deal with the legal ownership of NCSC assets and liabilities. They do not affect the joint commitments by the Commonwealth and the States under clause 31 of the heads of agreement to share financial responsibility for the liabilities of the NCSC, nor do they affect the obligation of the Commonwealth to account to the States for half the value of NCSC assets calculated in accordance with the heads of agreement.

Part 9 of the Corporations Act is to be amended to confer cross-vested jurisdiction under the Corporations Law on the Family Court of Australia and the Family Court of Western Australia. The amendments will restore to the family courts the jurisdiction those courts had in relation to matters arising under companies and securities legislation immediately prior to the commencement of the Corporations Law on 1 January 1991.

Prior to the introduction of the Corporations Law, the family courts had jurisdiction to deal with matters under the cooperative companies and securities legislation by virtue of the general scheme for the cross-vesting of jurisdiction for Australian courts. However, the Corporations Act excluded the general cross-vesting scheme and replaced it with a special regime for the vesting and cross-vesting of jurisdiction between the Federal Court and the State and Territory courts on Corporations Law matters under which all those courts have full coordinate jurisdiction under the Law.

In the present Bill, the approach has been taken to give the family courts the same status under the Corporations Law as they had under the general cross-vesting legislation in relation to jurisdiction under the former companies and securities codes. The family courts will be subject to requirements to transfer Corporations Law matters to other courts in accordance with provisions which follow closely the general jurisdiction of courts cross-vesting legislation. This will enable the family courts to deal with Corporations Law matters when they arise in an ancillary way in relation to family law proceedings. A family court will be able to transfer a case to any appropriate State supreme court or the Federal Court of Australia having jurisdiction under the Corporations Law.

I turn to the federalising approach of the legislation. Various amendments are proposed to the provisions of the Corporations Act to make more explicit and clarify, in relation to the national scheme laws applying in the Australian Capital Territory, the `federalisation' formula under the State application Acts. That legislative device is the mechanism by which the Commonwealth laws relating to the investigation and prosecution of offences, and the review of administrative decisions, apply to matters arising under the State corporations laws and ASC laws as if those laws were Commonwealth and not State laws.

I now refer to commencement and the application of certain changes. One further feature of the Bill that it is appropriate to mention concerns the amendments contained in the Bill that are proposed to commence from the date when the new national scheme began operation. The purpose of providing retrospective application for these amendments is to provide commercial certainty by avoiding the possibility of an unexpected and/or unnecessary loss of rights, or the imposition of additional liabilities, on the business community and other persons. This is particularly the case in respect of those provisions which are intended to put beyond doubt that no substantive change in the law occurred on 1 January 1991, such as the provisions in the Bill recognising the national effect of the registration of company charges under the corporations law of a jurisdiction.

Other amending provisions to commence on 1 January 1991, such as those amendments relating to the legislative machinery of the new national scheme, reflect corresponding provisions in the State application law and seek to reinforce the valid national operation of the new scheme, or make explicit what was intended to be implicit in the operation of the new national scheme laws when they came into force on 1 January 1991.
The remaining provisions of the Bill propose various technical and clarifying amendments and make minor drafting corrections to the Corporations Act, the Corporations Law and the ASC Act and ASC law.

In accordance with the arrangements under the heads of agreement relating to the new national scheme, members of the Ministerial Council for Corporations have been fully consulted on the Bill. Some members of the Ministerial Council made specific comments on the draft Bill. The Bill was also refined in the light of comments from the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and its various subcommittees, and the Australian Accounting Standards Board. Following consideration of the comments from the Council and others, a revised draft Bill was circulated to the members of the Council, which has now voted to approve the Bill in the form in which I am introducing it today.

The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill marks the first step under the new scheme on the path to restoring our international business reputation. The Bill will assist in establishing a corporate and market environment in which business and investors may carry out their essential activities and prosper with confidence in the stability and fairness of that environment.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Costello) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Foreign Judgments Bill will provide a framework for the enforcement of foreign civil judgments in Australia by a simple registration process. This Bill will replace existing State and Territory legislation governing registration and enforcement of foreign civil judgments in State and Territory supreme courts. It will also implement arrangements agreed with New Zealand as part of closer economic relations, and an agreement entered into with the United Kingdom last year.

Having Commonwealth legislation rather than separate State and Territory laws will provide greater efficiency in negotiating and implementing arrangements with other countries for enforcement of judgments and will permit better use of resources. The introduction of Commonwealth legislation has received general support from State and Territory Ministers. Consultative arrangements that have been developed between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories will continue. The Commonwealth will consult the States and Territories before entering into any arrangement with another country for enforcement of civil judgments.

At present foreign judgments can be enforced in Australia either by bringing an action at common law based on the judgment or by registering the judgment in a State or Territory supreme court or State or Territory law. Most State and Territory laws providing for enforcement of foreign judgments are substantially uniform, being based on the United Kingdom Foreign Judgments (Reciprocal Enforcement) Act 1933.

The uniform legislation is based on the principle of reciprocity. It provides for registration in the supreme court of a State or Territory of money judgments given by the superior court of a foreign country to which the legislation is applied. The legislation may be applied by instrument with respect to a foreign country where that foreign country gives substantial reciprocity of treatment to judgments of the relevant State or Territory supreme court.

A judgment is not registrable under the uniform legislation unless it is final and conclusive, is for a sum of money-other than a sum in respect of a revenue debt, fine or other penalty-and is enforceable by execution in the foreign country. Once registered, a judgment has the same force and effect for the purposes of execution as if the judgment had been originally given in the registering court.

The uniform legislation contains safeguards which enable registration of a judgment to be set aside in certain circumstances. These include an inappropriate assertion of jurisdiction by the foreign court, public policy and registration in contravention of the legislation.

The Bill is based on the legislative scheme reflected in the uniform State and Territory legislation. The problem with the current scheme has not been the legislation itself but rather the multiplication of effort involved in implementing and keeping arrangements up to date under the various State and Territory laws. Under the current scheme there is invariably a long delay in implementing arrangements in all jurisdictions.

Other problems that have arisen with a scheme based on State and Territory legislation are lack of uniformity in the arrangements made with other countries and lack of capacity adequately to deal with judgments of Australian Federal courts. Commonwealth legislation will facilitate negotiations, enable satisfactory arrangements to be made for judgments of all Australian superior courts, increase efficiency and reduce resource needs. At the same time, the State and Territory supreme courts will continue their role under the present law for enforcement of foreign judgments.

The Bill will widen the scope of the judgments enforceable under the current uniform scheme. In addition to providing for the enforcement of money judgments of foreign superior courts, the Bill provides for:

- enforcement of judgments of foreign inferior courts where the foreign country provides reciprocal treatment for Australian inferior court judgments-agreements on this have been reached with New Zealand and the United Kingdom;

- enforcement of foreign non-money judgments-for example, injunctions-also on the basis of reciprocity, by registration in the same manner as money judgments agreement on this has been reached with New Zealand, and

- enforcement of New Zealand revenue judgments, including penalty components of such judgments, in the same manner as civil money judgments. Revenue debts include income tax, capital gains tax and customs duty.

Considerations of justice, convenience, greater certainty in international transactions and comity between nations show the desirability of the scheme reflected in this Bill. With the increased mobility of persons and money across borders, the need for, and benefits of, an effective capacity to enable a judgment given in one country to be enforced against assets in another country are obvious.

The Bill is a good example of the efficiencies that can be achieved through Commonwealth, State and Territory cooperation in allocation of functions. While the Commonwealth legislation will replace State and Territory legislation, the States and Territories will still be directly involved through the consultative process on proposed arrangements with foreign countries and in the continued enforcement of foreign judgments in their courts.

It is not expected that this Bill will have a significant financial impact. The Bill will permit some resource savings for the Commonwealth, States and Territories by removing multiplication of effort involved in each State and Territory having to implement arrangements under its own law. In the short to medium term, savings at the Commonwealth level will be offset by the need to bring existing arrangements under the Commonwealth Act.
I commend the Bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill will amend several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The Bill contains amendments which are of a minor policy nature or which correct existing legislation. None of the amendments concerns major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues.
The proposed amendments will not have a significant financial impact. The proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977 are expected to lead to savings of the order of $15,000 per year.
The amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will permit the Trade Practices Commission to charge for material published by it. It is estimated this will result in revenue of $33,000 per annum.
The proposed amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I intend to confine my comments to the more noteworthy amendments.

A provision is to be inserted into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to provide that where a State or Territory law alters the name of a body or of an office, a reference in the Commonwealth Act to the body or office under the old name shall be construed as a reference to the body or office under the new name. The amendment will overcome difficulties which recently arose where the name of a State Crime Commission referred to in a Commonwealth Act was altered by State legislation.

An amendment will also be made to allow a board member of a statutory body to participate at board meetings by telephone, closed-circuit television and other modern electronic means of communication. Several Acts already make provision for this form of participation. The amendment will remove the need to enact such provisions in individual Acts, and overcome the problems which arise if members are precluded from participating in board meetings unless physically present.

The Bill will repeal provisions in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, requiring estimates of receipts and expenditure to be approved by the Attorney-General before moneys appropriated can be spent. These provisions are not necessary, as the Tribunal and courts operate under the Department of Finance ledger system, whereby the funds appropriated are controlled and released by the Department of Finance in accordance with validated claims submitted by each agency. Such claims must be in accordance with Finance regulations and directions. The issue of funds is also in accordance with the running cost splits separately identified in the Budget papers.

The amendment of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933 will clarify the current provision dealing with proceedings related to the winding-up of companies. The revised provisions will make it clear that the powers given to the Master and the Registrar in relation to winding-up proceedings may be exercised interchangeably between the Master and the Registrar.

The amendments to the ASIO Act will bring procedures for the handling of warrants relating to postal articles into conformity with the procedures for the handling of warrants relating to telecommunications and will place the Australian Capital Territory in the same position as the States and the Northern Territory so far as the performance by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation of its functions is concerned. The Bill also includes other amendments of a consequential nature.

The amendment to the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 will remove the provision for adding three extra days, known as `days of grace', to the maturity date of bills of exchange that are not payable on demand. This practice, which allows extra time for payment of a bill of exchange or promissory note, is out of step with general international practice. The proposed amendment will bring Australian law into line with similar provisions under United Kingdom and New Zealand law.

The amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977 have a twofold purpose: first, to abolish the National Legal Aid Representative Council; and second, to amend the Act to enable a further member to be appointed to the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee (NLAAC).

The Council, a 20-member body, was established administratively in September 1987, and given a statutory basis by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Amendment Act 1988. The Council is one of two advisory bodies established by the Act, the other being the NLAAC, a seven-member body of persons possessing particular expertise relevant to legal aid policies and programs. The Council was created to give representatives of major legal aid providers and consumers a forum for discussion and to enable them to provide advice to the responsible Minister.

Over the past three years, both bodies have been responsible for advising the Minister on legal aid matters. However, while the NLAAC meets about five times a year, the Council only meets once a year. The three occasions on which the Council has met have shown that it is not an effective body. Its continued operation, at a cost of approximately $20,000 per year, is an unjustified duplication of effort, given the role of the NLAAC. In July 1990, the NLAAC presented a detailed report on a two-year review it had conducted of legal aid programs and policies.

In its report, the NLAAC has recommended that there be regular national and international legal aid conferences at which a wide range of interested organisations, groups and individuals could discuss legal aid issues. Such conferences would provide a more effective forum for exchanging ideas and developing new policy proposals than the Council. The other amendment will expand the NLAAC to eight members, thereby broadening the relevant expertise and experience of its members.

The proposed amendments to the Statutory Declarations Act 1959 will simplify the processes for witnessing statutory declarations and provide a more accessible service to members of the public and business community by broadening the categories of persons able to witness statutory declarations. The amendments will also remove the requirement for the Attorney-General, or his delegate, to make appointments as a commissioner for declarations.

The amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will authorise the Trade Practices Commission to make charges and impose fees in certain areas of its activities, thereby improving the Commission's revenue base and providing a means for the utilisation of the user pays principle in relation to some of the Commission's activities. The amendments will authorise the Commission to make charges in relation to the supply of material it publishes in the course of carrying out its functions or exercising its powers.

The amendments will also enable regulations to be made permitting the Commission to make charges or impose fees in relation to a person's attendance at or participation in an activity arranged by or on behalf of the Commission, such as a seminar, the provision of prescribed discretionary services by the Commission, such as providing a speaker at conferences, and the making of an application for an authorisation or the giving of a notification to the Commission.

The proposed amendments to the Law Officers Act are to ensure that a pension will be payable to a Solicitor-General who has served in that office for at least seven years. The Act currently provides that a pension is only payable to a Solicitor-General who has served at least seven years and who has not been reappointed at the end of his or her term of office.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending five Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio. While none of the proposed amendments are highly significant, they are important for the functions of the portfolio. Details of the amendments follow.
Civil Aviation Act 1988

The Civil Aviation Act and regulations contain numerous offence provisions. There is, however, no clear articulation in the legislation of the powers of investigators when they are investigating alleged breaches of the legislation. One of the ramifications of this has been that recently prosecutions for alleged dangerous goods offences were unable to proceed because of doubt regarding the extent of the search and seizure powers of investigators.

Furthermore, in its second report on air safety regulation, the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force expressed concern that the powers of investigators were not clearly set out in the Act and recommended that the Act be amended accordingly. The amendments proposed to the Act will provide investigators with adequate and clearly defined powers. These will be subject to strict safeguards to protect the rights of individuals against whom the powers may be exercised. The safeguard provisions proposed by this Bill are in line with similar provisions found in other Commonwealth legislation.

Section 98 is also to be amended in order to clarify the power to make regulations dealing with the Authority's powers in respect of the preparation and approval of various technical documents specified in the Bill. The Bill also allows for the making of regulations via the adoption of instruments, or other documents, as in force at a particular time or from time to time.

A major effect of these amendments will be to ensure that a person selecting a particular system of aircraft maintenance will comply with subsequent changes to the system as determined by the aircraft manufacturer or the Authority to be necessary in the interests of safety.

The Act provides that, where assets are transferred from the Commonwealth to the Authority, the Minister administering the Act and the Minister for Finance may determine the value of assets as on the day of transfer and may determine an amount which is deemed by the Act to be a loan from the Commonwealth to the Authority. On 20 June 1988, a determination was purported to be made determining the value of assets intended to be transferred to the Authority on 1 July 1988, the date when the Authority began operations, and the loan in respect of those assets. The Attorney-General's Department subsequently advised that this determination is invalid, as a consequence of technical deficiencies in the procedures originally used to transfer the assets.

This Bill allows the Minister to now make a valid determination of the value of those assets at the values set in their determination of 20 June 1988. This action is intended merely to affirm the Authority's initial capital structure.
Federal Airports Corporations Act 1986

The Federal Airports Corporation Act is to be amended to make airport security a function of the Corporation. It will also be a function of the Corporation that it be responsible for the provision of aviation security safeguards at all Federal airports.

The Government has decided to rationalise responsibilities for airport security by making airport operators, including the Federal Airports Corporation, responsible for counter-terrorist presence, overall access control and security of the air side areas of airports.

In making this decision, the Government had two main objectives in mind. The first was to provide a single point of responsibility for security at each airport. The second was to ensure that there was a cost discipline on the provision of security measures, particularly in relation to counter-terrorist first response presence. I consider that the airport operator is in the best position to integrate the various security functions at the airport and to ensure cost effective delivery of security services. Airport operators will be required to ensure that the aviation security functions are performed to minimum standards being developed by the Department.

From 1 July 1991, the Corporation becomes subject to income tax and its taxation year will be 1 July to 30 June. Consequently, this Bill will change the Corporation's financial year from one ending 31 March to one ending 30 June. This amendment will preclude the Corporation from having two balance dates each year, one for statutory financial reporting purposes and one for taxation purposes, being just three months apart.

If the two years did not coincide, there would be significant inefficiencies and a substantial increase in costs to the Corporation owing to it having to duplicate many of its financial and administrative, accounting and reporting functions.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act enables Australia to adopt the three recent amendments to the Annex to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973. These amendments also substantially increase the level of penalties for pollution offences and will allow summonses to be served on the master, owner or agent of a ship when prosecuting such an offence.

As well as the above amendments, the Bill will make some minor amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990.

The amendment making the Federal Airports Corporation responsible for airport security at and in relation to Federal airports will save the Government $15.9m in each financial year. The other amendments will have no effect on Government revenue or expenditure. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Ms Fatin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin The Hon W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Bill relates to local government funding arrangements and has four main objectives. In brief it:
(a) gives effect to the Special Premiers Conference decision to untie local roads funds and pay these via general purpose grants;
(b) rectifies the unintended consequence for local government arising from the transfer of the debits tax base to the States and Territories from 1 January 1991;

(c) provides the Treasurer with a discretion to set general purpose assistance to local government at a level consistent with the underlying growth in general revenue assistance to the States and so avoid the need for frequent amendments to the Act; and
(d) provides for the movement in general purpose assistance to local government to be directly linked to the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and the Northern Territory.
The Bill also makes minor procedural and technical changes to the Act and deletes obsolete provisions.

In respect of local roads funds, the Special Premiers Conference of October 1990 decided that funds for local roads would be untied and paid to local governments, or to State governments where they are responsible for local roads, via general purpose grants. The decision indicated that funds would be paid at the same real level as at present.

Following consultation with local government and the States, the Government has agreed on the means by which it will give effect to the Special Premiers Conference decision. It will introduce interim arrangements for 1991-92 under which:

(a) local roads funds would be untied and the bulk of funds currently provided for local roads under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 will be provided as general purpose assistance under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986;

(b) an additional $296.1m in base funding for councils will be provided under the latter Act in the 1991-92 financial year. This figure represents an adjustment of 1990-91 funding levels for inflation, with funds to be further adjusted in 1991-92 and subsequent years in line with existing general purpose grants;

(c) existing State distributions will be maintained and intercouncil distributions will be in accordance with relevant principles currently operative under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988. Of the additional $296.1m in base funding, $272.7m relates to funds that will be provided to councils using a formula based on population and road length and $23.4m relates to funds that will be provided to councils on the basis of an assessment of special works needs; and
(d) in the case of moneys allocated to both local government and the States, the former local roads funds would be separately identified within general purpose assistance.

The interim arrangements will provide a period of stability while consultations proceed with local government and the States on the detailed arrangements to apply in 1992-93 and beyond. The Government expects to decide on the longer term arrangements by the end of 1991 following further consultations with local government and the States and following consideration of a wide range of options.

At this point I want to stress that the arrangements we are proposing in relation to local road funding have been developed with the full cooperation, assistance and advice of local government through the Australian Local Government Association. I place on record my appreciation of this local government contribution and note that it is a practical reflection of the aspirations for a more effective partnership between the Commonwealth and local government that both spheres of government are seeking to achieve.

The second major objective of the Bill is to adjust the funding formula in the Act to account for the transfer of the debits tax base to the States and Territories, with effect from 1 January 1991. The reduction in general revenue assistance to the States to compensate for the transfer of the debits tax base would have, under the current funding formula, the effect of reducing general purpose grants to local government. The Bill provides for the effect of the transfer to be disregarded in 1990-91 when calculating local government funding entitlements. In the absence of any remedial action, the consequential reduction in general purpose grant entitlements for local government would be $9.1m in 1990-91 and $21.8m in 1991-92.

The need for legislative changes to the Act to accommodate changes in funding arrangements with the States highlights the need for more flexible provisions to be included in the legislation to cover contingencies of this type. The current formula allows the Government no flexibility to vary the level of payments to local government as a result of changes to the basis on which payments to the States are made.

Such changes have been required in each of the previous two years-in 1988-89 because identified health grants were discontinued, and in 1989-90 because of the transfer of payments under the State Government Loan Council program to the Commonwealth-State housing agreement-and now a further change is necessary in respect of the debits tax base. The Special Premiers Conference reforms could also require further changes.

The third major objective of the Bill therefore is to provide the Treasurer with the discretion to set the level of general purpose assistance to local government at a level consistent with the underlying growth in general purpose payments to the States. This is the outcome intended under the existing funding formula. The Treasurer would be able to make adjustments to reflect changes in the classification of payments or in the distribution of expenditure responsibilities and revenue powers to the States.

The Treasurer would consult me in making the determination of the funding adjustment factor and the Bill requires that a copy of the determination is to be delivered to State and Northern Territory Treasurers, including an explanation of the use of any discretion. I would of course ensure that local government was also advised of any changes.

The fourth and final major objective of the Bill is to extend to local government the same commitment announced by the Treasurer at the June 1990 Premiers Conference that general revenue assistance to the States be maintained in real terms for the next three years, that is, 1991-92 to 1993-94.
