That commitment was conditional upon its not applying if Australia were to experience a major deterioration in its economic circumstances.

Existing arrangements under the Act effectively provide local government with close to a real terms guarantee with approximately 97 per cent of the funding formula linked to the level of general revenue assistance to the States. However, general purpose capital payments which currently comprise the balance of the funding formula have been nominally fixed in recent years.

The Bill therefore proposes that a new set of comparable grants for the States, including the Northern Territory, be defined for the purpose of calculating the factor by which local government grants change. The Bill makes provision for the movement in general purpose assistance to local government to be directly linked to the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and Northern Territory. This move would greatly simplify the funding arrangements with local government and provide greater certainty in funding for the next three years. The financial impact of the changes proposed in the Bill are relatively minor.

As already outlined, establishing a direct link between the movement in general purpose assistance to local government and the movement in general revenue assistance to the States and the Northern Territory will effectively provide local government with a real terms funding guarantee for the next three years. The estimated cost of this move is $0.9m in 1991-92 and $1.9m in 1992-93. This results primarily from the removal from the funding formula of the non-indexed general purpose capital assistance payments.

The changes that we are proposing will simplify the administration of the legislation and will provide benefits for local government. They reflect the importance which this Government attaches to the role of local government in our Federal system of government. They are another measure in a long list of measures which successive Hawke Governments have taken to strengthen the capacity and raise the status of local government. They are measures which, when combined with the very positive developments that are continuing to occur in local government in a wide range of areas, can only lead to a better local government in this country. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Bob Woods) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 April, on motion by Mr Griffiths:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Control Amendment Bill 1991 indicates that the Government is slowly and hesitatingly trying to make export establishments responsible for much of their own export inspection through quality assurance programs. This is supposed to ensure that the number of inspectors and, therefore, costs are reduced. While there has been some improvement in a small number of establishments, the change to self-regulation is stalled in bureaucratic and union red tape.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, it raises the question: to whom does the Government give consideration or have responsibility in this matter? As always with this Government it seems to be to unions and unionised labour and not to whom it should be; that is, the producers of the product that is exported or the exporters. The attempt to have the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) look at its own structure has failed. I commend the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths)-at the urging of the industry and the Opposition-for instigating an independent inquiry, but it has only been given a month to carry out its work.

This legislation will be supported by the Opposition because it recognises that with self-regulation there is a need for exporters to be penalised for making false statements. There is a need for significant penalties so that standards are maintained. The Bill makes it an offence for an inspector to receive goods or services from registered establishment owners; legalises the issue of health certificates-even in cases where the importing country does not insist on them-which are often used as an aid to trading to prove that the product meets the requirements for domestic consumption and to obtain payment; clarifies the ability to remit fees as well as collect; and removes references to monetary penalties for offences where terms of imprisonment are also provided, allowing the Crimes Act to be used to convert the term of imprisonment into a monetary penalty where the court so requires.

The Government has been forced to make it an offence for an inspector to receive goods or services from abattoirs, mainly because meat inspectors have been taking gall stones. One could say that this is particularly galling to the abattoir owners. It is claimed that these gall stones are an aphrodisiac which sell in Asia for about $2,000 a kilogram.

In the past, many proprietors have had to stand by and let inspectors take them because, if challenged, the inspectors would find some way of getting even with the abattoir owner. In those circumstances, it is not uncommon for meat to be condemned as a way of getting even.

This is just one of the reasons why there is a need for major restructuring of the export inspection service of AQIS, instead of just tinkering around the edges. In saying that, I am not, as such, being critical of AQIS. It has a dual role: the quarantine role and departmental responsibility for export inspection. For a variety of reasons and over a period of years, the present structure has developed. In some comments that I will make later, I will show just how bureaucratic that has become.

The decision by the Government in the last Budget, for its own budgetary reasons-I believe that this was not at the instigation of AQIS-to move to 100 per cent cost recovery on export inspection has changed all the rules of the game. Everybody who is in export inspection has to understand that. Of the total budget of AQIS-about $170m-export inspection is $132m, so it is the major cost factor. That $132m is being completely paid for by producers and exporters who have no accountability whatsoever of the efficiency of that expenditure of their money, particularly at a time of very low rural income. That has become a very urgent consideration. I acknowledge that the Minister, following the budgetary announcement to move to 100 per cent cost recovery from 1 January this year, did instigate that inquiry.

To my knowledge, it is the most expensive system in the world of export inspection in relation to who pays; that is, the producers and the exporters. In some countries-for many years this was the situation here-it was seen to be a public health responsibility, so the exporter paid nothing, or it is seen to be assistance to exporters and, therefore, there is still not a requirement for them to pay. New Zealand has implemented an accountable system. Its costs for fish inspection are now 72 per cent lower-that is, the cost to the exporter-than the fee charged in Australia. So the indication there is very clear. What has been a situation in the past cannot be allowed to continue in the future. If this Government does not do it properly, the coalition Government will.

The position has been generally adopted-and this goes back to beyond the 100 per cent cost recovery requirement-that there is a need for corpor- atisation, so that there is a better accoun- tability and efficiency in this service, but also a need still to maintain, generally, an on-line system. Presumably, in the creation of a more efficient and accountable system, there is a need to remove the unnecessary inspectors that are there now; and during the period of the 50 : 50 cost recovery situation that was introduced by the Labor government in an earlier period, that was the general coalition position; that is, to move for corporatisation and greater accountability.

But one has to ask the question now: is that still adequate? Is it enough? Will it provide the efficiency that is required? The answer, from the coalition point of view, is that the whole system needs changing and that more has to be done. This is the view not only of the Opposition but also of abattoir owners, the meat industry and, in particular, the Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, Dick Austen. He is the most senior man in the meat industry in Australia today. Of course, meat inspection is easily the most significant part of that $132m-I think it is about $100m for meat inspection out of the total of $132m for export inspection.

Mr Austen was quoted recently in some rural papers, following a meat and allied trades conference in Canberra, about changes to meat inspection. I want to quote from a letter he wrote to the Land newspaper following the reports of what he said in the paper. I am quoting exactly what he said, not what he was reported to have said. He said:
I have never advocated the abolition of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

My comments relating to meat inspection came at the end of a speech to industry people attending the Australian Meat Industry Convention. In the lead-up to my comments, I had praised the industry for its efforts in taking over management of quality assurance procedures through AUS-MEAT.

I expressed the view that health and hygiene matters, currently under the auspices of AQIS, could in time be managed by individual meat processing companies, monitored by AQIS. AUS-MEAT provides the model.
As Resources Minister Alan Griffiths correctly points out in the article-
that is, the article that was published in the Land-

Australia's overseas customers have strict demands on health and hygiene for which AQIS has responsibility. The negotiation of self-regulation monitored by AQIS would be a lengthy process with these customers.

My comments were intended to stimulate debate about the inevitable move to self-regulation within the meat industry. It is only self-regulation that will impose the necessary disciplines, cost-effectiveness and customer-orientation within the industry. In making these comments, it was not my purpose to criticise AQIS as an organisation or its employees.

The Australian meat and livestock industry has made substantial gains in recent years in raising its quality standards and practises. The industry is mature and responsible enough to extend its self-regulation to health and hygiene but this must be done in a realistic way, involving the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

No-one is saying that AQIS should be abolished. What is being said, in the words of Mr Austen, is that we do have to get rid of the unnecessary middle management and bureaucracy, and industry must itself have a basis of self-discipline and self-promotion.

The aim should be for abattoirs to employ their own quality control inspectors. They should be government qualified meat inspectors. Most of them would, or could, be the same people who are employed by AQIS today. In this way, we could have a very positive solution, because the inspectors themselves would be better paid, with a more responsible job as a company quality controller. Honourable members should recall that at the moment the abattoir pays $65,000, but inspectors receive only $30,000. The rest is lost to the bureaucracy. It would mean a reduction in cost to abattoirs and growers, resulting in a more competitive product to overseas markets. More exports would lead to more export income and a better Australian trade performance and lower overseas debt.

As I said earlier, this does not mean an end to government inspection, which is required for many of our markets, but it would result in the export inspection section of AQIS consisting of a small group of highly qualified inspectors who had the right and the responsibility to visit any abattoir at any time and randomly check both the abattoir and the work of the company inspectors. Naturally, there would be penalties and they would have to be very severe. That is the reason, as I have said earlier, that we are supporting this legislation.

That raises the question: where does this put corporatisation? I am worried that if we do go the corporatisation route that will be seen as an end in itself and will not really achieve the efficiency-and, for that matter, the better standard of quality control-that needs to be there. If we have that on the way then it is harder to move on to the ultimate, and it is better to move all of that inspection service, or as much as possible, out of the government sector and into the company self-regulation sector, and then leave with AQIS-with those check inspectors who would remain with AQIS-that ultimate responsibility for overseas market requirements.

Earlier I mentioned the problems of how bureaucratic the export inspection service has become. Now I want to detail that charge. Of 1,654 meat inspectors there are 1,249 who are directly engaged in inspection services at a particular time. That means that there are always 405 inspectors, 25 per cent, not engaged in inspection. Of this number, 87 inspectors are deemed to be surplus to requirements. A further 155 are estimated to become surplus within the next two years. On top of that there are 162 inspectors who provide relief for those on holidays, sick leave, et cetera. To cover the cost of these inspectors who do not earn a direct recovery from the industry, a figure of $14,200 is loaded on every working inspector.

I understand-and I am quite happy to be corrected on this, as I am on anything else I have said-that once an inspector becomes surplus, that does not mean to say that he is no longer on the payroll, because it can take a long time for him to be removed from the payroll. I would be interested to know how many actually have been removed from the payroll who have been declared surplus.

More recently, in answer to a question from my colleague, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), the Minister admitted to 63 meat inspectors still being stationed at towns where abattoirs have been closed, some for as long as five years. I put out a press release drawing attention to this. That received a certain amount of attention, particularly from some of those meat inspectors, who rang up and were pretty unhappy. I guess that is fair enough. They said some interesting things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us, Bruce.

—I will leave out the colourful parts. They said that all of these meat inspectors are fully employed and are working in other abattoirs as relief inspectors. To prove the point-and the Minister has given information-the travelling allowance for these inspectors amounted to $811,621 in 1989-90. For example, some Bendigo inspectors have told me that they have all had at least two interstate trips to places like Geraldton in Western Australia for 13 weeks at a time, and what a hardship that has been.

SPEECH.PARA: Why, when there is a surplus of so many inspectors and when 162 inspectors are provided for relief, did they have to go anywhere? If one assumes a modest average of $100 a day for each of these inspectors to cover travel and accommodation, it works out at 128 days of work per inspector for 1989-90. Surely, even in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service that is not full time. Even if it was full time, that begs the real question: why do we continue to employ these people when there are surplus inspectors and when I have been advised-I am quite happy to be corrected-that they refused relocation assistance when the abattoir closed down? Surely they cannot have it both ways. They cannot refuse relocation, and then continue on in employment and run up this additional cost for less than full time employment. It seems to me a bit like somebody who wants to be a beach inspector but wants to live at Wagga rather than along a beach. It cannot continue.

I get plenty of examples of the problems, and one has to acknowledge that in any system, whether it is an inspector or an abattoir owner, there are going to be people who are not pulling their weight or returning their income or being completely honest all the time. I shall detail three recent examples that have come to me. One from the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association came in a couple of days ago. It reports on the abattoir at Alice Springs, which slaughters 10,000 cattle a year. With the new meat inspection fee from next month, that will cost $67,154, or $6.70 per beast. As the average weight is 190 kilograms, that means a cost of 3 1/2c per kilogram of carcass weight.

In the letter to the Cattle Council, the Northern Territory Association says that two weeks ago the meat inspector told management early in the week he would be crook on Friday. He presumably had it worked out well in advance when he would be crook. An inspector was flown up to Alice Springs from Adelaide, stayed a few days, and then went home as the local inspector was not crook after all. All the cattlemen know they are paying for this. But it does not stop other costs or charges for each working inspector to cover the following: field administrative expenses at $5,432; training expenses, $101; superannuation at 15 per cent of base salary, $4,769; Comcare premiums at 54 per cent of base salary, $1,833; leave loading at 1.5 per cent of base salary, $477; regional office administrative expenses, $6,421; and central office administrative expenses, $5,065.

There are two other examples. In one Victorian abattoir there are more inspectors than are needed, so whenever the races are on one will always be at the races. In another abattoir in Victoria, where I was speaking to the people a few weeks ago, they have nine inspectors, three supervisors and a vet. They say they need about half that number. In fact, half that number is all who work at any time because they take it in turns to work half hour on and half hour off. The company still does some quality control at the end because it is jealous about maintaining its own quality standard, which it believes it can do better than the inspectors.

Australia's farmers and export companies deserve better than this. We have got to have a leaner, better and cheaper service. The best way to do that is to get the Government out of it as much as possible, get as much as possible back to the companies, and then leave AQIS to provide the necessary inspection for overseas requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Control Amendment Bill is relatively short and simple, encompassing two new offences, namely, misrepresentation to government officials by food exporters that export requirements-by that I mean health and safety, quality and description-have been met, and the receipt of goods and services from exporters by food inspectors. Both measures should reduce malpractice in the food exporting industry and thus be of assistance to an important source of export income.

SPEECH.PARA: Other provisions of the Bill allow for the widening of circumstances for providing health certificates for food and the power to cancel them if found to be incorrect. The remaining clauses are largely procedural in nature. While the context of the Bill does not represent a significant change in policy, I should like to take this opportunity to point out the potential and possible value of raw and processed foods from Australia and some of the challenges and difficulties facing growers and processors before maximum exports can become a reality.

I have had frequent meetings with the small crop growers in my electorate. The Bundaberg area, as I am sure you know, Madam Deputy Speaker, being a Queenslander too, is now the biggest horticultural centre in Australia. Only a few weeks ago the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) came to Hinkler to launch a logo for the integrated pest management program and to talk to local farmers and exporters about the difficulties they are facing.

The huge possibilities of export to Asia have often been canvassed and are certainly recognised by Government bodies such as Austrade. Growers in my electorate mainly export to New Zealand, where we have just had news of some possible relief in the export inspection charges by having the official protocol for the number of pieces inspected in a small consignment reduced from 600 to 450, but it is yet to be ratified by New Zealand. That is particularly important to the small growers because their cost is more difficult to spread across a small volume.

Fruit and vegetable growers in my electorate have experienced considerable hardship and a loss of export trade due to the presence of Atherigona orientalis eggs in cucurbits. During 1989 the New Zealand quarantine authorities initiated new production and inspection procedures covering the import of fruit fly host material from all countries into their country. This was in response to increasing numbers of interceptions of fruit fly larvae in consignments at their ports.

At various consultations in 1989 and 1990, industry was advised that this potentially serious pest is not present in New Zealand. Accordingly, industry was advised that the Bureau of Rural Resources has been requested by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to undertake a reappraisal of the quarantine significance of the pest. I do not believe it does offer a threat to New Zealand, but we have to convince those authorities first. I understand that the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has been involved in discussions with industry groups to have the necessary studies undertaken. The result of the research projects will then be a basis on which a formal approach could be made to New Zealand for atherigona to be reclassified as a non-quarantine pest if the results supported this.

The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC), established in 1988 to assist horticultural producers to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of horticultural production and post-harvest handling, has been of great assistance to growers in my area. I cannot speak highly enough of the work done by the HRDC. We have requested that New Zealand, when determining the official protocol, examine the climate requirements of atherigona. The fly is restricted to tropical climates and, although I am no expert in this field, I doubt that it could ever establish itself in New Zealand because of the difference in climate.

Japan and the United States are already importing fruit from countries where the fly is present without it being treated as an object of quarantine. This is one of the difficulties we often get into with our products where other countries use quarantine or health as a hidden tariff.

We have recently had the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy visit my electorate to listen to farmers' concerns about their export problems. Australia is internationally known as a fairly reliable supplier of such bulk items as sugar, wheat, milk products, and so on, but our international reputation and success in exporting citrus, tropical fruit and vegetables is much less impressive. For example, in the 29 March edition of Business Review Weekly it was claimed that direct access to overseas markets for Australian fruit and vegetables requires a different marketing expertise from those employed for bulk goods.

Australian rockmelons are too big for Asia. Our oranges are too small and tart, and much of the produce is packed in containers that are too big and lack stylish presentation. Networking and common brand names are too often lacking for export maximisation. Lack of understanding of what the foreign customer wants and using only surplus produce for export are the other criticisms. Processing of food for export provides the greatest earning potential, but here again Australia tends to be beaten to lucrative Asian and other markets. Only last week the growers in my electorate were praising the work done by the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. What we need to look at now is more marketing expertise and advice.

Australia's horticultural industry is unlikely to improve its export performance while it is left just to government to ensure that exporters comply with minimum export quality standards. The industry itself must take prime responsibility for its export performance.

While I have mainly talked about the horticultural industry, as it is relevant to my area, AQIS inspects meat and livestock, wool, grains, fruits, dairy products, fish and other rural products prior to export. The inspection of goods prior to export aims to ensure that only products of a sufficient standard are exported. This is essential to maintain Australia's reputation as an exporter and to prevent a decline in Australian export of rural products. The meat substitution affair in 1981, and more recently the discovery of chemicals in meat-particularly dieldrin-showed how vulnerable exports are to problems concerning quality.

This Bill introduces several amendments to the Export Control Act 1982, and the amendments include: a new offence of entering goods for export, where the conditions for export have not been complied with; a new offence of authorised officers receiving goods or services from owners of registered establishments; the broadening of power to issue health and fitness for human consumption certificates; clarifying that the regulation-making power to impose fees for the performance of services by authorised officers includes the power to remit fees; and removing the references to monetary penalties for offences where terms of imprisonment are also provided, thus allowing the Crimes Act 1914 to be operated to convert the term of imprisonment into a monetary penalty where the court so requires.

There is no doubt that what we need to do is ensure that we get the most effective and efficient cost delivery with regard to AQIS, because with full cost recovery it means that the exporters, the primary producers in particular, do have to bear that full cost. It is full cost recovery, not just the cost of wages of the inspectors themselves. I believe the Government is moving towards that end, but it is not easy, it is not simple, to work out the optimum number of inspectors.

What we have to be cautious and careful about is not to reduce the number of inspectors dramatically. We have moved a number of inspectors through the system; they have gone out of the system already. But if we reduce the number to less than the number we require, and we down-value our inspection service, the primary producers themselves are the losers.

So it is going to be difficult to get to that optimum level, and it is going to take a lot of hard work and goodwill. We have to do that, because the more efficient and effective we are, as I have said, the better it is for the primary producer. But it is difficult.

One of the other things I have found in my area regarding the times of inspections is this: while in the beef industry it may be that there are normal hours of, say, nine to five or whatever, or even seven to four that apply, they are not applicable in the fruit and vegetable industry because there is usually no fruit to inspect in the sheds of the primary producers before lunchtime. So the hour structure is totally different.

There is a lot of hard work to be done in consultation with the inspectors to try to work through those sort of mechanical problems that exist. There is also the matter of having inspectors who are able to relieve at the right time.

The other difficulty is with abattoirs that are open for only a few months of the year. Of course, in such a large nation, particularly in the Northern Territory and Western Australia, where there is only a few months of operation, it is costly to make sure that those inspectors are there. Nevertheless, I would be concerned if we moved out of the inspection service to allow private enterprise or the producers-particularly in the meat industry-to manage or oversee the inspection, because we have already paid the price once, in 1981, and the cost of that would again be very high. Because we are in such a competitive world market it is important that we produce the best quality and that we ensure there is no way that any of our competitors or any country can use health or quarantine as a hidden back door to use tariffs.

As I have said, it is important that we get to that optimum level in efficiency; but it is not easy, it is complex. However, we are moving that way and I believe, consequently, that this Bill helps in some way to improve the system, and therefore I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: -Everybody who has come to this House--
—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
—The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Food Authority Bill represents the Government's attempt to reform Australia's food regulatory system and it results from decisions made at the Prem-iers Conference and representations from most of the major food industry groups. There was unanimous agreement at the Premiers Conference in Brisbane last year to establish a National Food Authority (NFA) in an attempt to resolve some of the many problems that have occurred in this industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of those problems include: the lack of uniform national standards-they vary almost from State to State; the lack of clear objectives in the industry in terms of its regulation; the standards are often excessively complex and rigid; the time taken to vary standards or to introduce new standards is too long; there is a lack of consistency in many of the decisions; there is a lack of ability of the public in many areas to have any representations or to have their say upon the decisions that are made; there are regular complaints about administrative inefficiencies, and the end result is that the efficiency and the competitiveness of the export industry in Australia is severely restrained.

Those complaints have been echoed not only by the food industry but also by the Commonwealth's Business Regulation Review Unit in its report of 1988 and indeed by the Industries Assistance Commission, as it was then, in its 1989 report on the food processing and beverage industries.

Let me say that the Opposition supports the principle of the Bill. We have one reservation, in respect of which we will move an amendment, and there are some other minor points that we would like to make. I think the thrust of the Bill is very important to the food industry in Australia.

In many ways it is a landmark Bill inasmuch as the States have agreed to cede some of their powers to set their own standards to the Commonwealth via this National Food Authority, which will be a statutory authority. Although, of course, in principle we are unhappy about establishing yet another statutory authority, we do believe in this particular case that the end result for Australia-which is what counts-will be a good result.

It is the setting up of that statutory authority that provides us with the major reservation which we have, and it relates to the definition of chairperson of the Authority. There are limits upon the age of the person who can be appointed, and the age is limited to 65 years. It is clearly inappropriate for any individual to be excluded or included on the basis of age; it is simply discrimination. We have pointed this out in regard to a number of other Bills. Indeed on some occasions I understand the Government has been prepared to remove that particular requirement that age be a bar to becoming chairperson.

The amendment that we will move in committee, if we get a chance, will be that clause 41, page 22, subclause 5, lines 4 to 7 be omitted. In view of the fact that we are unlikely to get to the committee stage, I seek leave to incorporate this amendment in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The normal course that is followed with amendments to clauses if the guillotine operates is that after all other procedures are gone through, the amendments are incorporated by leave. So that would be done at a later stage.
—If we get time?
—No. It will be done after the guillotine.

—A number of organisations have raised problems in relation to the Bill, but by and large we are supportive of the Government's position. There have been some criticisms, for example, that the Bill concentrates on public health issues rather than food quality issues, and indeed it does. I have to say that it is probably a very sensible thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that the Government should be responsible for monitoring the industry's food quality beyond the level of ensuring that there is no damage to public health and that the food is basically sound and healthy. The actual promotion or otherwise of food quality should be entirely outside of government's responsibility. Also, government should not really involve itself further in consumer affairs, including advertising of the particular product.

The question of consumer protection has been raised. There seems to be a worry about whether there will be a lowering of standards of the current requirements for protection. It has been suggested that we should insert an addition making it a requirement of the Authority, in this regard, to also prevent fraud and deception in the promotion and sales of foodstuffs. By and large, that requirement is already covered by the Trade Practices Act, amongst others, and I think it would be superfluous to instruct the Authority to have regard to that particular matter.

Some complaints have been made about the definition of some of the limits covered. This relates in particular, for example, to the production of food and it mentions additives. There was a suggestion that there should be a number of other factors which are actually mentioned in the wording of the legislation. I have to say that I think again the Government has got it right-in the same way that a Bill of Rights, once it spells out the rights of an individual, almost by definition limits those rights. In the same way, to spell out here all the things which should be included would, of course, limit those others things which may not be on that particular list. So I am happy with the definition of the production of food and the mention about additives in particular, since there is a particular concern there.

We have lobbied for time limits in other Bills such as the Therapeutic Goods Bill, so I have no particular problem here about prescribing time limits for the procedures to be followed. Indeed, I think this can only be advantageous and, as I will point out in a minute, there are some examples of fairly lengthy periods which have been gone through in the past.

There are some concerns-and I think these are major concerns-that the standards might be lowered. There is a requirement that the standards be correlated with international standards. Hopefully, we will receive later from the responsible Minister an undertaking that in fact the standards will not be lowered but that the high standards for which we are famous in Australia will be maintained and that international standards will have to reach those standards. There obviously are some problems there with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and we will have to ensure that those are not con- travened. But I would be happy to hear from the Minister the principle that high standards for international foods will be maintained and that we will not allow international foods of substandard quality to enter the Australian market. I believe that will be the case, and I would be happy to have confirmation of that.

There is a suggestion that all hearings of the National Food Authority should be made public, and that seems to me to be completely impractical. I think there is a provision already for some of the deliberations of the Authority to be made public, and I think that does cover the issues.

One issue which has been raised, I think, does have some legs, that is, the question of appeal. Generally, the problem here is that any requirement or proviso for an appeal to be made is for an appeal by the applicant for a new or varied standard. It does not allow other interested parties to institute an appeal against a particular decision. It does seem to me that there is room here for both applicants and bodies, for example, submitting evidence as part of the ongoing process to be allowed to appeal against particular decisions. I think that would be an amendment which would certainly improve the Bill in terms of allowing appropriate appeals.

There is also a question about the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS). We discussed this briefly in relation to the previous Bill. There have been some suggestions that there are problems inasmuch as the NFA is separate from AQIS. It was suggested that those two bodies might be merged, but I would see this as a mistake. In fact, I see the NFA very much as a legislative body, a body which makes decisions about standards. It is not an enforcement body; it is not the policeman of the food industry and, indeed, should not be so. So again, I think, in those regards, the Government does have the matter fairly correct.

I am pleased to say that there are a number of issues which have been an ongoing problem for people in the food industry, and there are some amazing inconsistencies. For example, in terms of low fat products, `low fat spread', `low fat cheese', `low fat yoghurt' and `low fat cream' are all completely acceptable terms, but `low fat ice-cream' is an unacceptable term.

There is a record in regard to ice-cream of a submission being lodged in 1988 with the Australian Food Standards Committee (AFSC)-a decision could be made at an out of session meeting of the PHC. Ice-cream is a seasonal product. Any delay in approval, therefore, could result in deferral for another year and the cost to industry, of course, is enormous.

There is the issue of low fat table spreads. That has been on the agenda now for some four years. Low joule confectionery has been on the agenda for more than two years. Those are attempts to permit production of dietary aids to help consumers comply with good general medical advice that they should reduce sugar and fat intakes. That generally commendable aim is one which is not assisted by the complex and lengthy approval processes which often have to be undertaken.

The classic example in a related area is the question of NutraSweet and the artificial sweetener Aspartame, which has been a great breakthrough in artificial sweeteners inasmuch as it is virtually tasteless and is an excellent replacement for sugar and yet has no calories. But there have been enormous delays. For example, the approval process for six products of Aspartame took some three years. That cost the company, in this case NutraSweet, something like half a million dollars and the estimated forgone sales revenue across the board was something like $50m for this product alone.

There is another example, Isomalt, which was approved in November 1989 and it was circulated out of session in June 1990 for final endorsement. It took seven months to circulate the AFSC decision to the PHC, which was far too long-yet another example of the delays and inefficiencies in the system. There was a minor revision of the milk definition discussed in February 1988, but it was not until December 1989 that that decision was gazetted. It took four years before the amendments concerning the use of humectants in confectionery and revisions to claims such as `no sugar added' and `unsweetened' were finalised. They are all examples of the enormous bureaucracy which is associated with the current program.

The current program is that each State and Territory adopts standards which have been developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council and then agreed to unanimously at present by members of the National Food Standards Council. But the existing agreement does allow States and Territories to make unilateral variations to those standards and, accordingly, for example, New South Wales sells unpasteurised goat milk and South Australia allows the addition of a red colorant to its prawns to increase their commercial appeal. There is a whole range of exceptions to the standards similar to those which I have touched upon there.

There are other examples of delays. There are enormous ones. I could go on forever, but let me just touch upon a few more. The use of nisin in high moisture hot plate products was deemed urgent. It took, however, from November 1988 to December 1989 to have this resolved. The use of stannous chloride in canned asparagus was first submitted for a decision to the FST in October 1987 but was not gazetted until November 1989.

The gap between FST meetings and AFSC discussion adds extra time to the decision making process in a number of areas-for example, adding ferrous gluconate to olives. The first meeting was in June 1988; gazettal did not occur until 1989. There are five different bodies, at least, through which decisions have to proceed. They have to be referred; the bodies all meet sporadically throughout the year; there is no coordinated program to expedite the decisions. The end result is that there are substantial disincentives for firms to engage in innovative developments and, of course, lost opportunities are in the end borne by the Australian consumer and the Australian economy.

The new Bill provides for fast-tracking of an application where the NFA believes that it is appropriate; it defines particular durations which the process cannot exceed; and, by and large, I believe that the bureaucracy has the potential, so long as the NFA is run appropriately, to be vastly improved.

As I mentioned in the beginning, we support the legislation. We do have this one amendment which we will move in the Committee of the Whole if we get half a chance. But in the interests of the other speakers on this particular Bill, I will terminate my discussion and hopefully resume in committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -I was most interested in the comments made by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) in relation to the National Food Authority Bill. I note that some of the points he raised, which have also been brought to my attention by some of the consumer organisations, relate to such things as the role of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) and the standard for food production, and I will go to those issues later on.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that I believe this Authority will be well received by consumer organisations, by industry and by the general public because in many ways it is long overdue. Its history goes back officially, I suppose, to the 1989 report by the Industries Assistance Commission into the food processing and beverages industries.

I can recall some 10 or 12 years ago when the debate around the model food Act was still high on the agenda. There was discussion then that Australia needed a national food authority. There was strong argument in those days for a national, uniform approach when it came to standards, when it came to assessment and when it came to things like labelling and packaging. So it is not new. But I believe it will be most welcome. This is another initiative of this Government in the area of consumerism, in the areas of public safety and also public health, and I personally welcome it.
I referred a moment ago to the report by the Industries Assistance Commission. The report highlighted regulations and rules at the State levels, and I quote:
. . . that entailed significant compliance costs and delayed the introduction of new products, hampered innovation, disadvantaging both producers and consumers.

I think that is a fairly good summation of the situation. That does not mean to say that everything that has been happening at State levels has been causing those sorts of problems, but there have been those difficulties.

These matters were taken up originally by the Australian Health Ministers back in June 1990 and then at the October 1990 Premiers Conference, initiated again by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as he saw the need-and he was backed by relevant Ministers in this House-to ensure that we got rid of those inefficiencies, that we brought about uniformity and that we overcame the duplications. I know these things will be further discussed at the forthcoming Premiers Conference and later this year.

I am pleased this Bill is before the House because it will be of significant benefit to consumers. It is important that as a nation we develop food safety standards, and this will be that initiative. It is important that we do coordinate food recalls. We do not want seven-or eight-different systems, including the States and Territories. It is far better that we have a uniform national approach.

It is also important that we coordinate imported food assessment. We have some difficulties in this nation where one State could allow something to come into the country-as happens with so many non-consumable items where it can come into the country because it has been random tested-then, under section 92 of the Australian Constitution, it can go anywhere within the nation. That can create some dilemmas as we have seen with so many consumer products which have proved to be harmful to the Australian public. So here we will have coordination, and I believe that will be welcomed.

It will also promote uniformity between domestic and international food standards. I have a personal view on this. I state on the record that this is my view and not a Government view. I feel it is a pity that, whilst the National Food Authority will be setting the standards, we will still have the implementation, when it comes to rules applying to imported goods, carried out by AQIS. I am not trying to cast aspersions at our authority in this area, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, but I really believe if we are going to go all the way to uniformity and overcome the duplication then, at some point in time, which I hope is not too far away, there ought to be further consultation between Ministers and departments so that that role could even be given up by AQIS.

There will be people who argue against it. We saw a situation not long ago where we had some seaweed coming from Japan. There was some doubt at the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) level, yet AQIS still agreed that it be sold in Australia. Fortunately, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) in his wisdom passed the matter on to the scientific body within the National Health and Medical Research Council. The Council quickly said there were some problems. The matter then went to a higher body and there were some changes made. The risk was that AQIS had agreed to the product being dispersed throughout this country.

Fortunately it did not happen, but it could have happened. It raises some questions in my mind, when we are dealing with imported products, as to whether or not we ought to have two systems of control. I stress that it is my point of view, but it is a valid point of view, I believe, and I hope at some point we can either get greater cooperation and coordination or that we come under one authority. I see that the structure of the National Food Authority lends itself perfectly to the concept I am proposing here.

The NFA will achieve national food standards. I just hope, as the honourable member for Lowe said, that this is not a diminished standard outcome. There are concerns amongst consumers that once consumers are taken away from being involved at the decision-making level that that can happen. As honourable members will know, under this structure neither consumers nor, for that matter, industry will be involved at the top, senior levels. But the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has made sure, where decisions are being made on standards, that the proposals will go to community groups and obviously then to industry and consumers, so they will have an input. That will be the test, and time will tell.

We will also see some pluses. We will see the protection of the health and safety of the public because we will have this national approach. We will not have different standards at a State level; we will not have different standards at a Territory level. We will have a national approach. It will not matter where the product is made; Australians, regardless of where they might reside, will have that in-built protection. It will enable consumers to make informed choices because of the availability of information on food ingredients, and again I welcome this. I hope, however, it will be in simple English terms. It is all very well to say the information is there, but if it is in some scientific terminology it will mean nothing to the consumer. Again, we will have to see how this organisation addresses that need out there in the community where there are different intelligence levels and certainly people with different skills when it comes to understanding.

It is also clear that the NFA will promote fair trading practices. Whilst this is at the national level, and it is recommendatory because of the States' concurrence, one would hope we will see some fair rules and practice out there in the marketplace. It is a far cry, as I said, from the model food Act and the way it was brought about where it was gradually introduced State by State. Whilst it was a worthwhile initiative-and as you, Madam Deputy Speaker, as a Queenslander will know, it was Queensland which led the way and pioneered that, and I might add that it was under a conservative government and I give credit to the Minister at the time-it took years to get the measures across the nation, it took years to enact the provisions, and when it was all said and done the outcome was one of a lack of uniformity.

This new structure is national; it is all-encompassing and it is uniform. It is really a win for consumers. It is a far cry from a view advanced to me when I was on the Gold Coast some time ago-in fact the new Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson, was also speaking at that conference but he was not a member of parliament at that time. It was a Housing Industry Association conference. I sat around with people at that conference when they were advancing this view that they wanted to get rid of every rule and every regulation. They were true deregulators, admittedly from the extreme right of politics, but they saw no need for rules or standards. They pursued the line of caveat emptor-let the buyer beware. If someone bought something at risk, their attitude was that they would not go back and buy it again.

I think that is quite ridiculous as they were really pursuing the law of the jungle. They were pursuing the line that the consumer should carry all risks. That is simply not on, and the National Food Authority is a clear indication that this Government is not prepared to go down that track. It is prepared to get rid of the inefficiencies; it is prepared to set up a mechanism which will fast track the solving of problems; it is prepared to find a way of setting new standards, a way of letting industry get rid of the burdening costs because of the different State rules. It will create that national approach. It truly is an example of good cooperation between the States, the Territories and the Federal Government.

It is a model for community input, it will allow the consumers and industry to have a say and it will allow for a new approach to ensure that there is a high tech and scientific input, for it has the power to set up scientific advisory bodies in microbiology, food science, food analysis and, particularly, food law interpretation. It will remove the inefficiencies that have been caused by the various regulatory regimes that have existed in the different jurisdictions at the State and Federal level.

It is vital that we have these changes, because the food processing and beverage industry is important to our overall economy. These industries account for some 16 per cent of employment across the nation and about 18 per cent of value added in manufacturing. In 1987-88 there were almost 4,000 food processing and beverage establishments in the nation. Thus one sees how vital these changes are to the national economy.

I fully support the changes. I have a couple of concerns and I will be watching very closely to ensure that there is not a diminishing of the standards that we have already. I will be watching also to see that, where there are provisions that allow the authority to hold certain types of hearings and inquiries in camera, those provisions do not overrule the Freedom of Information Act, because I have some concerns about that. At a later stage I will be speaking in relation to the appeal provisions and, because I cannot go to the clauses at this point, I will be seeking some clarifications in relation to aspects of the standards with regard to food production.

Otherwise the legislation certainly is most welcome. It will promote the domestic uniformity our nation needs, it will promote trade and commerce in the food industry, it should maximise the important information that consumers demand and need in the area of food products, it should maximise food safety and hygiene activities and, to reiterate, it will provide a national approach for dealing with problems.

In closing, I suggest that the elements are in place. The test will now be how effectively the legislation works. This will no doubt depend on willingness and ability to enforce the standards. I am quite optimistic about the National Food Authority, as it proposes what is truly an innovative, central, consumer oriented national food standards regime for the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like other speakers in the debate on the National Food Authority Bill, welcome this initiative. It has been a long time coming. The difficulties that have been experienced by the Commonwealth Government in setting national food safety standards have a long history. It has been a history of competition between various State governments, each one having its own views as to what is appropriate for the citizens of its State.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has chosen the course of establishing a national food authority with powers to set safety standards. I think that that is critical and vital. The Authority will also have a capacity to set standards which may go beyond those health safety standards, and that could be of some concern. I would not like to think that there is a preconceived idea of what the food tastes and requirements of Australians may be. I would not want us to see any diminishing in the variety of foods available to Australians, particularly foods that are produced within this country. I would want to see an environment maintained where producers of new and exotic foods are encouraged and where obstacles are not put in the way of producers to prevent them from developing and marketing their products.

I would not want to see unnecessary legalistic and bureaucratic control of the development, say, of new cheeses. Australia has seen a blossoming of the Australian cheese producing industry over the last 10 or 15 years. Australia is now producing some excellent cheeses. In the process of making cheese, bacteria and food are mixed to produce an edible product. The processes have to be hygienic and well controlled. At the end of the day the product itself must be suitable for human consumption.

Producers of foods such as cheeses are constantly experimenting to produce new products and provide the Australian consumer with a larger variety. I want to see that continue and I want to see it encouraged. I hope that there is nothing in the administration and attitudes of the National Food Authority that would prevent the continuation of those processes. On the other hand, I would like to see that the conditions which it is eventually decided will apply to Australian pro- ducers and manufacturers of food products should be applied also at the front gate of the nation.

If it is a requirement that Australian food producers meet certain standards-not safety standards, but certain standards-then it is imperative that there should be amendments to the Customs Act to prevent foods entering at the front gate. It is no good allowing foods to enter, be tested by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service or State authorities and then ultimately be released on a limited basis even though they do not meet what are laid down as Australian standards.

The imperative must be for standards that are a prerequisite for Australian production to apply automatically, at the front gate of Customs, to every import. This is critical at a time when Australian manufacturers and producers are under attack from cheap imports, some of which do not meet Australian standards. I am not looking for restrictive process in this; I am just looking for fairness for Australian producers.

Around Australia, stories are legion of products coming in that do not meet Australian standards. One which I know of was mentioned in the House today. Apricots from Turkey, allowed to be brought into Australia, could not be sold because their quality was so low that the consumer would not touch them, but they could not be exported again because the quality was so low that it would not meet Australian standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peanuts from China are a notorious example.

—I know the peanut situation. It is raging in central Queensland. Central Queensland is full of peanut problems, if I can put it that way. The peanut producers of Queensland have been to see members of this Parliament and I understand the problems that the cooperatives and the producers have. They are serious problems. I believe the Government has to be consistent. In this instance we are not looking for the artificial approach adopted by Japan and some other countries which apply standards to foods and imports that they themselves are not required to keep. In some instances the Americans have applied that sort of approach to Australian beef and other products where their own domestic standards were not as high as those they demanded from importers. We are looking for an identical application of the rules within Australia and internationally.
—Why is Kerin dragging his feet on this?

—My friend the honourable member for Gippsland, who is at the table, asks why Kerin is dragging his feet on this. I would like to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) really swing onto the ear of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) or the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). That would really be a sight to see. It blows me away to think of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy swinging on John Button's ear.
—I am doing something about it, not just talking.
—He says he is doing something about it and not just talking.

—I am delighted to hear that. If there is an opportunity for the Minister to respond in this debate, which has been guillotined, perhaps he would enlighten us as to precisely what he is doing, because primary, secondary and tertiary producers, who at this stage all face competition from imports, need to know that the Government will make sure that there is a complete and even opportunity in Australia where those producers themselves comply with certain standards and where importers meet the same standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The critical point is that products that are intended to be imported must be blocked at the front gate by the Customs process. Those products should not be allowed entry, unlike the current situation, until somebody in a State government or in the Quarantine and Inspection Service says that they are suitable. Importers must know that they will not get past the Customs process in Australia, and that is that.

The National Food Authority will deal with the labelling of food and beverages products. Labelling is a critical factor if consumers are to be able to make informed decisions. I trust that, in considering labelling, proper consideration will be given to the clarity, size and type style of lettering on all containers.

A whole range of labelling is taking place in Australia, particularly for lines produced in bulk for the major food outlets, and I am uncertain about whether consumers are really being informed. It seems that terms such as `product of', `produced in' and `packed by' are used fairly loosely. Consumers need to know the country of origin of a product; if the product has been repacked, consumers need to know precisely what the contents are by weight, volume and analysis. So the labelling process needs to be looked at carefully. Even the description processes are very important. For instance, I do not know how consumers can make up their minds about fruit juices and their derivatives when the percentage requirements were not marked clearly and boldly on the label. The confusion between cordials, drinks and juices has worried consumers for a long time and is an area that needs attention.

The legislation now before the chamber is part of work being done by Commonwealth and State governments. The last Premiers Conference determined an agreed framework for regulatory reform which set out to determine areas where the achievement of national standards and regulations are essential to the efficient working of the Australian economy. The Premiers Conference also agreed that mutual recognition should apply everywhere in Australia. It also sought to have mutual recognition in areas where national standards are initially considered desirable. If uniform standards were unable to be achieved within a tightly prescribed time frame, other alternatives to develop the process further should apply. This is sensible decision-making.

I particularly commend to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and to the House the Greiner initiative on mutual recognition. I think that was an enlightened contribution to the discussion. Mutual recognition between the States, with each State recognising the others' standards and eventually contracting that large range of regulation and recognition down to what is nationally acceptable, I think is a wonderful starting point. It has puzzled me for years that it could not be instigated, and I am pleased that the Premiers Conference has started on it.

The Premiers, along with the Commonwealth, have stated that during the Premiers Conference to be held later this week they expect to deal with packaging and labelling; that is, the registration and labelling of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, industrial chemical labelling requirements, and pressure vessels, including design rules, registration, testing and compliance procedures. The Premiers Conference to be held in November 1991 will cover areas such as planning and building approvals and food inspection. That is another area in respect of food that is being dealt with by the Premiers. I just hope that the horrible mess that has been created in the meat inspection services throughout Australia can be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a farce.

—It is a farce. It is no wonder that the Minister responsible for this area in New South Wales is about to set up his own service and go back to where we were a couple of years ago. No-one but the Federal Minister and the people under his responsibility can be blamed.
—He says he is the farmers' friend.

—The farmers do not understand that a friendship far above and beyond theirs is the Minister's affiliation and empathy with the Australian trade union movement. While he can be mutually and amicably acquainted with them-the Minister is a nice man in that regard-beyond that he has a deep bond of loyalty and ideological linkage which binds him through all circumstances, thick or thin, strike or no strike, with the union movement. It is necessary that farmers understand that because they have been damaged by not understanding it in the past.
—He is dominated by the ACTU.
—I hear what the honourable member for Gippsland is saying. I have seen examples of that, but I hesitate to brand the Minister in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premiers Conference in November this year will look at food inspection. The food processes are in train and there will be a number of efforts to achieve some regulatory reforms in regard to a whole range of products. The Commonwealth and the Premiers Conference have laid down provisions of the agreement on standards and quality and have set time frames and other requirements to achieve uniformity. I do not like the word `uniformity'; what is meant is some uniformity of regulation for the benefit of consumers.

As this process moves ahead, I would bring to the attention of the House-because this is the first and vital instance-that not only are we looking at food products; medical products have also been properly dealt with, and a whole range of other products will be considered for national standards. Again, the principle must be that building materials, timber products, curtaining and other manufactured goods-all sorts of products produced in Australia-have State or Commonwealth standards regulations applying to them.

Australian manufacturers must abide by volumes of standards. It is crazy for us as a nation to go on requiring our manufacturers to apply these standards if importers are not required to meet the same standards. The process as it applies now with food products is this: unless someone lodges a complaint about something being of low or improper standard and an appropriate regulation is established debarring entry of that product, it is allowed to come in. I would like to see a blanket provision which says that everything not acceptable in Australia is not acceptable for import and will not even come through.

I conclude my remarks by saying that this legislation is a good first step. It needs to be not too bureaucratic and restrictive, but it must apply through the Customs process to imports as well as to Australian products. I would like to see the extension of that concept not just to the food and beverage area but also to the other areas that are being considered by the Commonwealth and the State Premiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the National Food Authority Bill 1991. There is no more basic necessity of life than the primary subject of this Bill. I refer, of course, to food, the quality of which, like the air we breathe and the water we drink, has a major influence on our general health and well-being. The ready availability of adequate supplies of high quality foods is something most Australians take for granted. Australian people are fortunate in that this country has never suffered from an acute shortage of food in recent memory, something which tragically is an all too frequent occurrence in some other countries. For these countries the primary concern of food authorities is sufficient food to provide basic sustenance to their often undernourished populations. They are rarely troubled with concerns over the nature of additives or colourings used in foodstuffs or about chemical contamination during food processing.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in most of those countries there are set standards of quality and safety which food must meet to be acceptable for human consumption. While food is a basic necessity of life, contaminated or unsafe food can also be the harbinger of disease or death. This fact has led historically to the formation of basic regulations controlling food. The level and nature of that regulation varies from country to country, although there is an increasing move towards international standardisation. In the more developed and affluent countries, basic food standards-items covering hygienic handling and distribution of food and the regulations designed to reduce the risk of contamination by disease or other substances-have been expanded to cover a wide variety of food-related issues.

In some of these countries, food standards also include items such as requirements for certain information to be included in food labelling and advertising, restrictions on the type and design of packaging, and licensing requirements for food producers and distributors. Australia is one of these countries and, as is commonly the case, these extra restrictions and regulations have developed over a long period and in an ad hoc manner. Often different government departments and regulatory bodies have responsibility for various issues relating to food standards. This Bill attempts to create a more coordinated approach.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, shortage of food has not been a problem for most Australians. If anything, and given that we have just had dinner, they have probably suffered from the reverse-an overabundance of modern high-tech foodstuffs full of mystery ingredients. Some of this food is absolutely saturated with various chemicals and other additives designed to enhance its flavour, colour or storage potential, or the residue of chemicals and other materials used during its production and processing. The transportation, packaging and presentation of foods for sale can also subject it to various forms of contamination, either natural-bacterial or fungal-or artificial, foreign objects or other pollutants. All of these things can pose serious health risks to the people consuming that food.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, while some additives or chemical residues may have no serious effect on the majority of people, they can often produce severe reactions in people who have certain medical conditions or a specific allergic reaction to that particular substance. So there is a need for consumers to know both that the food they are purchasing has been produced, packaged and distributed in a safe and hygienic manner and what ingredients and additives, if any, have been used in its production and/or preparation.

Today's consumers also have the reasonable expectation to know the details of the country of origin of the food they actually purchase. Over the years governments have developed laws to address these potential problems and hence protect public health and safety to enable consumers to make informed choices about the products they consume.

Each of the States and Territories has some form of legislation which establishes food standards, basic hygiene requirements to be met in the process and handling of foodstuffs, labelling and packaging requirements for food for human consumption, and a multitude of other matters associated with the production, distribution and consumption of food generally. Historically, State and local governments hold the primary constitutional authority in this area.

Apart from the contribution towards national food standards through the National Health and Medical Research Council and various heads of government agreements, the Federal Government's authority in this area is reasonably restricted with probably its major role being the setting of certain standards for export foodstuffs to meet international requirements and regulation of imports. Because of this individual State and territorial regulation of food and the food industry over the early years, there is a strong potential for a number of differing requirements and standards governing various aspects of the food industry to apply throughout Australia.

Despite the significant reforms in food regulation that have taken place to date through the efforts of the National Food Standards Council, there is still much more to be achieved in this area. Pres-ently all food sold in Australia is required to comply with the provisions of the food standards code. The code is developed under the auspices of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which produces a draft standard for consideration by the National Food Standards Council, which comprises the State and Territory Ministers responsible for food issues. If the standards are unanimously agreed to by the Council, each of the Ministers then goes back to his or her own government to have the standards ratified, after which they are then adopted into State and territorial legislation.

Each State prepares its own legislation. Often because of drafting variations between States there is difficulty in maintaining uniformity in the national standards throughout Australia. Further, the current agreement allows each State and Territory to make variations applicable in that State or Territory to the standards set under the code, without consultation with the Commonwealth or other States or territories, thereby opening the way for further differences in the standards.

The present system for determining the standards is itself extremely cumbersome and time consuming. Further, it provides little opportunity for general consumer input or review. Under the current arrangements, the product recall process is not as efficient as it could be, owing to the individual requirements of each State and Territory. These problems have been recognised for a considerable period and a great deal of discussion has taken place between the various Ministers responsible. As a result of early consideration of these matters, some changes were introduced in 1987. However, these have not produced any major improvements in the overall food standards process, and dissatisfaction with the system has continued.

After further consideration of ways to overcome these difficulties and establish a truly effective and efficient national food standards system, the Australian health Ministers conference agreed to the establishment of a National Food Authority to develop and review the domestic food standards for recommendation to the National Food Standards Council. The health Ministers conference also agreed to a recognition of a national food standards agreement to provide for true uniformity between the States of the agreed national food standards resulting from the work of the National Food Standards Council. This Bill is the result of that decision and the agreement on micro-economic reform arising out of the Special Premiers Conference on Commonwealth/State relations held in October last year.

The Bill provides for the establishment of the National Food Authority, clearly defines its objectives and sets out firm guidelines for the performance of its functions. It also puts in place provisions for consumer and industry involvement in the development of standards and fixes time frames which the Authority must meet in dealing with specific issues. Although the Authority's primary function will be to develop and review standards relating to food available in Australia, including both domestically produced and imported foods, and to make recommendations to the National Food Standards Council, its functions will cover a broad range of issues which have relevance to food.

I do not propose to continue at any great length. I am pleased to have the opportunity to rise this evening to support this Bill. The introduction of the National Food Authority Bill will clearly create an efficient food standards setting mechanism with objectives that recognise that there is a range of interests involved and that standards setting is not costless for consumers, business or regulatory authorities. The end result should be a more efficient and cost effective method of regulating the food industry and providing Australians with access to a continuing supply of high quality nutritious foods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to rise to speak to the National Food Authority Bill. I know that honourable members on both sides of the House have shown a great deal of goodwill in their desire to see that this Bill does as the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) proposes that it will do. Apart from the Opposition's wishing to move a minor amendment, which I am sure the Minister will support, it goes forward with, as I said, the goodwill of both sides of this House. I am very pleased to speak to it for that particular reason.

SPEECH.PARA: In doing so, I believe it is reasonable for the Opposition to look at the pitfalls in nationalising a food testing authority and the factors that the Minister ought to take into consideration in setting it up. I would like to bring to his attention some of the complaints from the industry groups about the current regulations. I think they are worth while looking at briefly so that we do not make those mistakes again.

The first and most obvious complaint is the lack of uniform national standards. One would hope that this Bill would certainly overcome that and that the States do not choose to opt out of it for some political reason or for short term political gain.

The next point that the industry groups were concerned about was the lack of clear objectives. Perhaps in that single statement lies the success or failure of this new Authority. If it does not have clear objectives and does not enunciate them properly to the industry, confusion will reign and we will end up in a bureaucratic nightmare that is centralised control. Excessively complex and rigid standards are what these groups have had to put up with at the moment. I think that is self-explanatory. Time taken to vary standards is far too long. The Minister should take on board that we should try to fast-track simple regulations or innovative ideas, and that industry should not be held up by this national Authority.

Lack of consistency in decisions is another concern expressed by the industry groups. Once again, we would hope that the National Food Authority would certainly overcome that problem. Inability of the public to make submissions or have their say was one of the other complaints put forward. Administrative inefficiencies and the reduced experience and competitiveness are an impediment to the development of the export industry.

The Minister would do well to consider how this Authority can help our export trade. Recently, on an overseas delegation to South East Asia, I could only be impressed by the understanding that the nations there have of the quality of Australian food. At one factory that I went to, which sourced its milk powder from both Australia and the European Economic Community, we were told that it had to mix the EEC powder with Australian powder to get it up to sufficient standard to send it to Bangladesh. That is certainly not only an indictment of the quality of the EEC product but shows that Australian food standards are extremely high and a credit to our exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should have taken our powder.

—I agree with the shadow Minister at the table-the factory should have taken all our produce, and I hope that it will in the near future. But this is certainly a great idea that can help our export industries and, no doubt, that will become part of the operation of the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points come to mind that we ought not lose sight of. This is a diverse society; some people would call it a multicultural society.
