This being so, some minority groups have imported foods that perhaps are not of the same health standard as Australian food. I would hate to see those people who bring in traditional food annexed out of the Australian market by this regulation. If they have for many years been used to eating the national foods of their homeland, one hopes that they will be permitted to continue to eat those foods in Australia. Perhaps on such food there could be adequate warning labels that preservatives and so on are not to our standards.

This is also a great opportunity for this nation to move to some sort of uniform labelling code, whereby labelling accepted in one State of Australia would be accepted right across Australia. When people pick up a product, they should know from where it has been sourced, whether it has been repackaged in Australia and what additives are in it. In our society today many people are allergic to certain foodstuffs and require the protection of adequate labelling so that they can make sure that their dietary intake is as they require.

I also point out to the Minister that, in the abattoir industry, we have a national testing standard which seems to have failed by standards that are applied in the country, but we also have a peculiar situation whereby the standard for export to the United States is different from that which applies internally in Australia. One hopes that such a thing does not occur with our other food industries, as that would impose an unfair impost on those industries. Those things sometimes sneak into our negotiations and we are forced to make such extraordinary decisions, whereby the regulations that apply to food that we export is different from those which apply to food consumed in Australia. These things are to be avoided. In the main, one has to look at the positive side of this. I very much take on board the points that the Minister made in his second reading speech:

The Bill requires the proposed National Food Authority to pursue set objectives in making recommendations for the introduction, removal or amendment of food standards. The Authority will be required to have regard in priority order to:
the need to protect public health and safety;
That is obvious and commendable, and we hope that it is done in such a way as not to impact on reasonable business standards. A further objective is:
the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable consumers to make informed choices;.

I have already covered that point, but I point out once again that people from an ethnic background may very well want to import food of a standard slightly different from that which we allow in relation to food produced in Australia, and I hope that those people are not unfairly treated under this Bill or under the bureaucracy. A further objective given is the promotion of fair trading in food. I think that is extremely desirable. This matter has already been covered by a previous speaker. Where food is coming into mainstream Australia, we must ensure that it is of a standard that we would expect in relation to food produced in Australia. The Bill further provides for:
the promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry and the promotion and consistency of standards which apply to the food in international trade.
All those things are great objectives, and I wish the Minister well in his deliberation and his administration of this Authority over the next couple of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Food Authority Bill deals with aspects of the reforms to the food regulation system in Australia announced after the special Premiers Conference on Commonwealth-State relations held in October 1990, namely, that uniform food standards would apply across the nation and be regulated by a National Food Authority. Such a reform has the potential to achieve substantial efficiencies in food production and distribution throughout Australia. It also has the potential to be a boon to consumers. I earnestly hope that that is what it proves to be. An outline of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: While public health and safety will remain the prime objective of food standards, in developing new standards, the Authority will also seek to promote, as far as possible, consistency between domestic and overseas food standards in recognition of the benefits to be gained from increased international harmonisation.

Although consistency between domestic and overseas food standards is an important factor in trade, I would caution the Minister and the new Authority on this point, in the context of the debate on food irradiation in 1988 and 1989. The catchcry of much of the food processing industry at that time concerned the need for consistency with international standards and our trading partners. Consideration of public health and safety and the rights of consumers appeared to be given only very cursory attention, in the face of that commercial imperative.

For those people who do not know, food irradiation is a process whereby food is bombarded by highly radioactive gamma rays in order to kill off the insects, bacteria and other micro-organisms which can cause food to spoil. Its advocates claim that the process can be used as a substitute for other methods of food preservation that are considered harmful by consumers. It is strongly supported by tropical fruit and vegetable exporters in the northern areas of Australia.

Importantly, however, whilst not causing food to become radioactive at the levels which would be used-hence, the complaint at the time about food that glows in the dark-food irradiation does involve the creation of radiolytic substances which could be harmful to humans and which could also cause a loss of nutritional value in the food. There was also a lot of concern about the possibility of cancer being caused by food irradiation. There was not a great deal of proof, though, because at the time Australian research was very thin on the ground.

In his second reading speech on this Bill, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) made particular mention of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations and the fact that those negotiations have identified the need to avoid food standards being used as barriers to trade. He went on to say that the GATT goal is to ensure that national standards should be based on the standards developed by the Codex Alimentarius Commission or, where they differ, they should do so on a scientifically justified basis. It is intended that the National Food Authority will contribute to the decision making on Codex standards and, in turn, harmonise our domestic food regulations, where appropriate, with Codex. It is maintained that this harmonisation would remove the potential for accusations that Australia was using food standards as a non-tariff trade barrier.

Unfortunately, this proposal does not inspire me with confidence, given my experience on the food irradiation front; and I would strongly urge the National Food Authority to be on its guard against back door attempts to tie it, and Australia, into the food irradiation web. Had it not been for the alertness and energy of one particular member of this Parliament, namely, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott), I believe that Australia would have been presented with food irradiation as a fait accompli, via the model food Act in 1987-88.

Many State governments were keen to establish food irradiation facilities within their borders-particularly Queensland-and national agreement would have been relatively easy to obtain. However, once alerted, consumer opposition was extremely strong, and it would be strong again if this proposal were resurrected in the context of the National Food Authority's deliberations over food standards.

Many honourable members of this House, me included, lodged petitions opposing the importation of equipment and fuel rods as well as calling for a ban on irradiated foodstuffs at the Federal level. Under the chairmanship of the then honourable member for La Trobe, Peter Milton-an excellent member, I might say-the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts conducted a substantive inquiry into the use of ionising radiation and reported to the Parliament on 9 March 1989. In his tabling speech, he said:

The report which is now before the House is the culmination of two years of extensive investigation which resulted in 4,000 pages of oral evidence and many thousands of pages of written submissions and technical documents. Hundreds of petitions from all over Australia containing thousands of signatures were also presented to the House by individual members, indicating strong consumer resistance to irradiated food. In essence, the report concluded that the processing of food irradiation should not be permitted in Australia until such time as adequate research studies have been undertaken which can conclusively show that irradiated food is safe for human consumption and that a routine commercial method of detection of irradiated food has been developed.

While consumers are concerned about additives, preservatives, colouring agents and pesticides in food, they are equally wary about the prospect of food irradiation. The Minister for Resources also said in his second reading speech that public confidence in the food supply is essential to protect the marketability of agricultural produce and processed foods. The clean, green image of our exports and domestic produce must not be undermined.

I am most supportive of the proposal to establish the National Food Authority. It is a very necessary development, which should ensure that uniform standards are achieved and that consumer rights are protected together with those of industry. I earnestly hope that its laudable aims and objectives are never perverted by those, both here and overseas, who would wish food irradiation on the Australian public. I very much commend the Minister for his work in obtaining agreement with the States for this legislation and commend the Bill to the House without hesitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Food Authority Bill when being introduced by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) was lauded as providing an opportunity for the Federal Parliament to debate the issues and contribute to the reforms in the field of food regulation. The Government has demonstrated its commitment to that debate by allowing just over an hour for the introduction of this important Bill and me just a few minutes during the State of Origin match to comment on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The food industry is a very important Australian industry amounting to some 20 per cent of our manufacturing industry. It has a turnover of around $30 billion and employs 173,000 people. There is often criticism about the $2 billion worth of food imports that come into this country and there is good reason to be critical of many of those imports. It also needs to be remembered that this country exports four times that amount in food exports-about $8.5 billion-around 20 per cent of our exports. Trade in food is very important to this country and so the development of standards is also a critical issue.

This Bill seeks to develop some degree of uniformity in standards by developing the National Food Authority, which has a degree of control in the area-with the States, which have the constitutional power in this area, agreeing to abide by those common standards. A number of areas have troubled the food producers in Australia over many years. One difficulty that has been referred to often is that there does not seem to be any commonality in the standards for imported foods compared to domestically produced products. I hope that this is one of the issues that will be addressed under these new arrangements.

Those who would prefer to be free traders rather than fair traders often forget about the need to maintain common and fair standards for all. In the past, I have often referred to the problems with the import of peanuts from China. That is an excellent example of double standards being adopted. Chinese peanuts have 50 times higher residue levels of BHC chemicals, organochlorin, than those produced anywhere else in the world.

Most countries in the world will not accept Chinese peanuts. The Americans do not; but Australia has been gladly receiving them over recent times. In fact, under some considerable pressure from the main importer, our National Health and Medical Research Council is moving to set a limit in Australia of 0.1 parts per million of BHC chemical residues. That is 50 times higher than is acceptable in most other places of the world. Even Argentina, which is hardly noted for its high health standards, has a level of 0.02 parts per million of BHC chemical residues and that is the kind of level that is being pursued by Australian farmers.

Consumers do not know when they buy a packet of peanuts whether they are getting Chinese peanuts which have high levels of chemical contamination. That is one of the other issues that needs to be addressed in the development of common standards. Even though many of these peanuts come from China, they will have on the packet `Product of Australia'. That is the kind of dishonesty in labelling that we need to look at closely in developing uniform standards.

One of my constituents wrote to me some time ago and suggested that in Australia there ought to be a clearly identified trademark placed on products that are 100 per cent Australian. It is true that at present one can pay a few dollars to have certain logos placed on one's products. But if there were a trademark readily available for 100 per cent Australian products, it would help the shoppers when moving through the supermarket to know when they are buying a genuinely Australian product.

We all know that the words `Product of Australia' on the label these days means nothing. Little or low local content can still have `Product of Australia' written on it. We have often heard the story about orange juice which is made of Brazilian concentrate, sometimes even in imported containers, yet because it contains Australian water it is labelled `Product of Australia'. I know of even worse instances where the contents of canned foods were imported-even the cans were imported and the labels were printed overseas, and yet they have `Product of Australia' on them. There are changes that need to be made in developing our new standards.

It is bad enough that we are importing these products from Brazil, Israel, Romania, Turkey and every other imagin- able country, but when the housewives and shoppers do not know that they are getting products from those countries and do not know that they are buying products that do not necessarily meet Australian health standards, then I think it really is time that we took a stand on these sorts of issues. My constituents' idea of having a readily identifiable trademark would be very helpful to people so that they are able to choose between what is Australian and what is not Australian.

I have heard other people say that all the Australian goods ought to be in one part of the supermarket, and all of the foreign goods should be quarantined in another area. That may not be so practical. Certainly, I think it is essential that consumers be aware of their opportunity to buy Australian and the contribution that they can make to the Australian economy by buying good Australian products. They are not only benefiting the Australian economy and Australian producers by taking such action; they are also guaranteeing that they are getting a high standard of product that meets the Australian health requirements.

Hopefully, this National Food Authority will move to ensure that the imported foodstuffs also meet these Australian requirements. In common with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), I think it is essential that we ensure that the Food Authority does not allow our standards in any way to be compromised and does not succumb to any sort of pressure from importers or others for lower standards to be adopted in this country just to accommodate imports, even if those imports do come from a big and powerful country such as China. We have a right in this country to demand the higher standards. Australian producers have been in the forefront in the world in producing the very best quality products, and we have a right to expect those standards from producers in other countries who want to exploit our markets as well.

I think we should say loudly to shoppers in this country that they ought to buy Australian in their own interests and in their country's interests. Perhaps this Bill will start to redress the problems of labelling and standards, which are in many ways contributing to the difficulties that our industry confronts at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before the House the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, an omnibus Bill designed to amend various Acts concerned with crime, law enforcement and criminal justice. The Bill was introduced last Thursday and, at the last minute, as has been seen by the change in the orders of the day, has come on for debate this evening. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill, although we have a number of concerns about some aspects of its drafting. Furthermore, during the committee stage I will be moving some amendments to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill contains a number of amendments of a very technical drafting nature, as well as many amendments involving policy matters. Before proceeding further I will give a brief overview of the major features of the Bill. Part 2 of the Bill amends the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 to extend the scope of the witness protection scheme and to streamline the procedures for management initiated retirements. Parts 3 and 7 of the Bill amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 respectively. Parts 4 and 9 amend the Crimes Act 1914 and the Passports Act 1938 respectively.

The amendments relate to the cancellation of or refusal to issue passports to persons charged with or convicted of serious offences. Parts 5 and 6 amend provisions of the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act 1989 and the Customs Act 1901 in response to recent court decisions. Part 8 amends the National Crime Authority Act 1984 so that the Australian Capital Territory Government can participate in the activities of the intergovernmental committee. Part 10 amends provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 in response to some recent court decisions. Finally, the schedule to the Bill makes further amendments to the Crimes Act relating to the Federal sentencing legislation which was introduced by the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1989, which came into force in July last year.

Before proceeding any further it may be appropriate that I give an outline of some of the queries or concerns that the coalition has with the Bill's drafting. I had intended doing so earlier rather than later so as to allow the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to give appropriate responses in order to clarify some of the queries I am raising. But the Attorney-General has not bothered to attend at this juncture and perhaps those who are necessarily required to advise him might from outside the strict precincts of this place take note of what is being said and I may get a literate response from the Attorney when he finally arrives, after listening to these remarks and reading the notes that I dare say his advisers will in all propriety pass on to him.

The first query relates to clause 5, which seeks to amend section 26e of the Australian Federal Police Act to provide that, where at the time of appointment a determination has not been made with respect to the compensation payable to a staff member upon early termination, the Commissioner may make such a determination later, at the time of the earlier termination.

It seems to me that questions relating to redundancy or termination payments should have been settled at the time of appointment. It is certainly the usual case in the private sector to settle at the time of appointment matters such as what you are going to pay someone in termination.

I acknowledge that the Government has made efforts to improve and modernise employment structures within the Australian Federal Police (AFP). I see that the Attorney has arrived-not that I would normally languish for his attention, but I have matters of great plausibility and moment to put to him, on which I would like his pearls of wisdom, based on the advice that will be tendered to him. The officials have taken note of part of the first query that I make in regard to determinations and compensation on the termination of a member of the AFP.

As the Attorney-General entered I was saying that I acknowledged that the Government has made efforts to improve and modernise employment structures within the Federal Police-efforts which have received our support. But it would seem that this provision that I have been discussing, about not settling compensation matters upon appointment and settling them later on, could be open to abuse. It may allow for what I might call retrospective golden handshakes. I do not blame him for the outcome of the matter-I do blame him in the end result because of the advice he gave me at the end of the day-but I would say that it might also give rise to the type of farcical situation that the Government experienced in attempting to bring the appointment of the Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, Mr Burke, to an end.

One day Mr Burke had resigned and his resignation had been accepted. The next day he had been dismissed. The day after, his appointment had been terminated. These are the sorts of things in which, if the manner in which the termination payment is to be paid is not settled correctly at the time of an appointment, there may be the sorts of cyclical confusions that occurred on the resignation, retirement, termination, dismissal, et cetera, in the case of His Excellency, the former Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See.

So it would seem appropriate that the amendment to section 26e be subject to a sunset clause. After the relevant date there should be a clear and unequivocal obligation on administrators to ensure that at the time of appointment questions relating to termination payments are settled once and for all.

The next query I have relates to clause 12a, which alters the protection given to cash dealers for incorrect reports of suspect transactions made pursuant to the provisions of section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988. Under the amendments, a cash dealer will be protected for conduct carried out in the `mistaken belief' that such action is required by section 16. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill states that this is necessary as it has always been intended that cash dealers acting in `good faith' be protected. However, it seems to me that the phrase `mistaken belief' is wider than the phrase `good faith', and the former is not restricted to the bona fides of the relevant cash dealer.

Perhaps the Attorney-General can explain to me why the amendment does not faithfully pursue the objective spelt out in the explanatory memorandum. Clause 12 (b) inserts into section 16 of the Act new subsections (5a) to (5c) to impose upon cash dealers an obligation of confidentiality, non-compliance with which will constitute a criminal offence. Under the amendments, an exception is provided whereby cash dealers may disclose such information either pursuant to the terms of the Act or to a court by way of evidence. However, I query why no provision has been made to allow cash dealers to make such disclosures to legal representatives in the preparation of court proceedings. At the moment, having regard to the existing terms of the Act, it is only the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, as opposed to cash dealers, which may make such disclosures to legal representatives.

Another query I have with the amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act relates to clause 14, which seeks to amend section 23 of the Act. The amendment will alter the obligations of cash dealers to keep records so that they may retain copies, including microfiche copies, rather than original records. Although this change is undoubtedly a sensible and practical one, problems may well arise relating to the application of the best evidence rule, which requires the production of original documents in court proceedings. No doubt the Attorney-General, in considering the drafting of the Bill, has addressed the issue. I would be pleased to hear his comments on how the amendment may impact upon the best evidence rule.

I turn now to consider some of the policy issues involved in the Bill-a Bill, I might say to the Attorney-General, that I indicated we will not be opposing but to which we will be moving some amendments. In this respect I wish to make some comments about the National Crime Authority Act, the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act. Part 8 of the Bill amends the National Crime Authority Act so that the Australian Capital Territory Government can participate in the activities of the intergovernmental committee. Among other things, the intergovernmental committee is responsible for making special references to the Authority.

Honourable members will be aware that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority is at the moment conducting a comprehensive review of the Authority's activities. There have been reports that the intergovernmental committee, which is chaired by the Attorney-General, has put a submission before the parliamentary Committee suggesting that the parliamentary Committee be abolished and replaced by a judicial arbiter. I assume those reports are accurate and, if not, I am sure the Attorney-General will be able to clarify the matter.

I wish to make it clear that the coalition would not entertain a suggestion that the parliamentary Committee be abolished. The workings of the parliamentary Committee are essential to ensuring that the Authority is made accountable to Parliament. This is particularly important given the wide powers that the National Crime Authority has and given that its operations are conducted, obviously and necessarily, in a secretive manner. Much of the criticism over past years that has been directed to the Authority has centred around a supposed lack of accountability. The abolition of the parliamentary Committee could only support such criticism.

It would also seem to me that the proposal to abolish the parliamentary Committee may well be contrary to the views of the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Phillips. If I am wrong, perhaps I can be advised. I say this because of proposals that Mr Justice Phillips himself put forward in February of this year which are designed to make the National Crime Authority's operations more open and accountable. Central to the proposals put by him was the need to address the relationship between the Authority and the parliamentary Committee. At the time His Honour announced these proposals I issued a public statement saying that they had much merit and deserved careful and detailed consideration. Subsequent to that, by letter dated 21 February I made a submission to the parliamentary Committee expressing my in-principle support for those proposals.

I will briefly outline the proposals that have been made by Mr Justice Phillips and my response to them. First, His Honour suggested that section 51 of the Act-that is, the secrecy provisions-be amended so that they have no application to the workings of the Committee. I wholeheartedly agree with this proposition and, for the record, I note that in November last year the coalition resolved to support a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Noel Crichton-Browne which was designed to make it clear that the secrecy provisions had no application to the Committee's proceedings.

Secondly, His Honour has suggested that the words `a matter relating to' appearing in subparagraph 55 (2) (a) of the Act be deleted. Again, I agree that an amendment of this type is desirable as those words are problematical and leave room for doubt as to whether any given line of inquiry taken by the Committee may contravene the provisions of subparagraph 55 (2) (a). Clearly, the intent of these provisions is to ensure that the Committee does not investigate criminal activities. In my view, that intention would not be affected by the removal of those words.

The third proposal put forward by His Honour is that Committee members be subject to a statutory obligation of confidentiality. Again, I wholeheartedly agree with this suggestion. In my view it is simply a matter of commonsense that, should the Authority be more open in its dealings with the Committee, members of the Authority must have confidence that the Committee will treat sensitive information, particularly concerning any ongoing operations of the National Crime Authority, in an appropriate manner.

The fourth proposal His Honour makes concerns the publication of sensitive material in the reports of the Committee. In particular, His Honour has suggested that should a dispute arise between the Committee and the Authority regarding publication such dispute should be referred to a judicial arbiter for determination. I think it is desirable that a non-litigious means of dispute resolution be available. I have some reservations as to whether determinations of an arbiter should be final and conclusive in all respects. In my view, it may be prudent to consider whether provisions should be made for rights of appeal, particularly, for example, appeals on questions of law.

As I said in my submission to the Committee, this is a matter the Committee would be in the best position to consider in the light of its working relationship with the Authority. I also indicated that the proposal to refer disputes regarding publication to a judicial arbiter may have a wider application for other sorts of disputes between the Authority and the Committee.

Finally, Mr Justice Phillips has suggested that the provisions of subsection 25 (5) of the Act be amended so that the Authority may have discretion to conduct publicly hearings or parts thereof. Again, I agree with such an approach as it is often said that open hearings are an essential element for the fostering of public confidence in the administration of the criminal justice system. My only reservation is that it would be desirable to ensure that rights of review for aggrieved individuals are provided for in the event that a dispute arises as to the appropriateness of conducting an open hearing.

If there are said to be problems in the working relationship between the Authority and the parliamentary Committee, the way to resolve such problems would be, as Mr Justice Phillips has intimated, by addressing the legislation that governs the operations of both the Committee and the Authority. The suggestion by the Government and the intergovernmental committee to simply abolish the parliamentary Committee will have drastic ramifications for the accountability of the Authority and its operations. It is a suggestion that ought to be rejected.

I turn now to consider some aspects of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. On previous occasions I have made clear to the Attorney-General some of the concerns the coalition has with certain aspects of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. Let there be no doubt that the coalition is supportive of the objective of the Act, namely, tracing the money trail left behind by organised crime. In essence, the coalition is concerned with the overreach of some of the provisions in the Act. The approach the Act adopts is analogous to driftnet fishing; whilst it may catch some major criminal elements, it may do untold damage to many innocent individuals.

I have spoken about the breadth of identification documents, I have written letters to papers, I have made speeches as to how absurd the situation has become at this juncture, where not even a birth certificate on its own appears sufficient to open a bank account and where a passport is not sufficient in itself. All these things will be attended to by us in government.

When I last spoke in the House I did call on the Attorney-General to consider reviewing the provisions of the Cash Transaction Reports Act together with the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act. It is interesting to note that in his second reading speech on the Bill that we are discussing tonight, the Attorney-General indicated that the Cash Transaction Reports Act would be `reviewed in 1993 in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs'.
I am not entirely sure that those comments accurately reflect the recommendations made by the Senate Committee. If I could quote from paragraph 8.26 of the Committee's report:

In the case of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill, if it is enacted, the Committee considers three years from its commencement to be a suitable period of time. It considers that by that time the scheme proposed by the Bill will be fully operative, costs of implementation would have levelled out, and there would be some indication of the Bill's success or otherwise.

The various schemes in the Act have been subject to staggered commencement dates. For example, the requirements relating to false-name accounts commenced on 1 July 1988; the requirements to report suspect transactions commenced on 1 January 1990; and the requirements to report significant cash transactions came into place on 1 July 1990.

On my reading of the recommendation by the Senate Committee, it would not seem open to conclude that the review is to be conducted in 1993. According to the Senate Committee, the review should be conducted within three years of the commencement of the Act.

If there are any doubts about the matter, it may be appropriate that the Committee conduct its review in stages. For instance, it could immediately commence a review of the requirements of the Act relating to false-name accounts, and thereafter could proceed to consider the suspect transaction reporting obligations and so forth. This is a matter which my colleagues in another place may take up. We on this side of the House are certainly of the view that the earlier the review takes place, the better.

I turn now to the Proceeds of Crime Act. As with the Cash Transaction Reports Act, the coalition has some concerns about the overreach of certain aspects of the Proceeds of Crime Act. Again, the coalition is supportive of the objectives of both pieces of legislation, namely, the pursuit of the money trail, firstly, by tracing the proceeds of crime and, secondly, by removing the incentive for crime by confiscating the ill-gotten gains of illegal activity.
In February this year I raised with the Attorney-General the case of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and the Director of Public Prosecutions against Kunz. Is the Attorney-General with me on this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I remember it very well.
—There was a decision by Mr Justice Vincent of the Supreme Court that the Attorney-General will recall.
—Everything you say is taken note of.

—It might be taken note of; but I want to see more adequate responses. Perhaps tonight I will get them, and I thank the Attorney-General. I say that with all the love, affection, respect and regard I have for him.
—Are you still ill?
—Yes, heavily, at the moment. I will get back onto those tablets recommended by the Attorney-General, and I will make a better speech next time.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and the Director of Public Prosecutions against Kunz, Mr Justice Vincent of the Supreme Court of Victoria handed down his decision on 3 July 1990. In that case the Supreme Court was concerned with the purposes for which retraining orders should be used under the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act. The decision of Mr Justice Vincent raised a fundamental issue of policy: namely, whether the powers under the Act should be used in such a manner as to satisfy taxation liabilities or to otherwise ensure compliance with taxation laws. Mr Justice Vincent clearly rejected this proposition.

When I raised this case with the Attorney-General he indicated that it would be inappropriate to comment upon the policy issue, given that at that time His Honour's decision was subject to an appeal. I understand now that the appeal proceedings have been discontinued. In the light of that, I would ask the Attorney-General to advise the House as to what policy the Government has on this matter and whether it condones attempts to use the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act for taxation purposes.

I will conclude my comments by repeating my request to the Attorney-General that the Government give consideration to reviewing, at the earliest pos- sible time, the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act. It is a question of striking a balance, if you will, between effective law enforcement and individual liberty. I acknowledge that this is not always easy to do. However, it is an objective that clearly we are obliged to pursue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) raised various matters. Leaving aside for a moment the policy matters, and leaving aside the somewhat tenuous connection between the proposed amendment-that is, the first one he spoke to, section 26e of the Australian Federal Police Act - and the case of the determination of the commission of Ambassador Burke, which I will deal with in a moment, I think that probably the best thing to do is to run through the various matters that he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the first matter raised by the honourable member for Kooyong-that is, section 26e-as has been indicated in the second reading speech and as I confirm tonight, the amendment to section 26e of the Australian Federal Police Act will improve the management-initiated retirement scheme. I must say I did not understand how it could in any way relate to some sort of procedure whereby something could happen which, I think the honourable member for Kooyong implied, might be somewhat sinister in relation to golden handshakes. What will happen under that section is that the amendment-and I think this is probably understood by the honourable member for Kooyong-will allow the Commissioner to make a determination of compensation when a member or a staff member is retired early, if such a determination was not in fact made at the time of the appointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that not worked out at the time of appointment?

—The problem in relation to that was something that I thought the honourable member for Kooyong was aware of. Currently that is a problem if the appointment, for some reason, is not validly made. All this is doing is bringing about an improvement within the Australian Federal Police Act related to management-initiated retirement, because currently, if an effective determination is not made on this matter at the time of the appointment, the Commissioner has no power to correct it. That is all it is in fact doing. All that the amendment does is allow the Commissioner to make a determination ending the person's appointment early. Currently, only the person who made the original appointment can make this determination.

SPEECH.PARA: That would cause problems, as would be obvious, I would have thought, because appointment terms are for five to 10 years and the person who made the original appointment may not be available five or 10 years later to make the determination; and the amendment simply makes the provision more workable. It was an amendment to the provisions of the Australian Federal Police Act to improve the management initiated retirement scheme. On the direct point raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong, I repeat: currently if an effective determination is not made, which can happen for all sorts of reasons, the Commissioner has no power, in fact, to correct it.

The honourable member for Kooyong made a point of trying to connect this matter with the termination of the commission of Ambassador Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See. I would not, of course, take the point of relevance to this debate, but now that the Attorney-General has touched on this matter, I will say that one of the problems he has had with that whole issue-and I say this quite seriously-is that he has always seen something sinister in the Executive Council minute in respect of the termination of Ambassador Burke's commission. What the Executive Council minute said, as he has correctly stated from time to time, is that the commission of the ambassador was terminated. I would have thought that `terminated' simply meant `brought to an end'. There are two examples of how that could have happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Arnold Schwarzenegger, too.

—Actually, I did not have to look at anything to ascertain what `terminate' meant; it was something that I had understood for a fair while. What `terminate' means and always has meant, as I said a moment ago, is `bring to an end'. There are two ways in which that could have been done; there are two examples that I can give to the shadow Attorney-General. Firstly, it could have been terminated on the basis of a resignation by the ambassador in the case that the shadow Attorney-General is referring to. Alternatively, it could have ended on the basis of a termination on the recommendation of the relevant Minister. In the case that now is being referred to, that would be the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). But I think it is worth making the point tonight, because I do not think it has been understood, that how it was terminated would not have made any difference. Whether the termination came to an end on the basis of a recommendation accepted by the Governor-General, a recommendation by the relevant Minister, or on the basis of a resignation, the Executive Council minute would be the same. It would say: `The commission of the ambassador has been terminated'; and `terminated' in that sense would mean simply `brought to an end'.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that seems to have concerned the honourable member for Kooyong about this over the period is that he always seems to have expressed the view that `terminate' was used in some way in order to protect the payment to be made to the ambassador at the end of his term. I just want to make it plain that all of the advice that I have seen on this indicates to me that that would have been paid irrespective of the way in which it had been done. I do not think that, in fact, the question that the termination--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not provided for. It was a shonky payment.

—The shadow Attorney-General has made that point over and over again, and what I have said to him is that the termination of that appointment, irrespective of how it was done, would have read as it did in the Executive Council minute. As I said to the honourable member, on the advice available to me, there would have been no question that that termination payment would have been payable, whatever the reason for the termination taking place. Getting back to the Bill, because I diverted from that in order to attempt to clarify a couple of the matters that the shadow Attorney-General had raised in relation to that--
—It was interesting, though.

—I thank the shadow Attorney-General very much. The second matter he raised was clause 12(b), which relates to the Cash Transaction Reports Act; that is, the amendment to section 16. As he is aware, there is already an agreement in existence between cash dealers and the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency that the suspect transaction reports are to be treated in strictest confidence. But the agreement has been placed on a statutory basis in compliance with the international anti-money laundering initiatives, and the G7 financial action task force report on money laundering recommended that financial institutions should not be permitted to warn their customers that a suspect transaction report is being made. That is a matter we have discussed before-not in relation to these amendments, but in relation to the Cash Transaction Reports Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial action task force report also recommended that financial institutions should not be permitted to warn customers that a suspect transaction report has been made. Apart from the given reason that such warnings might result in funds being placed through other undetectable channels, the present position places cash dealers in a potential conflict between their obligations under the Act and the duty to their customer. It is our view that the proposal to amend section 16 to include a direction that cash dealers must not inform the customer that a transaction will or has been reported under the provisions of section 16 is necessary for those reasons.

I turn to the question of record retention by cash dealers-clause 14, amending section 23. The honourable member for Kooyong raised the problem of evidence. I must say that, as I understand the position, there is not any problem of evidence there. Those records are admissible and there is, in fact, provision for that type of evidence-that is, the records of bankers-to be admissible. Section 23 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act requires a cash dealer to retain original documents in relation to the account verification procedures, as the shadow Attorney-General indicated, and in relation to disclosure of commonly known names under the false name account provisions set out in section 24.

What we propose here is to amend section 23 to enable some documents to be retained in a copy form. During the period of consultations with representatives of financial institutions on this particular issue, in order to settle the requirements for account verifications procedure, there has been criticism-and I think the shadow Attorney-General is aware of this-of the present requirements based on what are alleged to be administrative difficulties and the cost of storage of large amounts of original documents. If copies were permitted, the documents could be stored on microfilm, which, as the shadow Attorney-General conceded, was probably a pretty sensible arrangement.

Section 23, as currently set out, appears to require the retention of originals of some documents, copies of which would be permitted under the Proceeds of Crime Act; and section 77 of the Proceeds of Crimes Act requires financial institutions to retain-I do not want to go through them all, but I will give the honourable member some examples-the original of each `essential customer generated financial transaction document', a copy of each `customer generated financial transaction document', and so it goes on and on.

The essential customer documents that are referred to there create the problem. What we are saying here is that now we are moving to the stage where that amendment to section 23 is necessary because of what appears to me to be some reasonable criticism-without necessarily saying it is entirely correct-of the administrative costs and difficulties relating to the storage of documents where they cannot be copied, particularly, as we have indicated, in relation to the microfilm.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is sensible, but it conflicts with the best evidence in the world.
—No, it does not. As I indicated earlier, there is no evidentiary problem with it. In respect of the other matter--
—I wish you well.

—The honourable member may be proved to be correct, but I do not think he will be on that issue. I thank him for his good wishes. In respect to the other matter that the honourable member opposite raised, I go back to a previous discussion we had in this House back on 13 February where he referred at that stage to the decision of Mr Justice Vincent in the case of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and the Director of Public Prosecutions v. Kunz. At that time I did refer the honourable gentleman to the view he expressed to me back in October 1990 when he indicated some detailed knowledge of this, a very complex area of law. I said then that I believed it would be inappropriate to amend the Proceeds of Crime Act at this stage. I still believe that it is better to take that view at this stage. My reply at that stage was couched fairly carefully for obvious reasons, which the honourable gentleman is aware of, and that was the question of the appeal.

SPEECH.PARA: I did mention on that occasion, and I repeat tonight, that that has been reinforced by the fact that there is a subsequent, and at that stage unreported, judgment on the same issue of Mr Justice Teague of the Victorian Supreme Court. In respect to the honourable gentleman's view on the Kunz matter, although the decision of Mr Justice Vincent in the Kunz case is no longer under appeal-and the honourable member opposite is correct about that-the subsequent decision of Mr Justice Teague that I referred to on the same issue, raising the same matter, is under appeal. The appeal books on that matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on a different point.

—The appeal books have been lodged, and the appeal is unlikely to be heard before November of this year. It would be unwise in those circumstances to comment in respect of that matter. In fact, if we look at what was the unreported decision that we discussed back in February, Mr Justice Teague stated that both section 218 notices and orders under the Proceeds of Crime Act have a powerful intrusive effect.

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour went on to say that he was satisfied that an order under the Proceeds of Crime Act had a greater priority than a section 218 notice in the absence of a specific provision to the contrary. There is another case of Kunz and Slade v. Director of Public Prosecutions and others, the judgment having been made in January 1991. Therefore I again disagree. It is on the same issue. I do not think that the time has come to say that the matter should be amended when appeal books have been lodged in the matter involving Mr Justice Teague in this area.

In relation to general policy, the honourable member raised an important matter in respect of the judicial arbiter and the National Crime Authority (NCA), and the matters under discussion between the intergovernmental committee and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority overseeing the operation of the National Crime Authority.

I acknowledge for the first time, I suppose, this evening that the constructive attitude that the honourable member for Kooyong has adopted towards the NCA-and particularly the efforts of Mr Justice Phillips, as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority-has been appreciated by the Authority, as it has been appreciated by the Government, but when the Committee found itself in the position where in camera evidence became public, that created particular problems for the intergovernmental committee.

As the honourable member for Kooyong is aware, but I think it ought to be put on record, the intergovernmental committee is a governmental committee involving Attorneys-General, and all Ministers for police, of all States and Territories of various political persuasions. The honourable member was not suggesting to the contrary, but there is nothing political about that committee. It is, in fact, very much a bipartisan committee in terms of its political structure.

That committee had very grave concerns about that matter, and that is why the committee put to the Parliamentary Joint Committee its view that we should revert to the judicial arbiter position. This, of course, is not a new position. That was the original position in the original Bill which, for reasons which may be repeated, the Senate altered.

A meeting is currently scheduled for 13 June, I think, in Melbourne of the intergovernmental committee and the Parliamentary Committee where all of those issues will be discussed. I take on notice the honourable member's view that things should remain the way they are, but I can assure him that there is a very strong view within the intergovernmental committee, subject to the discussions with the Parliamentary Committee, that the position in respect of the overseeing of the operation of the NCA should be changed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause
``(1A) Section 11a and paragraph 12 (aa) commence 4 months after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.''.
(2) Page 4, after clause 11 insert the following new clause:
Interpretation
``11a. The following definition is inserted in subsection (1) of section 3 of the Principal Act:
`serious offence' for the purposes of paragraph 16 means:

(a) a serious narcotics offence as defined in section 4 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; murder, kidnapping or equivalent offences; an offence against section 81 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; receipt, possession, concealment, disposition of or bringing into Australia any property, including money, that may reasonably be suspected of being proceeds of crime, being an offence against section 82 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; or an offence against section 83 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; and
(b) aiding, abetting or conspiring to commit an offence of the type referred to in paragraph (a).''.
(3) Clause 12, page 4, before paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
``(aa) by omitting from subparagraph (1) (b) (ii) `an offence' and substituting `a serious offence' ''.

I point out to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that similar amendments were moved in February 1991 this year but, in order to overcome the same question rule, the amendments now being moved have been recast so that, in effect, a different question is being put. Knowing the Attorney-General's quintessential undoubted powers of recall, he may well have picked up that these amendments have been before him. I just foreshadow that we have recast them so that any point he takes will inevitably fall to the ground. I would not wish him to meet with a lack of success before this Committee on that point. Having done that for him, perhaps he will listen to my plausible arguments and accept my amendments.

Amendment No. 1 inserts a new subclause 2 (A) into the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The purpose is to defer the commencement of provisions relating to section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act, which are to be amended by amendment No. 2. Because amendment No. 2 alters the obligations imposed upon cash dealers with respect to the reporting of suspect transactions, it is necessary that the commencement of the changes be deferred so as to allow for the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to issue new guidelines about the reporting obligations under section 16, and for cash dealers to have sufficient time to familiarise themselves with the new changes.

Section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act obliges cash dealers to make certain reports where they suspect that information they may have, amongst other things, may be relevant to the investigation or prosecution of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory. I emphasise that it is an offence against `a' law. The obligations imposed by section 16 relate to a wide range of offences, from the most trivial to the most serious. The amendment seeks to confine those obligations to information which may be relevant to a serious offence as defined. The effect of the amendment, if carried, will be to narrow the net cast by section 16. It will go some way towards alleviating the concerns held by many that section 16 as presently drafted poses very serious risks to civil liberties and unduly intrudes upon rights of individual privacy.

I get the feeling that the Attorney-General will not accept this amendment. He has not said so, but I get that distinct impression, on the basis of responses in the past on these kinds of points. As I recall it, on matters such as these, according to the Attorney-General there is a concern that the amendment, if carried, would force cash dealers to behave as investigators in order to determine whether the information may be relevant to a serious offence.

My reply to that is twofold. Firstly, cash dealers are already, in many respects, placed in the position of having to carry out investigative functions. Secondly, the amendment, if carried, will only relieve cash dealers of some of their more onerous obligations in ascertaining whether information may be relevant to `an offence against a law'-and I emphasise the word `an'. To narrow the ambit of section 16 can only make life easier for cash dealers. Narrowing the ambit of section 16 will confine its operation to the purpose intended, namely, the pursuit of the money trail left by organised crime.

Amendment No. 3 flows from amendment No. 2. Section 16 of the Act is to be amending by omitting from subparagraph 1(b) (ii) the words `an offence' and substituting the words `a serious offence'. The phrase `a serious offence' is defined in amendment No. 2 by reference to certain specified offences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The premonition, if I can put it that way, of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), that his amendments are not acceptable is correct. What again he is attempting to do here is narrow the effect of section 16. The shadow Attorney-General wants to confine the effect of section 16 to serious offences because he says that `a Commonwealth law' is too wide and he wants to narrow it. He says that my objection to that is that it puts the cash dealer into an investigative role.

SPEECH.PARA: To some extent I can understand what he is saying there, but I think it goes a bit further than that. It puts cash dealers into more than an investigative role if we say that within the terms of the Cash Transaction Reports Act they are only to report serious offences. It is not necessarily the investigative role that is the main problem, though that causes a lot of difficulties. The definition of `serious offence' in the interpretation provision of the proposed amendment would require, as I have said before in this place, a bank teller, for example, to be placed in the position of becoming somewhat of an expert in criminal law. We would probably get to a stage at which this section would become almost unworkable.

I think it is reasonable to say that the remarks made earlier by the honourable member for Kooyong are correct in the sense that although he and those advising him have very cleverly recast the amendments, we have been through this before. My recall is that it has been dealt with in some detail and I do not propose to go through it again, other than to say that I think we would get to the stage where this section would be almost unworkable. We would be placing people in the position of saying `We will report this' or `We will not report this', depending on whether they thought it was a serious offence.

I previously quoted some examples of that. I do not want to go through them all again, but I shall give one example. To make those circumstances narrower for which a report must be lodged, as the amendment does, would require a cash dealer to carry out an examination, and even perhaps go to the stage of seeking legal advice, before deciding whether a matter would be reported. It would not work; it is just not practical, in my view.

For those reasons the Government cannot accept the amendments, not because the proposal has been dismissed out of hand but simply because, with the narrowing of the class of offence to a serious offence, as proposed, the exercise becomes that much more difficult, and perhaps even impossible, for a cash dealer. I am not being dismissive when I say that the proposal put forward previously and again tonight would just not work. In fact, I think it would defeat the purpose of the section.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 7, after clause 20 insert the following new clause:
Interpretation
``20a. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of the definition of `Commonwealth Officer' the following word and paragraph:
`and (e) for the purposes of sections 54, 55 and 56, a person who is an agent of the Commonwealth, of a Territory or of a body referred to in paragraph (d);' ''.
(5) Page 9, after clause 21 insert the following new clauses:
Repeal of sections 31 to 44, substitution of new sections
``21a. Sections 31 to 44, inclusive, of the Principal Act are repealed and the following sections are substituted:
Interpretation
`31. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:
``act'' includes omission;
``benefit'' includes money, real and personal property and any advantage;
``judicial office holder'' means:
(a) a Justice of the High Court; or
(b) a judge of a court created by the Parliament; or
(c) a justice or judge of a court of a State or Territory who is exercising federal jurisdiction or is exercising or performing jurisdiction or a power or function under a law of the Commonwealth;
and includes:
(d) a person acting as an arbitrator or umpire under a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory; and
(e) a person who, alone or with other persons, is conducting proceedings under a law of the Commonwealth in which evidence may be taken on oath;
``judicial proceeding'' means a proceeding before:
(a) the High Court, a court created by the Parliament or a court of a Territory; or
(b) a court that is:
(i) exercising federal jurisdiction; or
(ii) exercising any jurisdiction or power, or performing any function, under a law of the Commonwealth;
and includes a proceeding under a law of the Commonwealth in which evidence may be taken on oath.
Judicial corruption

`32. (1) A judicial office holder must not ask for or receive or obtain a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on account of an act done or to be done by the office holder in his or her capacity as a judicial office holder.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 10 years.

`(2) A person must not provide or procure, or promise or offer to provide or procure, a benefit for a judicial office holder or for another person on account of an act done or to be done by the office holder in his or her capacity as a judicial office holder.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 10 years.

`(3) This section does not apply to salary, allowances or other benefits that are or could lawfully be payable to or conferred on a judicial office holder in relation to the performance of the person's functions or duties as a judicial office holder.
Corruption relating to offences
`33. (1) A person who is:
(a) a justice of the peace (other than a judicial office holder) and who is exercising any jurisdiction or power, or is performing any function, under a law of the Commonwealth; or
(b) a Commonwealth officer (other than a judicial office holder) and who is employed in a capacity relating to the prosecution, detention or punishment of offenders;

must not ask for or receive or obtain a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on account of an act done or to be done by the person in relation to that exercise or performance or that capacity, as the case may be, with a view to:
(c) interfering with the due administration of justice under a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory; or
(d) procuring or facilitating the commission of an offence against such a law; or
(e) protecting an offender or intending offender against such a law from detection or punishment.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 10 years.
`(2) A person must not:
(a) provide or procure; or
(b) promise or offer to provide or procure;
a benefit for any person on account of an act of the kind referred to in paragraph (1) (c), (d) or (e) on the part of a person referred to in paragraph (1) (a) or (b).
Penalty: Imprisonment for 10 years.
False evidence etc.
`34. (1) A person must not, in evidence given in a judicial proceeding:
(a) on oath, affirmation or declaration; or
(b) after being warned that the giving of false evidence could result in criminal proceedings against the person;
knowingly or recklessly make a statement, whether admissible or not and whether of fact or opinion, that is false.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.

`(2) A person must not, in a statement from the dock in a judicial proceeding and after being warned that the making of a false statement could result in criminal proceedings against the person, knowingly or recklessly make a statement, whether of fact or opinion, that is false.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(3) An interpreter in a judicial proceeding must not knowingly or recklessly give an interpretation that is false or misleading.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(4) A person must not knowingly or recklessly make a statement, whether of fact or opinion, that is false in an affidavit, statutory declaration or certificate that:
(a) is made for the purpose of a judicial proceeding; and
(b) is made admissible in the proceeding (whether or not admitted).
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.

`(5) A person must not knowingly or recklessly make a statement, whether of fact or opinion, that is false in a document that is intended to be placed before a court in a judicial proceeding that is a committal proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(6) An offence under subsection (4) or (5) is not committed unless:
(a) the affidavit, statutory declaration, certificate or document was made on oath, affirmation or declaration; or
(b) the person was warned in writing before making the statement that the making of a false statement could result in criminal proceedings against the person; or
(c) a warning of that kind was given orally and the affidavit, statutory declaration, certificate or document acknowledges that the warning was given.
`(7) An offence under this section is not committed if:
(a) the court, tribunal, body or person did not have jurisdiction in the proceeding; or
(b) the statement or interpretation was not material in the proceeding.
`(8) A person cannot be convicted of an offence under this section on the uncorroborated evidence of one person.
`(9) For the purposes of a prosecution for an offence against this section, the following matters are immaterial:
(a) whether or not the court, tribunal or body was properly constituted;
(b) whether or not the judicial proceeding was held in the proper place;
(c) whether or not the person who made the statement was a competent witness.
`(10) The question whether a statement is material in a proceeding is one of law.
Fabricating, altering or concealing evidence
`35. (1) A person must not, intending to:
(a) influence a decision by a person whether or not to institute a judicial proceeding; or
(b) influence the outcome of a judicial proceeding, whether the proceeding is already in progress or is to be or may be instituted at a later time;
fabricate evidence or alter, conceal or destroy any thing that may be required in evidence in the proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(2) A person must not, intending to:
(a) influence a decision by a person whether or not to institute a judicial proceeding; or
(b) influence the outcome of a judicial proceeding, whether the proceeding is already in progress or is to be or may be instituted at a later time;
use evidence that has been fabricated, or a thing that has been altered, as mentioned in subsection (1).
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
Corruption of, and threats against, witnesses
`36. (1) A person must not:
(a) use threats against another person; or
(b) provide or procure, or promise or offer to provide or procure, a benefit for another person;
intending to induce the other person or a third person:
(c) not to attend as a witness at a judicial proceeding, whether the proceeding is already in progress or is to be or may be instituted at a later time; or
(d) not to give evidence at such a proceeding; or
(e) to give false evidence at such a proceeding; or
(f) to withhold truthful evidence at such a proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(2) A person must not:
(a) prevent another person attending as a witness at a judicial proceeding, whether the proceeding is already in progress or is to be or may be instituted at a later time; or
(b) prevent another person producing a thing in evidence at such a proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
Deceiving witnesses

`37. A person must not do an act with the intention of deceiving another person in any way in order to affect the evidence of the other person at a judicial proceeding, whether the proceeding is already in progress or is to be or may be instituted at a later time.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years.
Threatening or causing violence, injury or damage on account of an exercise of a person's duty at a judicial proceeding
`38. (1) A person must not cause or procure, or threaten to cause or procure, any violence, injury or damage (whether to a person or property) on account of anything said or done by:
(a) a person who was a judicial office holder at a judicial proceeding; or
(b) a person who was involved in a judicial proceeding as a witness, a juror, a legal practitioner or officer of a court; or
(c) in the case of a judicial proceeding involving an offence-a person who was an accused person or a prosecutor in the proceeding;
in the course of, or in relation to, the proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply to a thing done in relation to a person who was involved in a judicial proceeding as a witness if the person:
(a) gave false evidence in the proceeding; and
(b) knew at the time when the evidence was given that it was false.
Threatening a person with intention to influence outcome of a judicial proceeding
`39. (1) A person must not make a threat of any kind to any person with the intention of inducing a person who is, or is to be:
(a) a judicial office holder at a judicial proceeding; or
(b) involved in a judicial proceeding as a witness, a juror, a legal practitioner or officer of a court;
to act in a way that will influence the outcome of the proceeding.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(2) The threat referred to in subsection (1) need not be made against the person referred to in paragraph (1) (a) or (b).
False accusations that a person has committed an offence
`40. (1) A person must not allege or suggest that another person has committed an offence that the person knows or believes the other person did not commit, intending that:
(a) the other person will be charged with committing the offence; or
(b) police or other authorities will pursue criminal investigations against the other person in relation to the alleged offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 10 years.
`(2) A person cannot be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) on the uncorroborated evidence of one person.
Obstructing, preventing, perverting or defeating the course of justice
`41. A person must not obstruct, prevent, pervert or defeat the course of justice in a judicial proceeding in a manner that is not specifically dealt with in another provision of this Part.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
Impersonating jurors etc.
`42. A person must not:
(a) take an oath as a member of a jury in a judicial proceeding knowing that he or she has not been selected to be a member of the jury; or
(b) take the place of a member of a jury in a judicial proceeding knowing that he or she is not a member of the jury.
Penalty:
(c) if the person did the act intending to obstruct, prevent, pervert or defeat the course of justice in that or another judicial proceeding-imprisonment for 5 years; or
(d) in any other case-imprisonment for 2 years.
Impeding proper investigation etc. of offences

`43. (1) A person who knows that an offence has been committed must not, intending to impede investigations into the offence, to prevent or impede the apprehension, prosecution or conviction of the person who committed the offence or to impede the production of evidence materially relevant to the guilt or innocence of any person in relation to the offence:
(a) make a threat of any kind, or give or agree or offer to give a benefit, to another person in order to induce another person to:
(i) provide information that the person knows to be false; or
(ii) withhold information; or
(b) receive or agree to receive a benefit for himself or herself or for another person in return for:
(i) providing information that the person knows to be false; or
(ii) withholding information.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
(a) a person is charged with an offence under subsection (1) relating to the receipt of a benefit in return for withholding information; and
(b) the offence to which the withholding of information relates is not an indictable offence;
it is a defence to a prosecution for the offence referred to in paragraph (a) if the defendant proves that the benefit amounted only to:
(c) the making good of any loss or injury caused by the offence referred to in paragraph (b); or
(d) reasonable compensation for that loss or injury.

`(3) A person may be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) even though the person was not aware of the exact circumstances surrounding the commission of the offence that the person knew to have been committed.
Compounding of offences
`44. (1) A person must not ask for or receive or obtain, or agree to receive or obtain, a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on the agreement or understanding that the person will:
(a) conceal the commission of an offence; or
(b) abstain from, discontinue or delay a prosecution for an offence; or
(c) withhold information that might be materially relevant in proceedings for an offence; or
(d) provide false information in respect of the commission of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 years.
(a) a person is charged with an offence under subsection (1) relating to concealing the commission of an offence (the ``compounded offence''); and
(b) the compounded offence is not an indictable offence;
it is a defence to a prosecution for the offence charged if the defendant proves that the benefit amounted only to:
(c) the making good of any loss or injury caused by the compounded offence; or
(d) reasonable compensation for that loss or injury.'.
Insertion of new Part IV
``21b. After Part III of the Principal Act the following Part is inserted:
`PART IV-BRIBERY AND CORRUPTION
Interpretation
`51. In this Part:
``act'' includes omission;
``association officer'' means:
(a) an officer or employee of an organisation of employers or employees registered under the Industrial Relations Act 1988; or
(b) a person who performs services for or on behalf of such an organisation; and, in sections 54, 55 and 56, includes an agent of such an organisation;

(b) an office in the Defence Force or in a public authority under the Commonwealth; and

(d) an office in the Public Service of a Territory or in an authority of a Territory;

``reward'' does not include salary, wages, allowances, fees or other remuneration payable to a member of the Parliament, a Commonwealth officer or an association officer under the law or under the terms of his or her employment or engagement as such a person.
Demanding or receiving benefit on basis of official office
(a) a person demands, exacts or requires the provision of a benefit to himself or herself or any other person from another person; and
(b) in making the demand, exaction or requirement, the person suggests or implies that it should be complied with because the person holds:
(i) a Commonwealth office; or
(ii) employment by the Commonwealth, a Territory, a public authority under the Commonwealth or an authority of a Territory;
whether or not the person holds that office or employment; and

the person is guilty of an offence.

Buying or selling public offices
`53. (1) If a person:

(a) asks for or receives or obtains, or agrees to ask for or receive or obtain, an additional benefit for himself or herself or for another person on account of an act done or to be done by the person or another person with regard to the appointment or possible appointment of a person to an office or employment in the Australian Public Service, the public service of a Territory or a public authority under the Commonwealth; or

the person is guilty of an offence.

`(2) In subsection (1):
``additional benefit'' means a benefit of any kind other than:

Influencing duty, functions or authority of Commonwealth officers or association officers

`54. (1) A Commonwealth officer or an association officer who asks for or receives or obtains, or agrees to receive or obtain, a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on the basis that the exercise or performance by the officer of:
(a) his or her duty, functions or authority as such an officer; or
(b) any duty, functions or authority that the officer has held himself or herself out as having;
will be influenced or affected is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.

`(2) A person who, in order to influence or affect the exercise or performance of the duty, functions or authority of a Commonwealth officer or an association officer as such an officer, provides, or promises to provide, a benefit for any person is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 5 years.
`(3) In a prosecution for an offence under this section, evidence to show that the provision of a benefit is customary in any trade or calling is not admissible.
Asking for or receiving secret benefits

`55. (1) A person who is or has been a Commonwealth officer or an association officer and who, without the knowledge and consent of the relevant authority, asks for or receives or obtains, or agrees to receive or obtain, a benefit for himself or herself or for another person as a reward or inducement for any act done or to be done by the officer or former officer:

is guilty of an offence.
