`(2) A person who, without the knowledge and consent of the relevant authority, provides or promises to provide a benefit for any person as a reward or inducement for any act done or to be done by a Commonwealth officer or an association officer:
(a) in his or her capacity as such an officer; or
(b) in relation to the functions or activities of the body in which the officer is employed or for or on behalf of which the officer performs services or acts as agent is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years.
`(3) For the purposes of this section, the relevant authority is:
(a) if the officer is or was:
(i) the Secretary or permanent head of a Department of the Australian Public Service or of the public service of a Territory or a person having the powers of such a Secretary or permanent head; or
(ii) the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police; or
(iii) the head of a public authority under the Commonwealth or the holder of a statutory office;
the relevant Minister; or
(b) if the officer is or was the Clerk of the Senate or the Clerk of the House of Representatives-the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case may be; or

(c) if the officer is or was the Secretary of the Joint House Department, the Secretary of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Parliamentary Librarian-the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives; or

(d) if the officer is or was an officer of the Department of the Senate, the Department of the House of Representatives, the Joint House Department, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Department of the Parliamentary Library (other than a person to whom paragraph (b) or (c) applies)-the Clerk of the Senate, the Clerk of the House of Representatives, the Secretary of the Joint House Department, the Secretary of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Parliamentary Librarian, as the case may be; or

(e) if the officer is or was a member or special member of the Australian Federal Police (other than the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police)-the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police; or

(f) if the officer is or was a person employed in, or performing services for, a Department of State or a Department of the public service of a Territory (other than a person to whom paragraph (a) applies)-the Secretary or permanent head of that department; or

(g) if the officer is or was an officer of, a person employed in, or performing services for, a public authority under the Commonwealth (other than a person to whom paragraph (a) applies)-the head of that authority; or
(h) if the officer is or was an association officer-the committee of management of the relevant organisation; or
(j) in any other case-the person who appointed or engaged the officer or the person who has power to terminate the person's employment or engagement.

`(4) If, in a prosecution for an offence against this section, it appears that the receipt of the benefit, or the expectation that the officer had of the provision of the benefit, would, in all the circumstances, be likely to have influenced the officer to do an act contrary to his or her duty, the benefit is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to be taken to have been provided or promised as a reward or inducement for the doing of that act.
Using false or misleading documents
`56. A person who:
(a) gives to a Commonwealth officer or to an association officer; or
(b) being a Commonwealth officer or an association officer, receives or uses;

intending to deceive the body in which the officer is employed or for or on behalf of which the officer performs services or acts as an agent, a document that contains false or misleading information that:

(d) relates to a dealing, transaction or matter with which the body is concerned;
is guilty of an offence.

Buying or selling property by agents

`57. (1) If an agent of the Commonwealth, a Territory, a public authority under the Commonwealth or an organisation of employers or employees registered under the Industrial Relations Act 1988, without the knowledge and consent of the relevant authority, buys from, or sells to:
(a) himself or herself; or

any property for or on behalf of the body of which the person is an agent, the agent is guilty of an offence.

`(2) For the purposes of this section, the relevant authority is:

(b) if the person is an agent of the Department of the Senate, the Department of the House of Representatives, the Joint House Department, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Department of the Parliamentary Library-the Clerk of the Senate, the Clerk of the House of Representatives, the Secretary of the Joint House Department, the Secretary of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff or the Parliamentary Librarian, as the case may be; or
(c) if the person is an agent of the Australian Federal Police-the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police; or
(d) if the officer is an agent of a public authority under the Commonwealth-the head of that authority; or
(e) if the person is an agent of an organisation of employees or employers-the committee of management of the organisation.
Influencing duty, functions or authority of members of Parliament

`58. (1) A member of the Parliament who asks for or receives or obtains, or agrees to receive or obtain, a benefit for himself or herself or for another person on the basis that the exercise or performance by the member of:
(a) his or her duty, functions or authority as such a member; or
(b) duty, functions or authority that the member has held himself or herself out as having;
will be influenced or affected is guilty of an offence.

`(2) A person who, in order to:
(a) influence or affect the exercise or performance of the duty, functions or authority of a member of the Parliament; or
(b) induce a member of the Parliament to absent himself or herself from the House of which he or she is a member or from a committee of that House or of both Houses of the Parliament;
provides, or promises to provide, a benefit for any person is guilty of an offence.

Member of Parliament asking for or receiving
secret benefits

`59. (1) A person who is or has been a member of the Parliament who, without first informing the Presiding Officer of the House of which the person is or was a member, asks for or receives or obtains, or agrees to receive or obtain, a benefit for himself or herself or for another person as a reward or inducement for any act done or to be done by the member or former member in his or her capacity as such a member is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years.

`(2) A person who provides or promises to provide a benefit for a person who is or was a member of the Parliament, without first informing the Presiding Officer of the House of which the person is or was a member, as a reward or inducement for any act done or to be done by the member or former member in his or her capacity as such a member is guilty of an offence.

The amendments are very extensive and detailed, but they have previously been before the House in another form. Amendment No. 4 seeks to amend section 3 of the Crimes Act 1914 by adding at the end of the definition of `Commonwealth Officer' a reference to agents of the Commonwealth for the purpose of proposed sections 54, 55 and 56. Those proposed sections are contained within amendment No.= 5, which can be divided into two parts. It seeks to introduce into the Bill new clauses 21a and 21b. Clause 21a seeks to repeal sections 31 to 44 of the Crimes Act 1914 and to substitute new provisions relating to the administration of justice. Section 21b seeks to insert into the Crimes Act a new part IV dealing with bribery and corruption.

This really is a series of amendments that the Attorney-General can pick up. Here the Government has a report brought down by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, a committee chaired by the former High Court Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs. I presented a private member's Bill that picked up the drafts recommended by this eminent committee, which is supported by the Government. As the Government's approach to law reform is somewhat glacial, it did not pick it up. Here is the second chance. The Attorney-General can now make his name as a great legal reformer in the field of criminal law and he does not have to do a thing but pick up these amendments tonight.

The genesis is the fourth interim report of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court. The Attorney-General can ignore all my previous speeches. He can just switch off what I am going to say now, save and except when I remind him that his own body has recommended these amendments. They are drafted. His officials do not need to do any more work. A simple yea instead of a nyet will get him into the record books as a great reformer in the field of criminal law.

All the Attorney-General has to do to achieve that tonight is to pick up these amendments. The Attorney cannot disagree with them; they have been so plausibly argued in the reports of the Gibbs Committee of Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law. The chamber will be aware that on 6 December last year I introduced into the House a private member's Bill designed to implement the recommendations of the Gibbs Committee. At the time I urged the Government to respond to the recommendations of the Gibbs Committee and support my private member's Bill. I do not give up; I felt that my appeals might fall on deaf ears, and they did. My private member's Bill was withdrawn from the Notice Paper last week and that allows me to introduce it here in the form of the amendments to the Bill now under consideration. I supply that information in case someone with a lofty notion of the Standing Orders seeks to have these amendments not put any further. That private member's Bill evaporated like the Government's hopes for the next election evaporated last week.

In recent times the issue of institutionalised corruption has received enormous attention. The various State royal commissions and other inquiries, particularly the one in Western Australia that has caused the Government so much damage, and properly so, have highlighted the need to strengthen criminal laws relating to bribery and corruption. One voice of affirmative action would place the Government in a position of repute and it would come to any further discussions on WA Inc. with very clean hands if the Attorney were to pick up these amendments.

This whole question of bribery and corruption is particularly contentious given the Government's proposed ban, for example, on political advertising, which the Government says it will address or avoid the risk of institutionalised corruption at the Federal level. Time does not permit me to explain in any detail the absurdity of that proposition. Needless to say that, if this Government has a serious concern about corruption, it should move with the greatest speed to accept and implement the recommendations of the Gibbs Committee. The simplest way to do that would be to accept my amendments.

One of the beneficial reforms contained within the amendments is the extension of the Crimes Act to trade union officials. Many honourable members, particularly those from Victoria, will be familiar with the so-called Tennis Australia saga, where it is said by some that a threat to impose industrial action if a donation of $10,000 were not forthcoming did not constitute the offence of demanding money by menace, blackmail or any other criminal offence. To put it mildly, I find that proposition to be spurious. In any event, if carried, my amendments would resolve the matter and would bring trade union officials within reach of the Crimes Act. Conduct of the type involved in the Tennis Australia saga would fall within the provisions of proposed part IV.

I understand the Attorney may be of the view that, instead of writing his name into the record books as a great reformer in criminal law in the attack on bribery and corruption, he will not take action to pick this up at this stage because he has not yet responded to the third report. Honourable members will recall that my amendments reflect recommendations in the fourth report of the Committee, and the Attorney, allegedly working his way through these reports seriatim, has not yet responded to the third report of the Gibbs Committee relating to the principles of criminal liability and the Committee will be handing down a final report later this year.

However, I inform the Attorney that my amendments do not rest upon the need to implement the recommendations of the third report. They do not alter the existing principles of criminal liability. That point was made in the fourth report. Furthermore, as the fourth report said, the recommendations could be implemented immediately and there is no need to wait for the Committee's final report. I could probably walk away from this Parliament a satisfied man tonight and I may even rethink the period I remain in this Parliament. So much work would be done by the Attorney simply picking up these amendments that his name would go into the record books. I would feel then that I had played a minor contributory role by moving these amendments, and the Attorney-General would be rested from a shadow Attorney-General who seeks to move amendments to everything the Attorney-General brings into this Parliament.

Just think of the enlightened and detached approach that the Attorney-General would be able to take if he did not have me snapping at his heels. A simple affirmative answer to the question that the Chair will soon put will establish satisfaction all round and, more to the point, will write into the laws of this country a proper and effective approach to attacking bribery and corruption. If the Attorney-General says no it will not mean that he is not serious about these things; it will just indicate that he is again dawdling his way through law reform. This glacial approach is not acceptable, and I urge the Attorney-General to support us.
Amendments Nos 6, 7 and 8 are of a consequential nature and flow from amendment No. 5. I await with great expectation the Attorney-General's response to the question that the Chair will put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing firstly with the lighter side of the issues raised by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), it is not really a matter of writing one's name in the record books as he suggests that I could do by adopting these amendments. One would not want to encourage his departure from this place anyway. He started by saying that if he could get this up he would be happy to leave the Parliament this night. To go away, I thought he meant, and come back tomorrow. But then, by inference, I thought it was going to be a far grander gesture.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing he ought to understand by now-I have known him for about 30 years, which is a horrifying thought, and it is even more horrifying when one thinks that he has been here for most of that period-is that flattery will get him nowhere in relation to adopting amendments in order to write someone's name in the record books.

Basically, I think the honourable member for Kooyong is wrong about this matter. Turning to the more serious aspects, I have to say that a lot of work has been put into these amendments that have been moved by the honourable member. I do not know whether he would admit it-perhaps he would say that the legislation to which I am about to refer has been redrafted cleverly-but they do have a very familiar ring to them and they sound similar to the terms of the Crimes (Bribery and Corruption) Amendment Bill 1990, which was a private member's Bill introduced by the honourable member for Kooyong.

These amendments, or the Bill, whichever way one might like to refer to them, are based on the fourth interim report of the Gibbs Committee. They are really based on the model Bill that is contained in the fourth Committee report. That model Bill is, in turn, based on the principles of criminal responsibility which are recommended in the third report of the Gibbs Committee, and those principles are not based on existing law.

I find it extraordinary that the honourable member for Kooyong really wants to pursue that at this stage. What he really wants to do is pass a Bill which purports to implement parts of that fourth interim report of the Committee chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs. I do not know whether the honourable member for Kooyong disputes this fact, but the Bill relies on the criminal responsibility recommendations contained in the third report, which in turn, I think it is reasonable to say, may well result in entirely unintended consequences. I do not think the honourable member intends this to happen, but both sides of the House have had some experience of unintended consequences.

This latter possibility is a very real concern because the proposed Bill is drafted on the premise of a set of principles of criminal responsibility that not only are different from the present scheme of Commonwealth criminal law but also may not be enacted, at least in their current form. We do not know about that at this stage. It should be added of course that the Gibbs Committee found the existing laws to be adequate to deal with offering and accepting bribes in circumstances involving a corrupt discharge of official duties or a corrupt failure to perform duties under the existing applicable principles of criminal responsibility.

Once these principles are reformed and formulated, the recommendations in the fourth interim report, including those concerning bribery and corruption, may need further review. It is true that everyone would like to see the reports of the Committee chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs dealt with-not, as the honourable member seriously put, at any glacial pace but as quickly as possible. We are attempting to do that. They have to be worked through in that way. I am surprised that the honourable member wants to pursue this on the basis, as I said earlier, that this Bill is undoubtedly drafted on the premise of a criminal responsibility that is not only different from the present scheme operating under Commonwealth criminal law but may not be enacted, at least in its current form.

As indicated to the honourable member-and I will repeat it-the Gibbs Committee found the existing laws adequate. For that reason, until we have dealt with those reports-not in a glacial manner but as quickly as possible-all of these issues will be dealt with in a sensible way rather than our implementing legislation based on something which may well change.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Duffy)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the House too long on the third reading, but I will exercise my right to say a few words. I could go on at great length expressing my disappointment that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) did not wish to pick up these amendments and be established in the minds of all those who follow law reform as one of the great performing Attorneys. I will not go on at great length about that. However, I will say, very seriously, that the Attorney is well aware of the regard and the respect I have for him. I do not in any way impugn him in the words I am going to say because I regard him as a man of principle-sometimes wrongly applied; but a man of principle-a man of candour and a man of honesty. But there are some in his Party who are not.

SPEECH.PARA: The man who has just ceased to be the Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See is one whose credentials are open to question. Had the Attorney-General picked up those amendments tonight, the Government would have had an opportunity to consider charging Mr Burke because Mr Burke had received commissions while he was a Commonwealth officer. The evidence that has come out of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters indicates that not only stamps and gold bars were accepted and played with by Mr Burke when he was Premier of Western Australia, but also that funds were being made available to him while he was an officer of the Commonwealth.

By not accepting my amendments, the Attorney-General has tonight stepped away from giving himself the opportunity, should it present itself even further, to make prosecutions under a Commonwealth Act to tackle any breaches of the law that Mr Burke may have engaged in. Quite apart from the proper reforms that have been recommended by the committee chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs, it helped the Attorney-General by drafting the legislation. I add that the amendments I put in were taken from drafts that Sir Harry Gibbs attached to his report, aware of the glacial or snail's pace at which this Government moves in the field of law reform. The drafts were part of the report. All those drafts, prepared by some of the greatest legal brains in the land and put into this report so that the Attorney-General could just pick them up, bring them into the Parliament and enact them, I put before him tonight.

Were it any other Attorney but him, I would have said that he did it deliberately to protect Mr Burke. Knowing him, I will not say that. But the consequence-as far as the Attorney-General is concerned, perhaps the unintended consequence-is that, by not supporting these amendments, he has thrown aside the opportunity of pursuing, in the course and name of justice, those who may have engaged in activities that are certainly contrary to the proper execution of their duties. He could have done it by simply picking up my amendments. I regret that he did not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply very briefly to the matters raised by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Firstly, it is unfortunate that, whilst he does not direct those comments at me personally, he should suggest that anyone on this side of the House-and I reject it entirely-has been concerned for any reason other than that which I stated tonight not to pick up what is basically the Crimes (Bribery and Corruption) Amendment Bill 1990, that is, the private member's Bill previously produced and basically contained in these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I stated earlier that those amendments contain basically the model Bill in the fourth interim report of the Gibbs Committee. I said that, in turn, that model is based on principles of criminal responsibility recommended in the third report. Those principles are not based on existing law. I have to repeat that because of the allegations made by the honourable member for Kooyong. Therefore, to pass a Bill which purports to implement parts of that fourth interim report, relying on criminal responsibility recommendations contained in the third report which may need refining as part of the development of a model code, may well result in entirely unintended consequences. I have to repeat that because of the allegations made.

In conclusion, I think the honourable member for Kooyong did not have in mind the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters when he introduced his Bill. He introduced his Bill with what one can only say was a genuine desire to do something in the area-I am not disputing that-of bribery and corruption, which is certainly not something that could ever be directed at the honourable member for Kooyong.

I am concerned that once again in this House we are having things said about someone-in this case, the former Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See-based on evidence given before a royal commission. The honourable member for Kooyong and most honourable members of this House do have concerns-and if they do not, they should-about allegations that are made about various people in royal commissions. Someone from that side of politics may find themselves, not too far down the road, faced with the sort of publicity that Brian Burke has been faced with over the past few months. When the Royal Commission concludes, and when and if any charges are laid and prosecutions take place, is the time to talk about these matters.

I do not think that I did respond to the proposal to write my name in the record book by somehow adopting his Bill. However, I want to write my name in the record book in another way, by saying that I am not prepared to be part of the vilification of anyone-be they from this side of politics or, I can assure the House, from that side of politics-by way of allegations made before royal commissions until they are fully tested, all the evidence has come out and the matter is concluded one way or the other, as it should be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Clerk calls on the next order of the day, it might interest honourable members to know that for a certain football game this evening the final score was New South Wales 14, Queensland 12.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I must thank you for your courtesy to the House in advising us of the outcome of a football match which, as far as I am concerned, is of no interest at all. There is one solitary Queenslander here who may find it of great interest; but there are a couple of Victorians who follow real football. All I can say is that if you are going to take up the time of the House with these interjections, Mr Deputy Speaker, I may have to complain to the Speaker!

SPEECH.PARA: As I have been sitting waiting for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1991 to be called on, I have been contemplating the fact that the Bill provides a good opportunity to demonstrate that, in many significant areas of environment policy, there is a bipartisan stance and no significant political dispute. Any sense of satisfaction I had about that was eased by the fact that I do not think that means very much to the very few members who are here for the debate and for the three people in the visitors gallery. It seems a rather small number of people to satisfy on this point.

However, on opening I make the point that the area of the environment has been one of considerable politicisation over recent years, and at times I think the substance of the debate has been lost in the politics of the debate. Tonight is an opportunity to note the strong bipartisan support that there has been over the past 15 years or more for the preservation of one of Australia's great natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef. This Bill, which adds another degree of protection to the reef, has the unqualified support of the Opposition. Whilst it is a fairly limited extension of the protection which has been given to the reef by a variety of means--
(Quorum formed)

Mr Deputy Speaker, a large number of people seem to have come into the chamber who were interested in the football match, the result of which was recently announced. Let me say that I congratulate those honourable members who were supporting the winners and commiserate with those honourable members who were supporting the losers, whoever they may have been.

To return to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill, this Bill is intended to decrease the risk of oil and other toxic substances damaging the Great Barrier Reef by requiring all ships over a certain length and carrying specified cargoes to carry pilots while in reef waters. In fact, it is aimed at the 10 per cent of about 2,000 ships in the specified cargo and size categories which the Government says-and which the Opposition accepts-are not adhering to the current voluntary system of pilotage.

This law follows efforts made by the Australian Government to obtain international acceptance of the need to protect these particularly sensitive waters. Again, as I shall indicate later in my speech, those efforts certainly had the support of the Opposition. We behaved in a way which we believed would maximise the Government's chances of success in this regard. We are delighted that there was success.

As I say, the Bill has a limited impact because it simply covers the 10 per cent of shipping that was not complying with the voluntary ban. When we look at the potential risk and at the risk of damage to the reef, the Opposition certainly accepts the move in this direction as worth while. The legislation has our unequivocal support.

The measure is but one in a series which has been undertaken over the past 15 years. I remind the House of the efforts of an ex-colleague of yours, Mr Deputy Speaker, my old friend David Thompson, who I think was famous in the coalition for his announcement when he was the Minister for Science and Technology that there would be no drilling on the Barrier Reef. Subsequently, under the coalition Government, the Great Barrier Reef was inscribed on the World Heritage List on 26 October 1981. Of course, in addition, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park had been established in 1975. There has been a history of cooperation in ensuring that this national treasure is preserved.

In terms of more recent efforts to support and defend the reef, the Government brought forward legislation in 1990 to close the loophole allowing boat operators to increase Green Island visitors. Again, that had the support of the Opposition. Earlier this year, we had legislation to deal with the surrender of exploration permits within the marine park. Subject to our concerns that any issues of compensation should properly be dealt with, that also had the support of the Opposition.

It is instructive to note that it is not only at the political level that the additional restrictions which are being imposed by this legislation are being supported. I was pleased to find that the advice which the Opposition obtained from industry sources with respect to the legislation confirmed the universal view that this was a worthwhile measure. Indeed, the Australian Chamber of Shipping advised that it has been its policy since 1978 that ships using the sensitive waters should have the assistance of a pilot. It drew my attention to the fact that at a meeting of the managing committee of the Chamber on 13 November 1978 the following was provided:
The meeting strongly recommends that vessels with minimum under-keel clearance use the services of a pilot in Torres Strait.
The Chamber assures me that that has been its consistent policy since that time and it supports this measure.

In the same way, the Australian National Maritime Association advised the Opposition that it supports the requirement to carry licensed pilots on ships transiting those areas of the Great Barrier Reef which have been designated as particularly sensitive areas.

Again, it is perhaps a little out of line with the general perception of how the debate on environmental matters proceeds in this country that one of the issues which was raised by industry representatives was whether the legis- lation was sufficiently broad in its geographic application. We received representations which suggested that there were other areas which should be subject to the pilotage requirements. We made inquiries about those representations and we were advised-and it appears to be correct-that there are international law reasons why the restrictions cannot be broader than is provided by this legislation.

I think it is worth putting that on the record because the position is that we get a great deal of stress in the debate on environmental issues between those who are concerned with industry and economic matters and those who are concerned with environmental matters. This is one of the many examples of real cooperation and real community purpose between all of those who are concerned.

Other elements will be brought into this debate by my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) who, with his responsibilities for shipping matters in the Opposition, will be examining what might be regarded as the micro-economic aspect of the provision of pilots. I want to make the point that the concerns which he will be raising on behalf of the Opposition in no way qualify our support for the principle that there should be pilotage in these sensitive waters.

The issues which are to be raised by the honourable member for Gilmore go to the question of whether the means of obtaining pilots, and the restrictions which are imposed in terms of the supply of pilots, in fact represent the most efficient means that could be adopted. I will not trespass on the ground that he intends to cover in what will be a short debate. I simply make the point that in the Opposition's consideration of these matters that has been looked at as a matter of economic efficiency which in no way impinges on our support for the principle that there certainly should be pilots in these areas.

I think that the virtues and the value of the Great Barrier Reef are very well known in this chamber. It is, in fact, one of the world's most diverse marine ecosystems. It is an area which provides a home to some 1,500 species of fish and 350 types of hard coral. When one compares it with other areas which are highly regarded-for example, in the Caribbean there are only about 500 types of fish and 40 corals-after Greenland, the area of the Great Barrier Reef is the planet's biggest protected area. We have about 2,900 individual reefs spread over 344,000 square kilometres of ocean, an area larger than Britain. It is a matter of some satisfaction that there is at both State and Federal government levels, on all sides of politics and within the community a total commitment to seeing the preservation of this area.

That brings me to one of the truths about environmental protection that I think is too little debated in this country. It is one thing to set aside these very substantial areas, and over the last decade, both at sea and on land, very considerable areas have been set aside and labelled as areas of particular environmental significance. One of the things that follows from that sort of labelling or classification is that there is an ongoing and, indeed, permanent obligation to provide adequate plans of management, to provide adequate on the ground management, and to accept the responsibility for the very considerable expenditure that is involved. It is one thing to say that there is political acceptance of the need to protect these areas; it is another thing to say that there will be the political will to provide the resources required to ensure that the natural values are preserved.

I do not believe that the Great Barrier Reef area is one of the less well off areas of natural value in that regard. Having visited the Daintree, for example, I would suggest that there is an area that is grossly undermanaged and grossly under-resourced. It will be interesting to see what the Authority that has been established by the State of Queensland and by the Commonwealth will be able to accomplish to remedy that.

It seems to me to be totally unsatisfactory to have an area that is so widely regarded and, in a legal sense, so strongly protected in such a poor state of administration and care. There is very little sign of the level of management and of resources that would be required to maintain it in the state that makes it a long term investment for Australia and for the world. The Daintree is an area I mention in contradistinction to the resources of the reef because it is, of course, relevant to the reef. Some of the concerns that are felt about the future of the Great Barrier Reef area relate to the problems of siltation and so on that flow from the undermanagement of the Daintree area.

I want to make a general point: it is one thing to make the political gesture of reserving an area; it is another thing to deliver on the long term management and preservation obligation that flows from that. I mention that in the context of the present Government's attempts to meet what is perceived to be an inadequate resource base for the management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park by the imposition of additional fees on those who use it. This is an area that attracts enormous tourist use. It is probably fair to say that one of the major threats to the reef is not just the threat of ships going aground and having oil spills but the rather more insidious and persistent threat of the feet and other parts of tourists who use the reef for their enjoyment and wonderment.

I remind the House of the recent attempts by the Government, which at first appeared to be successful, to obtain support from the State Government on the imposition of additional fees and the subsequent withdrawal of that view by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss-a withdrawal that was regarded with considerable sympathy by the Opposition because of the quite difficult situation of many of the tourist operators. It is probably fair to say that 1990-91 is not a particularly good time to be imposing additional cost burdens upon people in the tourist industry in Queensland or elsewhere. The economic situation of many individual operators is very difficult, in common with the difficulties that are being experienced by business throughout the economy.

The fact that those people are experiencing difficulties does not remove the reality that additional resources are required if the reef is to be protected. One is again reminded of the fact that if we are to have the levels of environmental protection that are demanded by the Government's rhetoric and, indeed, demanded by the Australian people, who are concerned to see the natural environment maintained and preserved, particularly those areas of high environmental significance such as the Barrier Reef, there is no escaping the need to find resources to meet the task.

I have had some very interesting conversations with people who have been long involved in the conservation movement. They have suggested to me that the push for World Heritage listing, for example, in some areas of Australia is a push that is at least in part, and some would say in large part, motivated by the desire to see better management plans in place and, even more importantly, additional resources attracted to enable proper management to be undertaken of areas so that they will not simply be degraded over time.

I remind the chamber that, if we are to achieve our environmental objectives which are so easily tossed off by politicians, it is very important to match the rhetoric with reality including the provision of adequate resources. In the present economic circumstances in Australia where we are seeing governments, both State and Federal, suffering real budgetary difficulties, the reality is that authorities which are charged with the responsibility of the management of these sensitive areas are hard pressed financially as well.

It is a very difficult environment in which to attract the additional resources that people might wish to see, whether it is for additional research into the crown of thorns starfish, to take an example which is relevant to the reef, or in the provision of the sort of manpower and I think public works which are required to see an area like the Daintree preserved if people are to continue using that area as they are at present. I simply wish to roll this thought up with the view that good environmental protection is in fact closely allied with economic success.

I think it is a truism to say that the poverty stricken countries of the Third World are those where we are most likely to find extremes of environmental degradation. We have just emerged from the period where the opening up of central Europe has reminded us that, even in long established industrial societies where the economies are badly run and resources are difficult to come by, environmental degradation is the norm. Even here, in fortunate Australia, a country which is not overcrowded and is blessed with a splendid environment in many respects, the truth is that very considerable resources are required if we are to meet the environmental challenges we have.

I say on behalf of the Opposition that we will always join with the Government in measures such as those which have been brought forward with respect to the Barrier Reef, and I have mentioned three tonight, because we wish to see appropriate laws in place. But I remind the chamber that, if we are to meet the really significant environmental challenges that we face not just on the reef but across the whole Australian land mass-and I pick for mention the question of soil conservation, the degradation of our soils, and the reduction of our water quality-the truth is that we need to have a very healthy economy if we are to produce the sort of surplus that is required to put resources to work.

In talking over recent months with people who are concerned with that, the premier environmental problem that Australia faces, I have been struck by the depth of their concern about the lack of resources to deal with those very broad problems. The point was made to me very tellingly that the sort of reconstructive work which is undertaken by, say, a mining operation such as Alcoa-work which received recognition at the United Nations level just a year or so ago-is possible because of the high value which is being achieved by the exploitation of that country.

A rather telling contrast was made to me about the problem of dealing with, say, an outback station which might be half a million acres or a million acres in area and which might be producing an income somewhat akin to that produced on a couple of thousand hectares or even less in a more settled and richer pastoral or agricultural area. The reality is that we face very, very substantial and high cost environmental problems which are not as glamorous as the Barrier Reef and which do not have the capacity to carry some of the costs because of tourist income that can be generated and so on. If we are over the next decade to have the capacity to divert resources to deal with those problems we will really need to have a more effective approach to economic management.

I make that point because too much of the environment debate in this country is isolated from the reality of economics and from the pressures which economic mismanagement and economic failure place upon environmental management. We had an example of it recently when dealing with the issue of recycling in the context of a report of the Industry Commission. The point was made in that report that one thing that inhibits the recycling of paper in Australia is the very high transport and port costs which make it too expensive to do things which would otherwise be environmentally friendly.

It is a relatively easy task for this Parliament to pass laws that will provide the very necessary physical protection for the reef, and again I express the wholehearted support that the Opposition has given to this process through to this point of legislating. If we are really concerned about our capacity in the long term to preserve the sort of thing that is being protected by this framework of legislation, we really do have to look to economic management.

I close by making the point that I have said often enough, both in this place and elsewhere, that the environment debate in this country has been somewhat debased and overpoliticised. It has been debased by its overpoliticisation. I use this as an example of the approach that the Opposition is seeking to adopt to ensure that matters are dealt with in substance and simply not treated as matters of short term politics.

I first became involved in this issue of ensuring compulsory pilotage in the Great Barrier Reef area when I received representations from the Australian Conservation Foundation. Those representations came from the Atherton Tablelands branch and seemed to be very sensible representations which certainly caused me concern. I took up the matter with the department and sought a briefing because it seemed to me that, whilst it would be perhaps of short term interest to me to issue a press release about what was drawn to my attention as a problem that had not been dealt with, it would be a good idea to get the facts straight before I actually ran out and played politics with it.

I acknowledge the very great readiness of Mr Kelleher to make himself available and to explain the position. He briefed me and made the point that both the department and the Authority were in fact engaged in a quite delicate international exercise to obtain international support for a measure of compulsory pilotage. The view was expressed that, given that the Chairman of the Marine Park Authority would shortly be presenting a paper to the meeting of the International Maritime Organisation in Sweden with the aim of getting that organisation to regard the reef world as a particularly sensitive area, we might withhold any action which might cause any outside concern.

The concern was expressed to me that there were a number of other countries rather adverse to Australia's approach in this matter and it was thought that it would not be helpful to make this matter a political controversy. So, I reported to the Australian Conservation Foundation in September last year on the outcome of those discussions and offered the assurance that the Federal Opposition would support strongly the need for pilotage. I said that the chances of a major catastrophe were simply too great and any controllable area of risk should be closed off. I said that, depending on how matters developed, whilst I would expect to have something to say publicly eventually, I was refraining from so doing at that stage to avoid arousing unnecessarily the concerns of some of the major nations whose sensitivities I have mentioned.

I simply offer that as some earnest of the Opposition's desire to cooperate with the Government and, indeed, with anyone else who is pursuing what we think are objectives which are genuinely aimed at achieving environmental protection in this country. I repeat the view that there has been excessive politicisation of many of these issues. They are often difficult issues. Fortunately, this is a straightforward one with which we are dealing tonight. Often there are difficult issues involving difficult trade-offs. I ask the Government to examine its own record in this regard and to adopt in future an approach which is more concerned with the substance of issues and less with the theatre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill implements a scheme of compulsory pilotage for ships which constitute a potential threat to the environment of the Great Barrier Reef. The measures contained in this Bill will improve the protection of one of the world's greatest assets and Australia's most treasured natural attraction.

SPEECH.PARA: The Great Barrier Reef is the largest system of corals and associated life forms anywhere in the world. It commences just north of Fraser Island and extends 2,000 kilometres along the east coast of Queensland. It covers an area of 348,700 square kilometres on the continental shelf of Australia. The Great Barrier Reef is acknowledged as an area of unique biological diversity and as an area of great natural beauty and wonder. A greater part of the Great Barrier Reef has been placed on the World Heritage List. Most Australians believe strongly that the Great Barrier Reef is a region requiring the highest possible level of environmental protection. As the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said in her second reading speech:

The Government has noted with concern the effects of spillages of oil and other toxic substances on the marine environment around the world and is of the view that such risks to the Great Barrier Reef should be minimised as much as possible.

This Government has had a longstanding concern to improve the protection of the Great Barrier Reef against possible spillages of oil and other toxic substances. For many years the Federal Government has encouraged the users of passages through the Great Barrier Reef to avail themselves of pilotage when and if it is available. The Department of Transport and Communications took the view that there could be difficulties at law, for example, in requiring compulsory pilotage on the high seas and that a unilateral declaration of compulsory pilotage would probably have been rejected by the International Maritime Organisation.

Notwithstanding that, the Department pursues with the International Maritime Organisation a recommendation that pilots be carried on vessels carrying oil or noxious or hazardous substances in the Barrier Reef waters. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has been a strong supporter of compulsory pilotage for ships on reef waters. The Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilots Service has also been a strong supporter of compulsory pilotage.

In 1983 the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works recommended in a report relating to the provision of navigational aids on Hydrographers Passage in the Great Barrier Reef that the Department of Transport pursue through the International Maritime Organisation an agreement to compulsory pilotage in Hydrographers Passage, which is just north of Mackay, with a system of exemptions, on examination, for suitably experienced masters. The Public Works Committee was conscious that pursuing this matter with the International Maritime Organisation would take considerable time and urged that Australia consider making a unilateral declaration for compulsory pilotage, subject to a favourable opinion from the Attorney-General's Department as to the legality of such a course of action. Furthermore, the Department of Transport and Communications stated in evidence that in its view the 1958 Convention on the High Seas provided a procedure by which special laws could be made for special areas. The Committee noted that `it would seem to the Committee that the Great Barrier Reef would qualify as a special area'.

It is interesting to note that, when the reference on Hydrographers Passage was referred to the Public Works Committee in October 1983, the then member for Darling Downs, the Hon. Tom McVeigh, urged the Government to proclaim compulsory pilotage in the area of Hydrographers Passage. His comments referred strongly to environmental protection of the Great Barrier Reef.

The subject of compulsory pilotage in reef waters has been discussed over a long period of time. In 1978, for example, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, in its report entitled Oil Spills, recommended, inter alia:

The Commonwealth Government at an international as well as national level encourage the acceptance of compulsory pilotage for all oil tankers and other types of vessels over 10,000 tonnes in areas where detailed local knowledge is required for safe navigation.

It was just three years ago that the Federal Government made recommendations to the International Maritime Organisation to introduce a system of voluntary pilotage-a system which was embodied in resolution A.619 (15). This resolution recommends that ships of 100 metres in length and over and all loaded oil tankers, chemical carriers or liquefied gas carriers, irrespective of size, use pilots when navigating the Torres Strait, the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef, the Great North East Channel and Hydrographers Passage.

At the time it was only the second place in the world where the International Maritime Organisation had adopted a similar resolution. When the resolution recommending a system of voluntary pilotage was adopted by the International Maritime Organisation, the Government hoped that this recommendation would induce all responsible shippers to carry pilots on their ships when transiting the Great Barrier Reef.

The recommendation has succeeded in having 90 per cent of the relevant vessels voluntarily carry pilots. However, many vessels have ignored, or by virtue of length are not covered by, this recommendation. Approximately 10 per cent of the vessels covered by the recommendation continue to transit the defined area of the reef without a pilot.

There are approximately 200 unpiloted transits per year. One of the chief offenders has been the United Kingdom. Many people would have suspected that shippers using flags of convenience, for example, Liberia and Panama, would be likely offenders, but in fact the United Kingdom has been one of the worst offenders.

Yet luck has held with the Great Barrier Reef. Since the Torrey Canyon disaster in 1969, there has not been a serious spill of any kind on the reef. This good fortune can be attributed to the excellent work being performed by the Department of Transport and Communications in the provision of navigation aids and its insistence that the rules of navigation be adhered to. Nevertheless, an accident similar to that of the Torrey Canyon disaster could have happened at any time. Furthermore, although ships now possess satellite navigation systems and are able to identify their position within 100 metres on the earth's surface, the old navigation Admiralty charts have some reefs marked more than 10 kilometres from their true location.

Zoning plans produced by the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority using satellite imagery have standard errors of less than 100 metres. Therefore, the zone plans are far more accurate than the Admiralty charts. Whilst a ship could have an accurate identification as to its position, it could easily run up against a reef because of the simple fact that the reef was not where it was marked on the old Admiralty charts.

The failure of a number of shippers to comply with the voluntary scheme could not be allowed to continue. The Government then decided to introduce a scheme of compulsory pilotage. In addition, as there have been a number of groundings of ships in the 70 to 100 metres range in recent years-certainly at least one per year-the ship length requirement will be reduced to 70 metres.

This new scheme will not encompass the Torres Strait and the Great North East Channel. These straits are used for international navigation and therefore attract the right of transit passage. Nevertheless, the great majority of ships using the Torres Strait and the Great North East Channel would be covered by the requirement for compulsory pilotage as ships transiting the inner routes of the Great Barrier Reef normally pick up or set down pilots at the western extreme of Torres Strait.

As Australia is a nation which supports the responsible application of international law and international cooperation, the Government sought endorsement of its proposal for compulsory pilotage from the international maritime organisation. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
