SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in this place, some of my colleagues will recall I have pointed out that, on 10 February 1964, we saw one of the worst disasters in the peacetime history of the Royal Australian Navy. I speak, of course, of the collision between the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft carrier and flag ship HMAS Melbourne off Jervis Bay, which claimed 82 lives. For nearly three years, I have been supporting the compensation cause of some 80 survivors through to a successful High Court precedent-setting action for one late last year. Regrettably, many of those survivors and their families still bear the scars of the tragedy-scars of psychological trauma, of persistent nervous shock, of domestic instability, of financial strain and, very importantly in this parliamentary setting, of misplaced confidence in and neglect by a government which espouses social justice but which demonstrably failed in this instance.

SPEECH.PARA: An editorial entitled `Justice at last' in the Brisbane Courier-Mail on 7 September last year said in part:

The view that the Commonwealth has behaved with despicable bureaucratic self-interest in the Voyager case would result in very little argument in the general community. The High Court ruling . . . paving the way for compensation claims by the survivors of that horrific 1964 naval accident is a signal victory for social justice.
It goes on:

The Commonwealth long denied liability for compensation. Mr Hawke's first government lifted the statute of limitations on the case in 1985, then slammed the door when it found there might be substantial compensation claims in the offing.
The editorial goes on to say:
About 80 survivors of the Voyager now are eligible to lodge claims to be compensated for the nightmare-
It continues:

The ruling means that the Commonwealth as the employer of people paid to defend the country cannot claim exemption from civil compensation if they come to harm in the course of normal duties. This is an important precedent. It is also elementary justice.
I regret to say that the path to justice once again has been obstructed. This is best illustrated in a recent letter I had from Jim Taylor, one of the claimants' counsel, which says in part:

Is the Government aware that in the Victorian Supreme Court on Wednesday 8th May on the third day of the Voyager trial (Clark -v- Commonwealth) the legal representatives of the Government sought and succeeded in having a Jury discharged because of possible prejudice to the Commonwealth by Counsel's opening address? Portions of the address were widely publicised in newspapers. In Counsel's address to the Jury the Commonwealth's conduct in seeking to relitigate all the Verwayen issues which case the Commonwealth lost in Verwayen -v- The Commonwealth (High Court 5th September, 1990):
(i) ``were described as being ``scungy'' tactics . . .
(ii) ``that the survivors had been engaged by the Commonwealth in a ``battle'' far more serious than any they were likely to have ``fought in their service in the Navy; and
(iii) ``that the Commonwealth was pertinacious-
which I understand means wrongly persistent-
(iii) in not accepting that the decision in Verwayen applied to all ``survivors of the collision.

. . . these comments were made in the light of known conduct of the Commonwealth and in the light of comments previously made by O'Bryan J. in the Supreme Court of Victoria in Verwayen's case . . . whereby His Honour stated . . . is most unfortunate and reflects poorly upon the conduct of the Defendant.
He goes on:

Clark issued his Writ in August, 1985 on the faith of the promises made by the Commonwealth and six years later the Commonwealth are fighting the whole issue over again in spite of their loss in Verwayen's case which was regarded by everyone as a test case.
Finally, Jim Taylor finishes with two questions. Firstly:

Why will the Commonwealth not accept the verdict of the umpire i.e. the High Court decision that Verwayen and those like him were entitled to have their cases tried and to have the solemn promise made by the Commonwealth to them adhered to?
Secondly:

Is it the policy of the Government to continue to treat members of the defence forces in this shabby fashion? Is this really the Government's policy or is the nose of some bureaucrat being put out of joint in these matters?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to make a couple of remarks and observations about the New South Wales State election results in the Illawarra region last weekend. In what was an unprecedented swing back to the Australian Labor Party in the Illawarra, for the first time in quite some time we saw the Labor Party's first preference votes increase significantly in the five seats which are identified with the Illawarra. Most importantly, we saw the demise of an Independent who had held the position as the member for Wollongong, certainly for the last two terms of government. That in itself was an underlying trend which existed in most parts of New South Wales on Saturday, 25 May-that is, the demise of Independents.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the Illawarra we saw that the incumbent, the Lord Mayor, Alderman Frank Arkell, was finally seen for what he has been for quite a long period of time-a very shrewd politician and a very shrewd tactician, but somebody whom the people of Wollongong at long last recognised could not deliver the goods and someone who, in fact, took credit for a lot of initiatives and a lot of groundwork that were delivered either by Federal Labor governments or by State Labor governments.

In the Illawarra we saw first preference votes of the order of 53.5 per cent-plus recorded in the seats of Bulli, Keira, Kiama and, indeed, Wollongong and 62.5 per cent in the seat of Illawarra. This demonstrates clearly the absolute abhorrence of the people of Illawarra for the attitude displayed towards our region by the Greiner Liberal Government during the last 3 1/2 years.

Without doubt, in my view, it is one of the most appalling records of any government's neglect and absolute wanton malaise inflicted upon a region such as our own, simply because in the 1988 change of government from Labor to the coalition in New South Wales the people of the Illawarra showed good sense and did not change their vote, unlike places like Newcastle and western Sydney. To the credit of the people in those other areas of New South Wales, they saw the folly of their ways on 25 May and, indeed, came back to the fold with a vengeance.

In the case of the Illawarra, I would like to commend the local Labor Party candidates for the excellent campaign that was run. Ian McManus in Bulli, Terry Rumble in Illawarra, Bob Harrison in Kiama, Gerry Sullivan in Wollongong and Colin Markham in Keira have certainly delivered to the people of our region and will continue to do so in what may yet be a new Labor government in New South Wales.

In any case, the fact has to be recognised that the sorts of claims that the incumbent, Frank Arkell, had made about the activities that he was able to institute, and the work and employment generation that he himself took full credit for in the State seat of Wollongong and, indeed, throughout the whole of the Illawarra, were exposed for what they were-simple, hollow rhetoric.

The grain handling facility, the State office block, the Commonwealth office block, the announcement of a new taxation office for the Illawarra, a range of employment initiatives, the construction of the Brandon Park sporting complex, the construction of the Croome Road sporting complex in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and so on were all initiatives of Federal Labor or State Labor governments.

The Greiner Government gave us the closure of the Tallawarra power station, the closure of hospitals and hospital wards, the closure of the Huntley coalmine, and massive increases in unemployment because of the policies it adopted. It continually turned its back on pleas for infrastructure developments such as the Maldon-Dombarton rail link, which would bring economic benefit to the region; it continually turned its back on the development of an alternative road access to the Illawarra via Caloola Pass; and it constantly turned its back, in the arrogant fashion for which it has become known, on all the pleadings of the people of the Illawarra.

On Saturday, 25 May, the people of the Illawarra returned to the Labor fold. They will be served well by the State Labor members who have been elected. It will be my pleasure and that of the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) and the honourable member for Throsby to work closely with them. We in government-and hopefully they too as State members in government-will work for the betterment of the people of the Illawarra. They will be rewarded for their continuing loyalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to bring to the attention of the House the ridiculous way in which the Child Support Agency is being administered. Unfortunately, the administration of child support no longer bears any relationship to commonsense. I am particularly concerned about the decisions made by the Child Support Agency in relation to Mr Kym Dart of Cressy in Tasmania. Mr Dart is a non-custodial parent responsible for three children. He freely acknowledges his responsibilities to his children and has always done everything possible to provide for their proper care and upbringing.

SPEECH.PARA: The children are in the care of their mother and, following the separation, both parents came to an amicable arrangement for the maintenance of the children that was quite adequate to care for the children. But that was before the advent of the Child Support Agency. The Agency now insists that Mr Dart pay 32 per cent of his gross earnings in child support, regardless of how much the actual cost of maintaining the children might be and regardless of whether their mother wants the money or not.

Mr Dart works 50 to 60 hours per week as a self-employed motor mechanic. He is working long hours in order to rebuild his life and, hopefully, to be able to remarry. However, as his earnings increase so too does the amount of money demanded by the Child Support Agency. Prior to July this year, Mr Dart has regularly paid $624.75 per month, but from August onwards the amount jumps to $967.17 per month. The increase means that the figure of $48 per week per child now jumps to $75 per week per child.

The increase has been determined without reference to Mr Dart and has been based on figures provided by him in his last tax return. The fact that his taxation figures can be used in this way, without his knowledge or his prior approval, is a blatant and, in my view, totally unacceptable abuse of the privacy and confidentiality that should normally be attached to taxation returns.

Mr Dart has been told by the Child Support Agency that the only way he can obtain relief from its decisions is to quit his business and go on the dole. It might sound totally warped and beyond the imagination of members of the House, but I assure the House that this is what is happening and that this is the advice being given by the Child Support Agency. Mr Dart is only one of many people who are being unfairly disadvantaged by the Child Support Agency, but those people who are disadvantaged have no recourse to proper appeal procedures.

It seems that the Child Support Agency regularly chooses to interfere in custody cases where the non-custodial parent is willingly honouring an obligation to the children and very often where an amicable arrangement has been arrived at between both parents and is working very well. However, the evidence that comes into my office suggests that the Agency will not provide assistance to locate and extract money from irresponsible parents who are not honouring their obligations and in a great many cases the custodial parent is left to cope as best he or she can without any help from the Child Support Agency.

I strongly suggest to the Government that this most inappropriate body, the Child Support Agency, should be scrapped, because it is nothing more than a rort for arrogant and incompetent bureaucrats. The facilities of the Family Court of Australia should then be expanded so that all matters relating to child maintenance can be decided and administered by the court, where they would be more appropriately handled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak of a very important event which took place on the weekend in Queensland, the inaugural conference of the Queensland Children's Activities Network Inc., which addressed the issue of child care. Nothing more starkly illustrates the difference between those of us on this side of the House and those opposite than when we hear opposition to parents paying for their children. It is part of the whole tax evasion process.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortuitously, we have many people in our community who care for children. The Queensland Children's Activities Network Inc. does just that. It is made up of people who provide outside school hours care for children in our community. As honourable members would be aware, many of the children in our schools are no longer latchkey children, because of the work of this Government and the provisions this Government has introduced. The network provides meaningful and quality child-care outside school hours and also during the vacation.

I was delighted that the chair of the conference was Rita McNamara, who is currently a director of the Jindalee outside hours school care program in my electorate but who unfortunately is moving to be director of another child-care program just outside my electorate. All the management committees for the child-care centres were there. Kris Mann was there from Our Lady of Lourdes After School Care at Sunnybank, which provides for anything from 80 to 100 families in after school hours care and also vacation care. People from Moorooka were also at the conference.

The network is very important because it provides support for these operations. At the conference, we had people from all over Queensland-from Mount Isa, the Gold Coast, Rockhampton, Townsville and other areas. The only area that was not represented was Toowoomba, and one can only ask why this might be so, particularly given the level of child abuse that operates in that town.

It is particularly important that we as a Government have acknowledged the very important role of outside hours care providers and recognise that, for them to deliver quality child-care, they must be provided with sufficient training and must have an operations policy for the way in which they conduct their centres. They provide very real use of one of the most underutilised resources in our community-our State schools and other non-government school centres. Through these providers, children find themselves in familiar surroundings after school, with caring people who give them an opportunity to participate in real play, who perhaps offer assistance with homework, who provide stimulation in play and who provide excursions and all sorts of trips and opportunities which normally the children would not be offered if they had to go home on their own and enter a house alone.

In contrast to that, people in the coalition talk about their opposition to the Child Support Agency, which suggests that they think non-custodial parents should not be made to pay for their children. Those opposite are the very same people who, in the next breath, berate this Government for providing support for families through the supporting parent's benefit. I suggest to the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) that he and many of the taxpayers in his electorate should be delighted to know that over 90 per cent of people comply with the requirements of the Child Support Agency. Indeed, close to half a million children in this country whose non-custodial parents previously did not provide support for them do so now. That is a very important turn-around in the community, but once again what we have from the Opposition is yet more tax evasion.

I am delighted that I was able to be part of the Queensland Children's Activities Network conference last weekend at Griffith to provide support and real training opportunities for people through the provision of quality and affordable child-care to which this Government has been so committed and in which its record is unsurpassed. I think that it is very important that that is acknowledged, not just by the providers but by the families who use our outside hours care and indeed by the very schools that find that the provision of those facilities in fact stops vandalism and provides very real and valuable use of their facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the record a distressing letter from a constituent. He refers to the wrong electorate and to the wrong Federal member. However, I will read the letter as he wrote it:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Atkinson,

According to our local phone book (Chelsea Frankston area) you are our sitting member and it is in you that I have the beef with being the locally elected democratic member representing the Government in Canberra and Keating and Hawke.

In the past 10 months I have been made redundant twice. Both have affected me financially, but more so in the past 3 months as I have been forced to live on the superannuation I received from the first redundancy which in effect was for my future retirement in 16 years time, as I am now aged 49 years and the way things are going I'll have nothing because of Mr Keating's created recession.

No-one, but no-one wants to employ me because I am too old at 49, which effectively puts me on the scrap heap and, because my wife works, I cannot get any unemployment benefits. Our debt situation is such she cannot support me in anyway, which means I am continually using the superannuation money-which, in the not too distant future will run out.

And sir, what do I do then? Do I go out and beg on the Salvos? Also this situation has put great strain on the marriage as, being unemployed creates marital stress on one, and I am at times very hard to live with. As my wife is not well herself this could lead to a marriage break-down.
THANKS LABOR!

In time this leaves us with one alternative-sell our fully paid for house to take the strain off the marriage, pay off all the debts and go back to where we started first in marriage, that's renting a house, and, my whole life destroyed with no owned house and no job. What a mess you have created for me and others.
Therefore it is regretfully that I have to advise that you are the personal representative for the Australian Labor Party Government-
I deny that-

in the area, and take responsibility for the members in your electorate, I shall, if I do not get a job soon (within a fortnight) intend to sue you as member for Isaacs for loss of income, loss of interest, and the possible forced sale of assets-house, car and shares in the near future.

The amount I'll be claiming from you depends on how long I am out of work and what the personal cost is to me, as it is to you so-called great government that has forced this issue on to me-I didn't ask for what I've got from the government that promised the world to everyone and what they have done is made a bigger mess than the previous federal government did and has put my life into utter chaos as it is no fun getting job refusal after job refusal then ringing up other places and asked age and when told advised that you are too old as we want someone younger.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better than being a dole bludger.
—He is not a dole bludger. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Of the dozens of job applications I have scored one interview and only 4 others have had the decency to write to say I've missed out and this only brings anger and frustration on and makes me a different person to what I am normally, hence the marriage strain, which could soon see it on the rocks.
Don't you people have a conscience-don't you care, do you enjoy putting people out to pasture with nothing after destroying all they had, and leave them stripped with no pride at all.

That is why, sir, you leave me no alternative but to sue you and the Federal Government for what I stated earlier and the loss of civil liberties that I'm entitled to in this so-called democratic country. They call it the ``lucky country''-big joke-how about the ``unlucky country''. Worse still the ``Dead Country''!!!
FULL OF NEAR DEAD POLITICIANS/WORKWISE AND UNCARING.
Therefore if nothing happens in a fortnight and I'm still without a job-ACTION WILL BE TAKEN.
Yours faithfully,
David John Spalding.
There is a postscript which reads:
As I've been hit in the hip pocket nerve, I can not see why the ``pollies'' that caused it can't suffer the same fate too. Hence reason to sue.

David John Spalding may have got the wrong electorate and the wrong member, but his message is quite clear. I invite the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), or both, to come to my electorate and meet Mr Spalding to tell him what they propose to do for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the contribution of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) with considerable sympathy for Mr Spalding. However, I am glad that Mr Spalding at least had a superannuation package to fall back on, because I wish to reveal to the House tonight that I have finally managed to solve the puzzle behind the behaviour of Jeff Kennett, the Leader of the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party of Australia, in his plan to penalise Australian Labor Party members of parliament in that State, were he to be elected to office, by taking away their superannuation after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become known to me that the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party has developed a plan to clean out public transport in Victoria by bringing about a massive transport dispute as soon as possible after assuming office in that State. On the premise of resolving the dispute, it plans to do an airline pilots job on that State's transport workers. At the moment many of these State transport workers are nearing retirement age and if they were to survive in their jobs until retirement, they would receive the normal superannuation payouts from the State's superannuation scheme. However, if the State Liberals can engineer a situation in which those workers are sacked as part of an industrial dispute, they would lose the government-funded part of their superannuation payouts.

The missing piece of the puzzle has come to my attention. For some time I have known of the plan to clean out Victoria's public transport system as a means of showing how macho the Liberals are in their first term of office when the Kennett government would have a greenfields public transport system. I have known of that plan-it has been around for a while-but I did not twig, because it took me a while to put two and two together, to the superannuation plan. This present farce of threatening to take away the superannuation rights of Labor members of parliament is only part of the real agenda behind Jeff Kennett's threat. In reality he wants to establish the right to withhold the government part of the superannuation payments to people who have not performed to his expectations.

The other part of the puzzle now starting to fall into place is that about six weeks ago the Opposition in Victoria started talking about the unfunded component of the superannuation scheme as some debt that the State Labor Government had imposed on Victoria. In the mid-1970s I was a member of Mr Hamer's superannuation review team that put to the then government the recommendation that it should make its contribution to superannuation payments at the same time as did the employees. But, no, for many years government practice has been to pay out only when the individual worker retires.

Now, many of these people are nearing retirement and are due to receive their government-funded component, and the Liberals are now claiming that in some way this is mismanagement-that is, that all this money is owed to the State superannuation scheme. Of course this is establishing the ground rules to not pay the government-funded component of the superannuation payments. That this is not just another crazy Kennett scheme designed to cause public wonderment at the antics of Jeff Kennett will not go unnoticed in Victoria. It is in fact a well developed strategy in order to produce a basis on which to deny these workers their superannuation entitlements.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (a) the large number of accounts held with Pyramid, Geelong and Country Wide Building Societies which ceased operations in June 1990 which remain unidentified and (b) progress payments which have not been claimed by the operators of some significant accounts.
(2) Does the Commonwealth have power to call for a list of either (a) all depositors or (b) those depositors who have not been identified.
(3) Has any investigation been undertaken to establish whether or not any of these accounts were being used for illegal or criminal purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I thank the honourable member for bringing these matters to my attention.

(2) &(3) I am informed that the Victorian Attorney-General has directed that an investigation into the circumstances of the collapse of the `Farrow Group' (comprising companies and building societies which I understand includes Pyramid, Geelong and Country Wide) be held under the Victorian Building Societies Act 1986. Under an arrangement agreed to with the then National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), the Victorian Attorney-General also directed a special investigation into associated companies under the Companies (Victoria) Code. I understand the Australian Securities Commission, which has now replaced the NCSC, currently intends to maintain this arrangement.

The relevant Commonwealth agencies have power to obtain information from any person in relation to a possible contravention of Commonwealth laws. For example, the Commissioner of Taxation has, under ss.263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the power to obtain information, including books and documents, for the purposes of performing his functions under the Act. In addition, the provisions of the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 require cash dealers, including building societies, to report suspect transactions and all cash transactions of not less than $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA).
I have arranged for the matters raised by the honourable member to be brought to the attention of these Commonwealth agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the CSIRO Division of Food Processing undertaking a genetic research project focussed on preserving the colour and taste of Kiwi fruit in dairy and other products; if so, (a) what is the status of the project, (b) have Australian commercial partners been sought; if so, to what extent, (c) what degree of interest has been shown in local commercialisation, (d) which overseas companies have signalled interest and (e) at what stage are negotiations to commercialise the research.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Research by the CSIRO Division of Food Processing has resulted in a process for preparing a kiwifruit product having the colour and aroma of the fresh fruit, and which could be suitable for use by the dairy, confectionery and similar industries. Further work will be required to establish the commercial viability of the process and product.
Australian commercial partners have been widely sought. For instance:
- over 800 food industry companies and individuals were invited to a free seminar on the technology.
- articles in publicly circulated CSIRO newsletters and magazines, and the Sydney Morning Herald, have described the technology and invited interested parties to contact CSIRO.
- the technology has featured in radio and TV programs.
- discussions have been held with 29 individual companies.

Additionally, the NSW Kiwifruit Growers Association (NSWKGA), which instigated and has supported the project, has contacted numerous potential processors in NSW, South Australia and Western Australia.
No Australian company has expressed willingness to commit funds to commercialisation of the technology.

Overseas interest has been shown by companies and institutions in New Zealand (including the NZ Kiwifruit Marketing Board, and NZ Apple and Pear Board, and the NZ Department of Scientific and Industrial Research) and in Israel, Japan, California, Italy, Chile and Germany.

With the approval of the NSWKGA negotiations are under way to collaborate in trials including the processing of 10,000 tonnes of kiwifruit in New Zealand. If successful, the trials could lead to an agreement for development and commercialisation. Agreement would be subject to the technology remaining available for use by the Australian industry, and it is further intended that there should be a flowback to Australia of technology arising from it.
Supplementary Information
The lack of interest of the Australian industry can probably be attributed to the following:
- the industry is small; it would have only about 2000 tonnes of processing grade fruit for treatment each year, compared with about 40,000 tonnes in New Zealand.
- the industry is widely dispersed from Southern Queensland along the NSW coast and through Northern Victoria, with a small planting in Western Australia.
- since a processed kiwifruit product retaining the natural colour and aroma has not previously been available it is difficult to assess the market potential.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the CSIRO's Division of Animal Production and Processing developed a protein which will enable wool to be removed from the sheep's back by hand without recourse to mechanical devices.

(2) Was the project which led to the development referred to in part (1) conducted jointly with a private company; if so, (a) which company, (b) is the company still in partnership with the CSIRO and (c) has the company been taken over by another company; if so (i) which company, (ii) is the second company foreign owned and based, (iii) does it have to respect the joint venture arrangements previously entered into, (iv) what were those arrangements and (v) what obligation does the second company have to (A) develop and (B) manufacture the technology locally.
(3) Who has the controlling interest in this new technology.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The CSIRO Division of Animal Production has developed an integrated technology for wool harvesting based on the naturally occurring peptide known as epidermal growth factor (EGF). Current predictions are that the technology will be available for use by the wool industry by 1993.

(2) Initial work, from the late 1970s until 1982 was carried out by CSIRO independently of any company, but with financial support (which has continued to the present day) from the Australian Wool Corporation.

(3) In the early 80s EGF could only be obtained from natural sources, such as the salivary glands of mice. To expedite availability of the technology to the Australian sheep industry it was essential to encourage the development of means for producing EGF in commercial quantities. As CSIRO was unable to locate an Australian company having the necessary expertise an approach was made in May 1982 to Carlsberg Biotechnology Ltd, a subsidiary of the Danish company United Breweries Ltd, who were known to have produced peptides using enzymes. An agreement was negotiated whereby Carlsberg Biotechnology Ltd were to provide EGF in return for rights to market EGF when prepared by their patented process. The collaboration was unsuccessful and this agreement was terminated in 1988.

In May 1984 CSIRO negotiated an agreement with Wellcome Australia Ltd, involving the genetically engineered production of EGF by the UK parent company, Wellcome Foundation Ltd. The agreement gave Wellcome Australia certain marketing rights, and required EGF for industrial use to be manufactured in Australia unless, for sound commercial reasons, that would be impractical; it also had provisions intended to ensure commercialisation if a safe, effective product was developed.
In October 1984 Wellcome Australia's interests were transferred to Coopers Animal Health Australia Ltd, a company in which Wellcome Australia and ICI Australia Ltd had joint interests.
Early in 1990 Coopers was acquired by the US group Pitman-Moore Inc. The rights and obligations of Pitman-Moore remain the same as those of Coopers.
Supplementary Information

Collaboration with Wellcome Australia, Coopers Animal Health and Pitman-Moore has proceeded to date on the basis of Heads of Agreement executed in 1984. A final agreement detailing, for instance, royalty rates and the precise limits of Pitman-Moore's rights is currently being negotiated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What interaction takes place between the CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Physics and the Bureau of Meteorology.
(2) Do the activities of the Division and the Bureau overlap.
(3) Is there scope for the Division and the Bureau sharing equipment and developing collaborative programs.
(4) Is the Division considering such interaction with the Bureau; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Substantial interaction takes place between the CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Research and the Bureau of Meteorology.
These interactions are formalised under a Co-ordinated Research Plan being developed by the two agencies and involving several CSIRO Divisions and several branches of the Bureau of Meteorology.

The plan encompasses atmospheric research including those aspects of oceanographic and terrestrial research which bear directly on weather and climate. Taking stock of current atmospheric research activities, CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology have identified 5 major research themes.
These are:
- observations
- processes
- regional pollution
- weather
- climate.

CSIRO and the Bureau will continue to meet annually to discuss their individual major research activities, and their five year plans, within a framework based on the overall long term national objectives defined in the Co-ordinated Research Plan and the major mission and discipline based groups in the two organisations. These meetings will also serve as the forum for the annual review of the Co-ordinated Research Plan. Informal interaction takes place frequently on a scientist to scientist basis, with a number of collaborative projects in progress.

(2) The roles of CSIRO and the Bureau are complementary as agreed between the then Department of Science and Technology and CSIRO in 1981 and endorsed by the Fraser and subsequent Hawke Governments. Specifically the respective roles are:

``The Bureau of Meteorology, as the National Meteorological Service for Australia, will have primary responsibility for research in support of its own operations and services, including research directed to the broad delineation of the characteristics of Australian weather and climate and for liaison with the World Meteorological Organisation in relation to relevant research in Australia.

CSIRO's primary role will be to carry out research into physical and chemical aspects of atmospheric processes and phenomena, especially basic aspects and those related to environmental and industrial problems, and to community needs, bearing in mind the role of the Bureau.''

(3) A prime example of the sharing of facilities is the joint operation of the Cape Grim Baseline Air Pollution Station in Tasmania by the CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Research and the Bureau of Meteorology. This station plays a vital role in elucidating the impact of human activities on the global atmosphere. Activities, data and research results at Cape Grim represent Australia's main contribution to the United Nations World Meteorological Organisation Background Air Pollution Monitoring Network. A second example concerns the extensive use of National Climate Centre data by the scientists working in the Division's climate change impact research program.
(4) The answers to questions 1 to 3 indicate clearly the extent of collaboration between the two agencies but there are two other aspects worth noting.

The first is that the Director and Deputy Director of the Bureau serve respectively on the Advisory Committees of the CSIRO Institute of Natural Resources and Environment, and the Division of Atmospheric Research.

The second fact worth noting is that the Division of Atmospheric Research, the Bureau of Meteorology Research Centre and Monash University are joint proponents in establishing a Cooperative Research Centre on Dynamical Atmospheric Modelling.
